The extent of occurrence (EOO) of the current known distribution is 5,676 km2, within which the species occurs between 0-300 m asl and occurs in three threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species occurs in Banco and Azagny National Parks, and in a newly created community forest reserve for the Tanoé swamp forest. The Tanoé forest is now managed by eight local communities, which comprise two separate associations with jurisdiction over the entire area, and the Wildlife Division of the Ministry of Environment; the management plan includes training local residents in forest management practices towards the long-term conservation of the site (Rainforest Trust).

Conservation Needed
The Banco subpopulation is at high risk of extinction, so improved management of this park is recommended to ensure the species' persistence. 

Research Needed
More research is needed into its population status and threats, monitoring of the Banco subpopulation is needed, and further work is required on the taxonomic status of records from Taï National Park.

rationale:
Aotus brumbacki is listed as Vulnerable due to a suspected population reduction of 30% or more over the last 24 years (three generations), which is likely to continue into the next 24 years.
Much of this monkey's presumed range lies within regions of savanna habitats that have already been cleared forest, fragmented forest and ongoing ‘hotspots of deforestation’. Surviving subpopulations remain threatened by ongoing and increasing habitat loss due to the planting of oil palm and illicit crops, expanding cattle ranching, increased oil exploration and mining, and fires.
habitat:
Night monkeys typically occur in primary and secondary forest (including disturbed forest and selectively logged forest), seasonally flooded and terra firma, lowland forest, and submontane and montane (cloud forests) in Colombia and the Andes to 3,200 m above sea level (the specifically montane forms are Aotus lemurinus and Aotus miconax) (Hernández Camacho and Cooper 1976, Aquino and Encarnación 1994a, Defler 2004). Aquino and Encarnación (1994b) reviewed the habitat and forest preferences of the genus. A research in San Martin area, in 100 forest fragments, found A. brumbacki groups in fragments of gallery forest, lowland rainforest and Mauritia flexuosa swamps (Carretero-Pìnzon and Defler in prep.)

Night monkeys are nocturnal: they are most active at dawn and dusk. The only exception is Aotus azarae azarae of the Chaco of southern Bolivia, Paraguay and Argentina, which is cathemeral (active during night and day). They are frugivorous; their diet includes fruit, nectar and flower (seasonally important for the A. a. azarae in the Chaco), leaves, and small animals prey such as insects (Wright 1989; Fernandez-Duque 2007). Aotus azarae has been observed to include a significant portion of leaves in its diet (Ganzhorn and Wright 1994, Wright 1985, Arditi and Placci 1990, Giménez and Fernandez-Duque 2003), as has Aotus zonalis on Barro Colorado Island in an early study by Hladik and Hladik (1969).

They are socially monogamous, living in small groups of an adult pair and offspring of different ages (infant, one or two juveniles and sometimes a subadult. In A. a. azarae, a significant number of adults range alone. They may be subadults that have left their natal groups or older adults which have been evicted from their groups by competitors (Fernandez-Duque and Huntington 2002, Fernandez-Duque 2004). Both sexes disperse. Males care for the infants (carry them) (Rotundo et al. 2002, 2005). Lone adults were observed by Villavicencio Galindo (2003) in northern Colombia. Night monkeys are territorial—groups occupy overlapping territories of 5-18 ha (depending on the species and location) (Wright 1978, Fernandez-Duque 2007). Solano (1995) estimated a home range of 17.5 ha for A. brumbacki on the Río Duda in Tinigua Natural National Park, Colombia. Wright (1994) and Fernandez-Duque (2007) review the behaviour and ecology of the genus.

Captive male A. lemurinus reach sexual maturity when two years old, and captive female A. vociferans and A. nancymaae first breed when 3-4 years old (Dixson 1983; Fernandez-Duque 2007). In the wild, male A. azarae reach adult weight only when about 4 years old, and age at first reproduction is about 5 years of age (Juárez et al. 2003, Fernandez-Duque 2004). A female A. azaraewas found to breed for the first time at 58 months of age (Fernandez-Duque et al. 2002). Single offspring are the rule. Wright (1985) recorded births between August and February for A. nigriceps in Peru (Manu National Park), and Aquino et al. (1990) indicated a birth season between December and March) for A. nancymaae in north-eastern Peru. In the Argentinean Chaco, A. azarae shows a peak of births between March and June (Fernandez-Duque 2007).

Size: Hernández-Camacho and Defler (1985) recorded a weight of 875 g for one individual (sex unknown), and 455 g for a female, probably not fully grown.
threats: Although the distribution of Aotus brumbacki remains poorly known, much of this Colombian endemic’s presumed range lies within regions of savanna habitats, already cleared forest, fragmented forest and ongoing ‘hotspots of deforestation’ (Etter et al. 2006, Sanchez-Cuervo and Aide 2013).  Three of four sub-populations inhabiting protected areas remained threatened; El Cocuy National Park lies within a region characterized as a deforestation hotspot (Sanchez-Cuervo and Aide 2013), while Serranía de la Macarena Natural National Park and Tinigua Natural National Park are surrounded by areas that are already more than 70% deforested (Etter et al. 2006, Carretero-Pinzon 2013) and/or subjected to high levels of armed conflict (Morales 2017). Surviving subpopulations remain threatened by ongoing and increasing habitat loss due to the planting of oil palm and illicit crops, expanding cattle ranching, increased oil exploration and mining, and fires (Baptiste et al. 2017).  In areas where armed conflict has subsided or the combatants have changed, these threats may be increasing, even within protected areas (Morales 2017).
population:
Little information is available regarding the total population size, structure and dynamics of Aotus brumbacki, save for the fact that few subpopulations have been documented or are assumed to be present in several protected areas. Of these, two subpopulations (Sierra de la Macarena National Park and Tiniqua National Park) have been reduced to fragments surrounded by areas where more than 70% of the forests have already been cleared since the year 2000 (Etter et al. 2006), and a third (El Cocuy National Park) lies within the largest identified  'hotspot of deforestation' located in the Colombian Llanos (Sancez Cuervo and Aide 2013).

Much of this monkey's presumed range lies within regions of savanna habitats that have already been cleared forest, fragmented forest and ongoing ‘hotspots of deforestation’. Surviving subpopulations remain threatened by ongoing and increasing habitat loss due to the planting of oil palm and illicit crops, expanding cattle ranching, increased oil exploration and mining, and fires. Based on these threats, it is suspected that the population has undergone a reduction of at least 30% over the last three generations (24 years), and that it will continue to decline at this rate for the next 24 years.
range: Aotus brumbacki is a lowland night monkey, that extends East from the Cordillera Oriental in Colombia between the Ríos Arauca and Guaviare (Hershkovitz 1983; Defler 2003, 2004). The form occurring along the middle and lower reaches of the Meta, Tomo and Vichada and Guaviare has not been ascertained. Based on a specimen collected at Maipures, near the mouth of the Río Tomo on the Río Orinoco, Defler and Bueno (2007) indicated that the night monkeys of eastern central Colombia North of the Río Guaviare may be A. brumbacki, extending the range of this species to the Río Orinoco. Neither Bodini and Pérez-Hernández (1987) nor Linares (1998) give any indication of the occurrence of A. brumbacki in Venezuela, north of the lower Río Arauca.
useTrade: Use and trade informations are missing for this species.
conservationActions:
This species is confirmed, or may occur, in the following protected areas:
  • El Cocuy Natural National Park (306,000 ha) (possibly in range, Defler 2003, 2004)
  • Serranía de la Macarena Natural National Park (630,000 ha) (in range, Defler 2003, 2004)
  • El Tuparro Natural National Park (548,000 ha) (possibly in range, Defler 2003, 2004)
  • Tinigua Natural National Park (201,875 ha) (Solano 1985, 1986).
This species is listed on Appendix II of CITES (as Aotus lemurinus brumbacki).

rationale: This species is listed as Endangered because Sclater’s Monkey is estimated to have undergone a population decline exceeding 50% over the past three generations (about 27 years, assuming a generation length of nine years), resulting from a decline in area of occupancy and habitat quality, and high levels of exploitation. This decline is projected to continue into the future, and its rate will probably intensify due to continuing widespread habitat loss and degradation and hunting. Additionally, the species does not occur in any officially gazetted wildlife conservation area. In large part, Sclater’s Monkey persists due to its small size, cryptic nature, adaptability and general non-preferred status among hunters relative to other monkeys. Close population monitoring should take place. However, such monitoring may be hampered by insecurity in the Niger Delta and in other parts of the species’ range and by the lack of an organised national programme in Nigeria focusing on Sclater’s Monkey.
habitat: The original habitat of Sclater’s Monkey is moist tropical lowland forest, but due to severe habitat degradation, this species now persists in remnant secondary, gallery/riparian and freshwater swamp forests. The species is also found in marginal forest and farm-bush in communities where monkeys are regarded as sacred (Oates et al. 1992, Tooze 1995, Baker 2005). Sclater’s Monkey is likely omnivorous, with a diet similar to other members of the C. cephus group: mostly fruits, insects and young foliage (Oates and Baker 2013).
threats: The rapidly growing human population of Nigeria is expected to be the third largest globally by 2050. This growth has been accompanied by widespread environmental degradation and will continue to negatively affect natural habitats. Across Nigeria, land area devoted to agriculture and plantations (crop and grazing lands, floodplain agriculture, irrigation and livestock projects, and tree and forest plantations) increased by nearly 84,000 km² between 1976 and 1995. More than half of the country’s undisturbed lowland moist forest was lost during that same time frame (from 25,951 to 12,114 km²) (Geomatics International et al. 1998). From 1990–2015, net forest loss across Nigeria continued at a rate of 3.5% annually, resulting in a loss of ~4,100 km² each year – more than any other African nation. During this period, Nigeria lost 59.4% of its forested area and 98.7% of its primary forest (FAO 2015). During the latter part of this period, from 2000–2015, the rate of forest loss across Nigeria accelerated (5%) (FAO 2015), and the percent of forest cover declined from 14.4% to 7.7% (World Bank 2017). Conversion of forested areas to farmland is a major contributor to this decline; for the decade ending in 2008, Nigeria converted more land to annual crops than did any other tropical nation (Phalan et al. 2013). The southeastern region of Nigeria, where Sclater’s Monkey occurs, has among the highest human population densities in the country and one of the highest in Africa. As a result, most natural forest across this species’ range has been converted to cultivated land; unregulated logging and activities associated with oil exploration and production have added to the destruction (Oates et al. 1992, Baker and Olubode 2008). Of particular concern for Sclater’s Monkey is severe habitat fragmentation, resulting in a lack of connectivity among existing populations and associated loss of heterozygosity in population isolates. Additionally, the species does not occur in any official wildlife conservation area or have any effective protection from exploitation outside of the very few sites where it is protected by local communities owing to social taboos.
population:
Given widespread habitat loss across this species’ range, many of the remaining populations of Sclater’s Monkey are isolated, and most occur in highly degraded, unprotected forests. This degradation, combined with hunting pressure and lack of official protection, has led to decline of the population. The species’ persistence in southeastern Nigeria can be attributed to the species’ small size, shy nature and adaptability, and preferential hunting of larger-bodied primate taxa (Baker and Olubode 2008). Until the 1990s, Sclater’s Monkey was thought to be very rare, but extensive surveys since then have revealed its presence at a number of formerly unknown sites. In one regional survey, Baker and Olubode (2008) did not encounter any localities of recent extirpation (or sites where local reports indicated that populations of this species had been extirpated even though suitable habitat remains). Nevertheless, encounter rates were low: 0.18 detections per km surveyed.

In the very few sites where it is not hunted, or where hunting is less commonly practised (such as the Niger Delta where some communities rely on fish as their main protein source), this species may fare relatively well compared to larger primates. In the Edumanom Forest Reserve, a comparatively large forest block in the Niger Delta, one study found Sclater’s Monkey to be the most abundant diurnal primate encountered, occurring in an estimated 3.1 groups per km² (Baker et al. 2011). In three village sites where Sclater’s Monkey is protected by social taboos (i.e. monkeys are not killed), populations appear to increase: 1) Lagwa, Imo State (Baker et al. 2014a); 2) Akpugoeze community complex, Enugu State (Baker et al. 2014a, 2018); and 3) Ikot Uso Akpan, Akwa Ibom State (Eniang and Egwali 2011). However, the survival of these populations requires them to adapt to living in heavily deforested, urbanizing environments. Although apparently increasing, these populations are also relatively small: 178 individuals in Ikot Uso Akpan (Eniang and Egwali 2011), 206 individuals in Lagwa (Baker et al. 2014a), and 339 individuals in the Akpugoeze community complex (Baker et al. 2018).
range: This species is endemic to southern Nigeria. It ranges from the eastern Niger Delta in Bayelsa State east to the Cross River, and north to Enugu and Ebonyi States; the most northerly known populations occur in southern Anambra-Enugu States and central Ebonyi State (Baker and Olubode 2008). Sclater’s Monkey was feared extinct until it was sighted southwest of Oguta, Imo State, in 1988 (Oates and Anadu 1989). Additional populations were subsequently discovered in the early to mid-1990s (Oates et al. 1992; Tooze 1995, 1996). In a 2004 regional survey, the species was located in several sites where it had not been previously recorded (Baker 2005, Baker and Olubode 2008). Across its range, this species has generally been recorded in fragmented, degraded forests (Oates et al. 1992, Tooze 1995, Baker and Olubode 2008).
useTrade: Being the smallest diurnal primate across its range (along with Cercopithecus erythrogaster), Sclater’s Monkey has the lowest economic value as bushmeat relative to other diurnal primates. While it is sought after by hunters, some hunters consider the species more difficult to kill due to its size and cryptic nature, and some do not bother hunting Sclater’s Monkey given the lower profit it brings (Baker and Olubode 2008).
conservationActions:
This species is currently listed as Class B under the African Convention and under Appendix II of CITES.

There are no formally protected areas in the range of Sclater’s Monkey. Important conservation measures suggested by Baker (2005) include: 1) elevating the species to Schedule I of the Nigerian Endangered Species Act (this change may not be considered unless the species is elevated to CITES Appendix I); 2) raising awareness about the species and its uniquely Nigerian status through publicity and education; and 3) enhancing protection of key forests, including the Edumanom Forest Reserve in Bayelsa State, Upper Orashi Forest Reserve in Rivers State and the Stubbs Creek Forest Reserve in Akwa Ibom State.

Communities where Sclater’s Monkey receives cultural protection (through social taboos) are also very important, although forest cover in these sites has been greatly reduced over time. These include Ikot Uso Akpan and other communities in the Itam region (Akwa Ibom State), Lagwa (Imo State) and the Akpugoeze community complex (Enugu State). In Lagwa and Akpugoeze, previous and existing conservation measures include school-based awareness programmes, stakeholder workshops, documentation and publishing of folklore and oral histories related to the cultural value of monkeys, and population and forest monitoring (Baker 2013; Baker et al. 2009; 2014a,b; 2018). Forest restoration and conservation awareness efforts have also been conducted in Ikot Uso Akpan (Jacob et al. 2013). Development of small-scale ecotourism in these communities should be explored, given how readily monkeys can be observed at these sites.

Other potential areas for enhanced protection are the Niger floodplain and Osomari Forest Reserve (Oates et al. 1992), as well as the Blue River (Azumini, Abia State) and Enyong Creek/Ikpa River (Akwa Ibom State) (Tooze 1995).

rationale: Mandrillus sphinx is listed as Vulnerable in view of the widespread hunting pressure on this species, combined with habitat degradation across most of its range. It is suspected that these threats have resulted in a population decline exceeding 30% over the past 24 years (ca three generations) and which is unlikely to abate in the near future. The taxon therefore qualifies as VU under criterion A2cd.
habitat:
Mandrills are found in evergreen rainforest, stretching between 100 and 300 km inland from the Atlantic coast, as well as in montane forest, and secondary forest. They avoid thick undergrowth areas and marshes. Mandrills are known to cross areas of savanna up to 180 m across to access forest fragments and have been known to enter plantations. They are semi-terrestrial and usually forage at less than 5 m above ground. Mandrills are omnivorous and their diverse diets include fruits, buds, leaves, roots, insects, fish, meat, crustaceans, fungus and seeds (Rogers et al. 1996). Seeds form a more important part of the diet than the flesh of fruits, and large seeds are usually consumed (not dispersed).

Data on the home range of a group which is not hunted come from only one site: Lopé National Park in Gabon, where a horde of ~720 individuals has remained stable over 20 years, using 182 km² of forest-savanna mosaic habitat, including 89 km² of suitable forest habitat. The group used gallery forests and isolated forest fragments with high botanical diversity far more intensively that the continuous forest block (White et al. 2010). Males travel with the female and offspring horde only during breeding (June–September) and range alone at other times of the year, visiting the group occasionally if any females become reproductively fertile outside the usual season (Abernethy et al. 2002). Day range length for the Lopé horde averages 4.9 km per day, but for lone males is only 1 km per day. 

Humans are the Mandrill's major predator. Leopards and pythons are also known to predate Mandrills, but Crowned Hawk Eagle is not known to. Golden Cat and smaller carnivores are also not known to take Mandrills.
threats: Mandrills appear to be most seriously threatened in Cameroon and Equatorial Guinea.This species is affected by the destruction of its evergreen forest habitat since this reduces the capacity of environments to support Mandrill populations. However, the most immediate threat is posed by poaching for their meat (Abernethy and White 2013, Abernethy et al. 2013). Large males are preferentially targeted. Commercial bushmeat hunters pose a particular threat to populations that are located close to main roads and towns. Annual offtakes per hunted horde are likely to be lower for modern day hunters using guns and snares than in the past when hunters used dogs and nets, which could result in very high offtakes (>20% of the group in one hunt). However, impacts are more widely spread across the species' geographic range.
population: Total numbers of mandrills are unknown, but it is suspected that the species has declined significantly in recent years. Mandrills range in large hordes of several hundred individuals (Abernethy et al. 2002, Hongo 2014), but groups in areas suffering intense subsistence hunting pressure (notably Cameroon and Equatorial Guinea) are reported to be much smaller and they have been extirpated from some areas. The largest remaining populations are to be found in Gabon. Intact forest can support densities of around 10 individuals/km², but distribution is likely to be patchy and densities much lower in areas that have experienced long-term hunting pressure.
range: Mandrills are found in moist evergreen rainforest in central west Africa, south of the Sanaga River (Cameroon) through to mainland Equatorial Guinea, much of southern Gabon, and south-western Republic of Congo to the Kouilou River, and down to the Congo River. Inland, the lower Ivindo River and Ogooué River in Gabon limit its distribution to the east, but on two occasions mandrills have been recorded in the Garabinzam area of northwestern Congo, east of the Upper Ivindo (Fay 1989, Allam et al. 2016). In Cameroon, mandrills have been recorded in the Dja Biosphere  Reserve using with camera traps, and this appears to be at the northwestern limit of their range (Bata et al. 2017). Camera traps have also recorded mandrills at the source of the Ogooué, extending the species' range a little into the Batéké Plateaux National Park in Gabon (Hedwig et al. 2017). Mandrills do not occur in south-east Cameroon or east of the Congo River. The Ogooué River bisects the species range, separating them into two distinct populations: i) Cameroon, Equatorial Guinea and northern Gabon and ii) southern Gabon and Congo (Telfer et al. 2003).
useTrade: Mandrill carcasses have been recorded for sale in both rural and urban markets in all four range states in each of the past 15 years (www.offtake.org). In two extensive surveys of village hunters in Gabon, mandrills were the second rarest catch, accounting for <1% of village offtakes by number of animals in each site (Coad 2007, van Vliet 2008). The price of Mandrill meat in provincial towns in Gabon in 2014 was around $4 per kg, which was not significantly different to the average price of other bushmeats.
conservationActions: Mandrills are listed under Appendix I of CITES, and as Class B under the African Convention. There are many parks and reserves in the Mandrill's range, and their presence has been confirmed in at least one protected area in each range state and in most of the protected areas in their geographic range. Surveys are urgently needed to determine where viable populations still exist outside protected areas, and whether the populations in protected areas are at risk of isolation and fragmentation.

rationale: Although historically this species persisted quite well in degraded secondary forest, given continued major habitat destruction across most of its geographic range, and increasing hunting pressure on small-bodied animals as larger species are driven to extinction, the Calabar Angwantibo has been recognised as justifying at least Near Threatened status. It is estimated to have lost at least 20% of its habitat in the last 10-15 years (about three generations, based on a generation length of 4.6 years given by Pacifici et al. 2013); based on this habitat loss, it is suspected that the population size has also declined by at least 20% over the last three generations. More research is required to establish whether this species qualifies for a threatened category.
habitat: The Calabar Angwantibo is most often found in areas of dense, low undergrowth with abundant lianas and vines below 5 m in the understorey of primary and secondary rainforest; it particularly favours the growth that springs up in clearings, trees falls, and along forest edges (Jewell and Oates 1969). Therefore, wherever it is already established, small-scale forest clearance, selective tree-felling and road-making probably favour this species. In such areas it can becomes relatively abundant in thickets and patches of dense secondary growth. Its diet is invertebrates and fruits; based on the ecology of its sister taxon Arctocebus aureus in Gabon, it is likely that caterpillars form an important part of its diet. This species is able to produce two single young in a year, with a minimum inter-birth interval of about 4.5 months (Oates and Ambrose 2013).
threats: The biggest threats to the Calabar Angwantibo are the clearance of forest for cultivation, as well as some hunting for meat. Although this species can adapt to low-level habitat disturbance (if some dense undergrowth remains and inter-tree distances are not too great), major forest conversion to intensive and/or industrial agriculture is likely to eliminate it because of its weak capacity to disperse. Such forest destruction is increasing dramatically in many parts of its range, and especially in eastern Nigeria, as the human population continues to grow and economic development intensifies. For instance, in the period 1990–2015, Nigeria suffered an estimated 59.4% loss of forest cover, while the loss in Cameroon was 22.6%; in 1990–2000 the rate of forest loss was 2.7% per annum in Nigeria compared with 0.9% per annum in Cameroon, but in 2010–2015 these rates had increased to 5.0% per annum in Nigeria 1.1% per annum in Cameroon (FAO 2015). As other wildlife has declined, hunting pressure on smaller mammals has increased, and angwantibos now feature in many bushmeat reports (Svensson and Friant 2014, Svensson et al. 2016). In some areas they may also be killed when encountered because they are considered a bad omen (E.L. Gadsby pers. comm. 2016), and they feature in small quantities in trade as pets and for body parts (Svensson and Friant 2014, Svensson et al. 2015).
population: The Calabar Angwantibo is a cryptic species that can be locally abundant within its patchy distribution. In southeastern Nigeria in the 1960s it was encountered at a rate of 0.7 individuals per km (Jewell and Oates 1969). Originally, angwantibos were probably adapted to tree-fall gaps in the forest and to forest edges (Charles-Dominique 1977); as high forest has suffered increasing anthropogenic disturbance, habitats resembling tree-fall gaps and forest edge have become more widespread. However, with forest disturbance by humans in Nigeria and Cameroon giving way to wholesale forest clearance, and hunting pressure increasing, populations of Calabar Angwantibos are almost certainly declining.
range: The Calabar Angwantibo has a very patchy and localised distribution within the lowland rainforest block between the Niger River and the Sanaga River in eastern Nigeria and western Cameroon.
useTrade: This species is hunted for meat.
conservationActions: This species is listed as Class B under the African Convention, and under Appendix II of CITES. It is known to occur in Cross River National Park (Nigeria) and Korup National Park (Cameroon). It probably occurs in several other protected areas in the region, although its presence is not yet confirmed. Further surveys are needed to determine its true conservation status, and careful research is required to better understand the impacts of habitat conversion and hunting on its populations.

rationale: Plecturocebus ornatus is listed as Vulnerable in light of a continued decline inferred from more than a 30% loss of habitat in the past three generations (24 years), which is expected to continue at the same rate for the next three generations, due to a decline in area of occupancy and habitat quality as a consequence of deforestation caused by African palm oil expansion, petrol exploration and exploitation, illicit crops and expanding human settlements (Carretero-Pinzón 2013).
habitat:
Titi monkeys are known to occur in a wide range of habitats, although some species exhibit habitat preferences, for example Cheracebus lucifer is reported to prefer white-sand forests (Heymann pers. comm., 2008) and Plecturocebus donacophilus drier forests (Ferrari et al. 2000, Wallace pers. comm.). Members of the Plecturocebus moloch and Plecturocebus cupreus groups are considered tolerant of habitat disturbance caused by human activity or seasonal flooding (Roosmalen et al. 2002). Plecturocebus ornatus typically occurs in lowland tropical forests (canopy 15-20 m) (Defler 2010) and disturbed habitats (Mason 1968). A recent research in San Martin area, in 100 forest fragments, found P. ornatus groups in fragments of gallery forest, lowland rainforest and Mauritia flexuosa swamps (Carretero-Pinzón and Defler, in prep).

The ecology of this species has been studied in the department of Meta by Mason (1965, 1966, 1966, 1968, and 1971) and Robinson (1977, 1979, 1979, 1981, and 1982). Polanco (1992) and Porras (2000) studied a population near the Duda River.
threats: This species occurs in an area subject to intense human colonization that has been subject to widespread habitat destruction and fragmentation. As mentioned by Carretero-Pinzón (2013) a reduction of 35% of their distribution area has occurred in the last decade. This habitat loss and fragmentation has been produced by cattle ranching, palm oil plantation extensions and petrol exploration and exploitation (Wagner et al. 2009, Carretero-Pinzón 2013).
population:
Robinson (1977) recorded a population density of five individuals/ km². Wagner et al. (2009) found higher densities (192.2 ind/ km2) in small fragments, while Carretero-Pinzón (2013) found lower densities (57.94 ind/ km2 and 1.073 ind/ km2) for range of fragments between 16 ha and 1,050 ha.

Carretero-Pinzón (2013) reported a 35% reduction of distribution area for this species between 2003 and 2013 caused by habitat loss and fragmentation. Habitat loss is continuing. As a result, it is suspected that the population has suffered a reduction of at least 30% over the last 24 years (three generations), and that this reduction is likely to continue over the next 24 years.
range: This species occurs in eastern Colombia, in the department of Cundinamarca (Medina) north as far as the lower Río Upía/ Río Meta, south into the department of Meta, along the base of the Cordillera Oriental and the Sierra de la Macarena to the Río Guayabero/ upper Río Guaviare. It is the only member of the cupreus and moloch group occurring north of the Rios Amazonas/ Solimões/ Napo axis, in the upper Río Orinoco basin and is separated from the nearest other member of the cupreus group (Plecturocebus discolor) in the south by at least 350 km (Roosmalen et al. 2002). Eastern limits are poorly known but probably extend beyond Metica River (Defler 2010).
conservationActions: This species occurs in La Macarena National Park and Tinigua National Park. Although some populations are found within protected areas, guerilla activity makes it difficult to monitor these areas (T. Defler pers comm.).It is listed on CITES Appendix II.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern because, although its Extent of Occurrence is much less than 5,000 km<sup>2</sup>, it is common, adaptable, and does not appear to be in decline.
habitat: It lives in primary forest, farm bush (heavily degraded former forest), coconut groves, coffee plantations and disturbed areas. It lays its eggs on leaf surfaces over still or very slow-moving water, and the tadpoles develop in the water.
threats: It is currently not threatened, given its adaptability to modified habitats. A potential future threat is the development of the oil industry in the islands, which is likely to radically alter the overall environment.
population: This species is common on both islands.
range: This species occurs on São Tomé and Príncipe islands (in São Tomé and Príncipe) from close to sea level up to at least 1,420 m asl. Its Extent of Occurrence is much less than 5,000 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized.
conservationActions: It is present in Obo National Park.

rationale:
This species was known from the southern part of Euphrates and Tigris drainages in Syria, Iraq and Iran. However it is now absent from most parts of its distribution area and may only survive in Al-Huwazah marsh in Iraq, and the adjacent Hawer Al-Azim marshes and lower parts of rivers Zohreh, Karkheh and Karoun in Iran. These marsh areas have been reduced to just over 1,000 km² (in 2000), 35% of its size in 1977 (Richardson and Hussain 2006). It is also still present in Lake Assad in Syria (600 km²).

Due to overfishing and the destruction of marshes this species declined massively, by more than 80% since 1977. However, this decline took place more than 12 years ago (three generations) and the current population is low and fluctuating. Its total area of occupancy is 1,600 km² and it is known from two locations. Over harvesting is still a threat to the species, however education campaigns and the adoption of traditional 'Hima System' resource management has recently been adopted by local tribes to try and conserve the remaining fish resources in the southern Iraqi marshes.

The species is also susceptible to the large dam projects in the headwaters of the Tigris which will lead to a lack of water for biodiversity in marshes at the lower Tigris. It is also susceptible to introduced fish species, including Oreochromis aureus and Tilapia zillii which are present in the southern Iraqi marshes and are known to have major negative impacts. There is large oil development undergoing in the southern Iraqi marshes region, so oil spills are also a real potential threat to the species. The species is assessed as Vulnerable.
habitat: The species occurs in large rivers, lakes and marshes, mostly in standing waters of marshes with dense vegetation. It spawns on vegetation. Its generation length is estimated to be four years. Spawning time is during March and April in Huywazah marsh, Iraq (Al-Mukhtar et al. 2006). Fecundity is recorded at 16,068–358,343 eggs of 253–561 mm in total length (Al-Daham and Jasim 1993).
threats: The destruction of marshes as well a strong fishing pressure seem to be the main threats acting on this species. Fishermen use forbidden tools such as toxins and very small mesh-size gill nets to catch this species, which is a major target species in the marshes. Eastern Al-Hammar marshes are also being impacted by salinisation due to a canal connecting it to the sea. The species is also susceptible to the large dam projects in the headwaters of the Tigris which will lead to a lack of water for biodiversity of marshes at the lower Tigris, and the introduced fish species including Oreochromis aureus and Tilapia zillii which are present in the southern Iraqi marshes and are known to have major negative impacts. There is a large oil development undergoing in the southern Iraqi marshes region, so oil spills are a real potential threat to the species.
population:
A decade ago, this was a common commercial species all over its range. It has since crashed and a loss of more than 90% is inferred.

Before 1977, the species made up 25% of inland fisheries catch in Iraq (Al-Daham 1977). Latest studies show a huge decline in abundance: 'few' in 1984-1987 (Hussain et al. 1988); 0.32 (% of catch in lower Tigris) in 2005 (Mohammed et al. 2006); 1.0 (% of catch in Euphrates south Baghdad) in 2002-2003 (Al-Rudainy et al. 2006); 4.3 (% of catch southern marshes) in 2004-2005 (Hussain et al. 2008); 0.15 (% of catch Al-Hammar marsh) in 2005-2006 (Hussain et al. 2009); 1.4 (% of catch Huwazah marsh) in 2005-2006 (Mohamed et al. 2008); 1.6 (% of catch Al-Safia reservation Huwazah marsh) in 2006-2007 (Younis et al. 2008); 0.14 (% of catch in Um Al-Naaj, Huwazah marsh) in 2008 (Younis et al. 2011); 0.2 (% of catch Shatt Al-Basrah canal) in 2008-2009 (Younis and Al-Shamary 2011).
range: The species was known from the southern part of Euphrates and Tigris drainages in Syria, Iraq and Iran. In Iraq it was once widespread in Shatt Al-Arab River and lower parts of Euphrates, Tigris and Diyala Rivers including Al-Hammar marshes and Al-Huwazah marshes, Lakes Saniyah, Habbaniyah, Tharthar and Razzazah and reservoirs Al Qadisiyah and Dukan. However, it has now vanished from large areas: it is absent from most parts of its distribution area in Iraq, and might only survive in Al-Huwazah marsh in Iraq and the adjacent Hawer Al-Azim marshes and lower parts of rivers Zohreh, Karkheh and Karoun in Iran. These marsh areas have been reduced to just over 1,000 km² in 2000, 35% of its size in 1977 (Richardson and Hussain 2006). It is also still present in Lake Assad in Syria (600 km²).
useTrade: This is a species of major commercial importance and there is a high fishing pressure on it.
conservationActions: There are fishing regulations which are more or less not enforced. Traditional 'Hima System' resource management has recently been adopted by local tribes to try and conserve remaining fish resources in the southern Iraqi marshes. An integrated environmental and social management plan for the whole southern Iraqi marshes is also being developed by IUCN and the Iraqi Government.

rationale: Listed as Near Threatened because its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 39,553 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs at seven to ten threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its Yungas forest habitat, thus making the species close to qualifying for Vulnerable. Furthermore, this species is a habitat specialist with a patchy distribution and it has a weak dispersal ability, thereby making it more susceptible to threatening activities.
habitat: This species inhabits subtropical humid montane Yungas forest. It is a habitat specialist and strictly associated with small outcrops of Neogene red-brown strata of mudstone interbedded with sandstone (Akmentins 2011). These outcrops are frequent in areas associated with human activities, such as road construction and maintenance, or clear cutting of the forest for cattle grazing, however this frog is not expected to tolerate habitat disturbance (M.S. Akmentins pers. comm. May 2018). The habitat specialization restricts the effective quantity of available habitat for the species in contrast to the sympatric leaf litter frog species, Oreobates discoidalis, which inhabits the forest floor (M.S. Akmentins pers. comm. September 2017). Males call at dusk and night from bare ground or from small rocks, exhibiting territorial behaviour and defending their calling sites against conspecific males (Akmentins 2011). Reproduction is by direct development and egg clutches are laid in rock crevices (Goldberg et al. 2012).
threats: Yungas Andean forests face serious conservation threats, such as selective logging of valuable woody species; clear cutting of primary forest and forestation with exotic species; extensive cattle raising; oil investigation and exploitation; and development of civilian engineering projects (Lavilla and Heatwole 2010). Specifically, subpopulations at La Tablada, Salta province (Akmentins and Vaira 2009) are at risk from maintenance work on the Argentina-Chile gas pipeline (M.S. Akmentins pers. comm. September 2017). Subpopulations at the northeast portion of Calilegua National Park, Jujuy province (Padial et al. 2012) are at risk from oil exploitation (M.S. Akmentins pers. comm. September 2017). Subpopulations near the unpaved route 83 of Jujuy province (Akmentins and Vaira 2009), will be at risk due to a civil engineering project to widen the route for increasing the vehicle traffic (M.S. Akmentins pers. comm. September 2017). Finally, a recent increasing interest in developing bio-ethanol industries will result in the clear cutting of large areas of forest for extensive sugar cane crops (M.S. Akmentins pers. comm. September 2017).
population: It is locally abundant where it occurs, however subpopulations are patchily distributed throughout its range (M.S. Akmentins pers. comm. September 2017). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is endemic to the Yungas Andean forest ecoregion of northwestern Argentina, and is known from from Salta Province (Vaira and Ferrari 2008), Jujuy Province (Akmentins and Vaira 2009) down to Tucumán Province (Akmentins et al. 2012). This species probably occurs in Bolivia (Vaira and Ferrari 2008), but confirmation is needed. All geographical localities lie between 550 and 1,725 m asl. It is considered to have a fragmented distribution because the Yungas eco-region is patchy, separated by the more dry and lower Chacoan eco-regions, which are currently being converted to agriculture (Lavilla and Heatwole 2010). In addition to being a habitat specialist, this species is considered to have a poor dispersal ability and may not occur between the localities where it has been recorded (M.S. Akmentins pers. comm. September 2017). Its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 39,553 km2 and all individuals are expected to occur in seven to ten threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species has been recorded at Baritú National Park in Salta province, Calilegua National Park in Jujuy province, and Portrero de Yala and Serranias de Zapla Provincial Reserves in Jujuy province (Padial et al. 2012, M.S. Akmentins pers. comm. September 2017).

Conservation Needed
However, given threats occurring throughout the Yungas ecosystem and outside of these protected areas, additional habitat protection is recommended.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' taxonomy, distribution, population status and natural history.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern, as while there are some threats operating these are having a fairly small impact on the population as a whole, and overall the species does not appear to be significantly declining.
habitat: This is a diurnal, semi-arboreal lizard. Its habitat includes clearing edges in woodlands and open forests, and it is often found along river banks of larger inland river systems (Wilson and Swan 2013, Cogger 2014). This species is oviparous, with a mean clutch size of 8.8 eggs (Greer 2006).
threats: The threats to this species include habitat loss (land clearance for agricultural land, impacts of oil and gas extraction), some predation from foxes and cats and also from pigs (digging up and eating eggs). All are localized within this lizard's range and are not considered major impacts at the species level.
population: This species is regularly encountered, and the population is considered to be generally stable.
range: This Australian species is found in northern interior New South Wales and Queensland, west of the Great Dividing Range (Cogger 2014).
useTrade: The occasional animal may be traded as a pet, but overall this will have little to no impact on the population of this species.
conservationActions: It has been recorded from many protected areas. No direct conservation measures are currently needed for this species.

rationale: This species has been assessed as Data Deficient. It is widespread throughout the central cordillera in New Guinea and the has been recorded in the Huon Peninsula mountain range and possibly on Goodenough island in Milne Bay Province. Despite its wide range it is a rare species and very little is known about its ecology, natural history or physiology. It appears only to inhabit mid-montane rainforest, and although it is not currently threatened by the international pet trade this may change in the future. It is not presently known to occur in protected areas. Further research on this species' population status, threats and harvest and trade levels is required before an accurate assessment can be made.
habitat: This species inhabits mid-montane rainforest, occurring above l,000 m, but below the treeline, and appearing to favour humid, low-light conditions. This species is oviparous with clutch sizes of at least 14 eggs. Little is known about its diet but it probably includes small mammals and ground nesting birds (O’Shea 1996).
threats: This species is subject to a number of likely threats, including hunting for the pet trade or food (Natusch and Lyon 2012), mining for gold, copper, oil or gas, infrastructure development, and deforestation at higher elevations. There is some evidence that the species does not persist in habitats degraded for oil and gas drilling (M. O'Shea pers. comm. 2015). Given uncertainties regarding this snake's true rarity and the extent of its distribution, it is unknown whether these mostly localized pressures represent a significant threat to the species.
population: It appears to be rarely encountered throughout its range in New Guinea. It is unknown if Simalia boeleni in the central cordillera  represents one contiguous interbreeding population or a series of isolated mountain-top subpopulations with limited, reduced, or no gene flow with one another. Limited locality data suggests the latter as there appear to be two disjunct subpopulations in the central cordillera. The two known allopatricsub populations on the Huon Peninsula and possibly Goodenough Island are likely currently genetically isolated from the central cordillera subpopulation(s) because the intervening lowland forest is not suitable habitat. S. boeleni therefore appears to consist of multiple allopatrically distributed subpopulations that may be lineages of a single or multiple species.
range: This species is endemic to New Guinea. Very little precise distributional data is available for this species. It occurs throughout the central cordillera, and the Huon Peninsula of Papua New Guinea at elevations between 1,000 to 2,000 m asl. It may be present on Goodenough island in Milne Bay Province, although this needs verification. This disjunct distribution is probably more a reflection of our limited knowledge concerning the montane herpetofauna of New Guinea than any rarity on the part of the python (O’Shea 1996).
useTrade:
Yuwono (1998) reported but that it was difficult to get it in any quantity in trade from Indonesian New Guinea. Historically, live specimens of Simalia boeleni have been imported into the USA since the mid-1970s. International Species Information System (ISIS) records indicate that 127 legal specimens have entered zoological institutions and currently 44 (21 male; 23 female) of those specimens are alive. There are 102 (38 male, 64 female) specimens known to occur in private ownership, this population includes animals in USA, UK, Spain, Japan, and Germany. Most of these specimens are thought to have originated from one population found in the Western Highlands of Papua Province, Indonesian New Guinea. This species has gained the reputation of being difficult to maintain and reproduce in captivity (Spataro 2007). Throughout their short captive history, there has been a concentrated effort at breeding this species yet efforts have been successful only four times, with none of these occurring in zoological institutions (Austin et al. 2010).

This species is specifically targeted by wildlife traders as it fetches a very high price. Natusch and Lyons (2012) noted the trade of this species from Jayapura in Indonesian New Guinea and that forty individuals were recorded at wildlife traders between September 2010 - April 2011. This study also indicated that, according to eleven of fifteen traders (73%), some New Guinean species (including S. boeleni) had become particularly scarce due, in part, to over-collection as well as habitat loss at historic collection sites.

This species is listed under CITES but does not have a protected status in Indonesia. There is no export quota for this species (Austin et al. 2010). 

Indigenous people in some areas of New Guinea also hunt this species for food. It is also a totem animal in some regions revered as a spirit.
conservationActions: This species is listed under Appendix II of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES). This species has special protection status in Papua New Guinea due to its cultural significance, but not in Indonesian New Guinea (Natusch and Lyons 2012). It is not known with certainty if this species occurs in any protected areas. Further research on this species population status, threats and a program to monitor its harvest and trade levels is recommended. This species should be considered a target species in need of a well-structured wild and captive management plan (Austin et al. 2010)

rationale: Galeoides decadactylus is distributed from Morocco to Angola on the west coast of Africa, and also rarely occurs in Algeria, northern Africa and Namibia, southern Africa. It is also found in Cape Verde. It is found at depths ranging from 10 to 70 m. It is dependent on estuaries for spawning, larval and juvenile habitat, and may be also be dependent on mangrove systems. Adults are found in inshore waters adjacent to sandy beaches. Galeoides decadactylus is a commercially important species, which is taken primarily in beach seines, with gillnets, and in shallow hauls and shallow trawls. It appears to be managed as two stocks shared between nations. In the last 10-12 (three generation lengths from 2000-2011) FAO reported landings have increased by 8%. During this same time frame, scientific surveys in Mauritania show fluctuating but stable capture, and in Nigeria CPUE has remained stable. In Ghana, this species is reported as mixed-catch threadfin, but is considered to be less commonly observed than in previous years. In at least one subsection of CECAF, best models currently estimate this species to be over-exploited. Several studies prior to 2000, show a 50-75% decline in average body size, and up to 75% decline in catch (in Guinea). This species appears to have undergone severe population decline in at least some parts of its range prior to 2000, and is now present at lower levels, but is continued to be targeted with increasing effort. Throughout the region, both adults and juveniles of this species are taken in the fishery year-around. This species already been overexploited for many years, appears to have greatly declined prior to 2000, and we infer that this species is still declining over the past 10 years with increasing effort. Although better management and a reduction in effort is needed, in the absence of effective fisheries management and stock assessments, this species will likely become threatened within five years given the current rate of catch. It is listed as Near Threatened and is conservation dependent. This species should be prioritized in fisheries management.
habitat:
Galeoides decadactylus reaches a maximum size of 45 cm, though it is more commonly seen at 30 cm. It is usually found over muddy bottoms in shallow coastal waters, in estuaries and in lagoons. It is considered a marine-estuarine species (Simier et al. 2006). Mangrove wetlands are an important habitat for larval and juvenile stages of this species (Moses 2000). It does not appear to penetrate below the thermocline, and occurs in inshore waters adjacent to sandy beaches. It is a semi-diadromous fish which migrates to spawn into estuaries and the lower reaches of rivers (CECAF/ECAF Series 1986). This species generally feeds on crustaceans and small fishes. Detritus accounted for about 30% of food contained in the stomachs of estuarine specimens (versus zero percent in open sea specimens). About 25% of females developed directly from the juvenile stages, the others developing female gonads after passing through a non-functional hermaphroditic stage arising in apparently normal males. Spawning of the species occurs in all months, peaking in the dry season, but almost ceasing during the rainy season in Nigerian waters. Lengths ranged from 150 mm total length for males to 255 mm for secondary females, and this species grows rapidly during the first year. At one year, the species averages 207 mm total length, 317 mm at two years, and 390 mm at three years (Motomura in press). Galeoides decadactylus co-exists with Pentanemus quinquarius and Polydactylus quadrifilis in brackish waters of the the Warri River in Nigeria. The primary food items of this species included intertidal crabs, palaemonid shrimps and fishes (Edema and Osagiede 2011).

Length at first maturity along the coast of Nigeria 14.1 cm for males, and 13.1 for females (Williams pers. comm. 2013). In other countries, length at first maturity is estimated to be in 13.7 cm (Senegal), Congo 18.5 cm, Guinea 11-13 cm and Cameroon 13 cm (Sidibe 2003), which means that the age of first maturity is likely less than one year. At eight years, this species have been found to reach 34.55 cm in Guinea and 35 cm in Nigeria (Sidibe 2003). Generation length is conservatively estimated to be approximately four years.

Family Polynemidae
Polynemids are epibenthic fishes which occur on sandy or muddy bottoms in coastal waters and estuaries. Juveniles are found in seagrass beds or tidepools. As major predators of coastal and estuarine ecosystems, most polynemids feed on a variety of fishes and crustaceans. The pectoral fins of polynemids are divided into an upper part, with rays joined by membrane, and a lower part with four to 11 separate rays, which are thought to act as a sense organ to be used for searching for food in turbid waters. Most polynemids are protandrous. Information on  the larval development of polynemids is minimal. Eggs are spherical and pelagic. Polynemids are commercially important in the eastern central Atlantic. The annual catch of polynemids from the area averaged about 39,000 tonnes in the period from 2000 to 2006. There are 43 species in eight genera recognized worldwide (Motomura in press).
threats:
Galeoides decadactylus appears to be managed as two stocks in the eastern Atlantic Ocean (CECAF 2012). In 2011, the Demersal Species Working Group - CECAF South, considered Galeoides decadactylus stocks to be over-exploited in the region, particularly in the following West African Nations: Cote de Ivoire, Ghana, Togo, Benin and Gabon, Congo, Democratic Republic of Congo and Angola (CECAF 2012). In Togo, Ghana, Cote d'Ivoire and Benin, both adults and juveniles are taken in the fishery year-around. In Togo, it is taken at depths ranging from eight to 20 meters, in the coastal zone within three nautical miles of the coast (FIRMS 2012-2013). As of 2004, the G. decadactylus stock shared between Morocco, Mauritania, Senegal and Gambia were also were also considered to be over-exploited (FIRMS 2000-2013). 

Stocks of demersal fishes, including G. decadactylus, which are available to artisanal fisheries were seriously depleted between 1984 and 1987, underwent a slight recovery between 1988 and 1991, and are still considered to be in a depressed state in Nigeria (Moses 2000). Galeoides decadactylus is also taken as by-catch in the commercial octopus fishery operating off the coast of Guinea (FIRMS 2012-2013). The best model (Cote d'Ivoire, Ghana, Togo, Benin) was considered to be overexploited with an Bcurrent/B0.1 of 825%, and Fcurrent/F0.1 is 20%.

Mangroves are an important habitat for larval and juvenile G. decadactylus. In Nigeria, large tracts of mangrove are being lost through oil pollution, felling by local communities for fuelwood and building materials and clearing by the oil companies to make way for well location, oil pipelines and flow stations. Additionally, the exotic palm Nypa fruticans is rapidly replacing native mangroves (Moses 2000). 

Additionally, the targeting of juvenile fishes and by-catch of finfish from shrimp trawls are serious management problems in the artisanal fisheries of Sierra Leone, and this is likely the case in other parts of West Africa (Baio 2010).

This species used to be abundant, but is now considered uncommon in many parts of its range. In Ghana, it is reported in mixed-species Threadfin catch and in 2009 combined threatfin species catch in artisanal species 1,857 tonnes. It is taken in a wide variety of fisheries, with the beach seine representing the largest catch of mixed-species threadfin.
population:
This species is considered to be very common and is likely the most common species of this family.  FAO landings of G. decadactylus are reported from the following West African nations, in order of increasing reported landings in 2011: Mauritania (81 tonnes), Togo, Cameroon, Guinea, Guinea Bissau, Gambia, Gabon, Cote D'Ivoire, Liberia, the Republic of Congo, Senegal, Sierra Leone, Ghana and Nigeria (4,524 tonnes). Total landings of G. decadactylus have increased continually, with minor fluctuations, from 1950 to the present. In 2011, the total catch for this species was 18,557 tonnes. In the last 10 years, landings have increased by 8%.

The abundance of G. decadactylus varies seasonally by depth. The species is more abundant in the dry season in coastal zones at depths ranging from 5-15 meters, and at depths of 15-40 m during the wet season (Gascuel and Laurans 2001).

Model stock assessments
In Guinea, annual catches of G. decadactylus increased from 992 tonnes to 1,824 tonnes over the time span of 1995 to 1999, with the large majority of catches coming from the industrial rather than the artisanal fishery. Depending on the model used and the location, global evaluations of the stock based on catch/effort/abundance information was considered fully exploited or overexploited by the end of the time series (calculated value of mf MSY =0.9 or 1.4 in Guinea; 0.4 in Senegal, 0.6 or 1.4 in Cape Verde). Annual indices of abundance have deceased from 1985 to 1994 in Guinea. Fishing effort, which was calculated as the ratio of captures over indices of abundance, have increased from 1985 (0.35) to 1999 (7.04). A rapid depletion (70% decline) of biomass of five indicator species (including G. decadactylus, Pseudotolithus elongatus, Pseudotolighus typus, Pseudotolightus senegalensis and Arius spp.) was seen corresponding to increasing effort (doubling every three years in Guinea; Gascuel and Laurans 2001).

Galeoides decadactylus was found to be low in relative abundance in beach seine landings taken in various coastal locations off central Ghana (Aggrey-Fynn and Sackey-Mensah 2012). Artisanal fishery production of G. decadactylus has increased from 2002-2006, with a 2,500.2% increase in production from 39.5 tonnes to 425.4 tonnes from 2002-2004, and a 87.8% increase in production from 1,025.8-1,926.0 from 2004-2006 (Baio 2010).

Trends in demersal fisheries off the continental shelf of Mauritania
The fisheries of the northwestern African continental shelf have developed over the past several decades from low levels of fishing to intense exploitation, leading to severe decreases in biomass and serious signs of over-exploitation. In general, the abundance of demersal resources of northwest Africa has declined by a factor of four over the past 20 to 30 years. Although this species is not a component of fisheries in Mauritania, many trends in Mauritania are reflective of those in Senegal and Guinea. Over the Mauritanian continental shelf, reductions in biomass of up to 75% have been recorded. Using data from scientific surveys conducted in Mauritanian waters, trends in species biomass were modelled for 24 taxa, 15 of which showed significant decreasing trends, and only one of which showed increases in abundance. In Senegal and Guinea, abundance indices for this species have remained low, with shallow declines from 1985-1999 (Gascuel et al. 2007).

In Nigeria, CPUE for this species from 1990 to 2010 is fluctuating but relatively stable (Williams pers. comm. 2013). Length at age one is 18 cm, age two is 23 cm, age three is 27, and length infinity is 54 cm in Nigeria (Abohweyere 1989).
In the ISTAM database from 1965 to 1998, mean sizes have decreased from 0.4 kg to around 0.1-0.2 kg in 1998.

From 1985-1995, based on indices of abundance, this species declined and then started to increase until 2002 (Sidibe pers comm. 2013).

In Mauritania, from 2000 -2001, landings from scientific surveys are fluctuating from 29 metric tonnes in 2000 to a high of 93 metric tonnes in 2008, and a decline to 10 metric tonnes in 2011 (Camara pers. comm. 2013).

In Senegal, there has been no observed decrease in juveniles in studies since 2003 (Morais pers. comm. 2013).

In Ghana, this species is very scarce in markets, and it used to be more abundant.  However, it is still considered common in Senegal and Nigeria.  It is not that abundant in markets in Mauritania.
range: Galeoides decadactylus is distributed from Morocco to Angola on the west coast of Africa, and also rarely occurs in Algeria, northern Africa and Namibia, southern Africa. It is found at depths ranging from 10-70 m  (Motomura in press). It is also found in Cape Verde (Silva 2009). It generally only occurs between the Canary Islands and Angola.
useTrade: Galeoides decadactylus is an important component of the commercial trawl fishery in eastern Atlantic, constituting between 10 and 20% of the total landings by weight. The annual catch from the area averaged 15,600 tonnes from 2000-2006, mainly caught by Nigeria, Ghana, and Gabon (Motomura in press). It is a major coastal resource in Senegal. This species is taken in beach seines, with gillnets and in shallow hauls. It is marketed fresh, dried salted or smoked, and is highly regarded (FAO 2015).
conservationActions: Galeoides decadactylus appears to be managed as two stocks within Fishery Committee for the Eastern Central Atlantic CECAF waters.

rationale: Trichechus inunguis is here listed as Vulnerable based on a suspected population decline of at least 30% within the next three generations (assuming a generation length of 25 years) due primarily to ongoing levels of hunting throughout most of the region, coupled with increasing incidental calf mortality in the recent years, global warming trends and increased climate variability, along with increased economic and population growth, and habitat loss and degradation associated with fisheries and river traffic.
habitat:
Amazonian Manatees inhabit environments in lowland tropical areas below 300 m asl, where there is a large production of aquatic and semi-aquatic plants; they also favour calm, shallow waters, away from human settlements. They are the only sirenians restricted to freshwater systems. T. inunguis occurs in waters with temperatures above 23oC (Gallivan et al. 1983), living in the three types of water in Amazonian rivers (white, black and clear), being more abundant in white waters, where there is greater primary production (Best 1984, Rosas 1994).

Individuals engage in long seasonal movements, moving from flooded areas during the wet season to deep water bodies during the dry season (Arraut et al. 2010, Kendall et al. 2014). While the whitewater rivers (murky water) provide them with plentiful food, deep lakes function as refuges during the low-water season, where animals are less vulnerable to hunting.

Only one calf is produced at a time. Although no specific studies are available for the species in the wild, it is believed that the reproductive cycle is similar to the West Indian Manatee’s, with a long gestation and lactation period (up to 24 months), and a birthing interval of 2 to 3 years (Best 1983); age at sexual maturity is suggested to be between 6 and 10 years (Rodrigues et al. 2002).

Generation length is 25 years, based on what is known for T. manatus.
threats:
The commercial large scale capture of Amazonian Manatee was the main reason for the reduction of the populations of the species. The main current threats for Manatees are hunting for meat consumption (Denkinger 2010, Brice et al. 2011, Utreras et al. 2013, Sandoval 2015), entanglement in fishing nets and habitat alterations.

Illegal hunting, for both subsistence and local use, is considered the main threat to Manatees in the Amazon. Manatee populations have supported a tremendous take in past centuries and, although not at commercial levels, hunting still takes place throughout the region (Barbosa et al. 2010a, b; Franzini et al. 2013; Silva et al. 2014; M. Marmontel pers. obs). Most hunting is practiced with the use of traditional harpoons, but in Ecuador Manatees may be caught in traps set for Arapaima (Hidalgo 2010).

Hunters usually sell products to neighbors and nearby communities, but the meat is sometimes sold in local produce fairs or markets in the interior, or by order directly with the hunter. Public markets in Brazil (Manaus, Manacapuru, Beruri, Novo Airão, Tefé, Silves, Itapiranga, Itacoatiara, Santarém, Belém, Monte Alegre and Almeirim, Benjamin Constant, Atalaia do Norte) and Ecuador also illegally offer the meat for sale. Meat is sold in natura, or as "mixira" or subproducts such as sausage. The mixira, which is the meat preserved in its own fat, is one of the products that prolongs the pressure on the species, since it commands a high price.

Take estimates are available only for a few sites where conservation and research projects are taking place. Between 2002 and 2004, 64 Manatees were estimated to have been killed in the Amanã-Castanho area (3,000 km2) of Amanã SDR (Calvimontes 2009), most of them adult males. Between 2011 and 2015, the hunt count for the same area was 42 Manatees. Some 195 Manatees were estimated to have been killed between 2011 and 2015 in the Uatumã River valley (Brazil) through the expeditions of Project Protecting Life in Uatumã (S.M. Lazzarini pers. comm. 2016). In the Urucu region of Brazil 20 Manatees were captured between 2004 and 2007, 14 harpooned and 6 entangled (Franzini et al. 2013). Pantoja (2015) estimated 92 Manatees hunted in the area of the lower Javari river, Brazil, between 1980 and 2014. Based on interviews conducted in the Piagaçu Purus SDR (Purus river, Brazil), approximately 460 Manatees were killed in the protected area between 2004 and 2014 (Souza et al. 2014). Based on 48 interviews, 36 manatees were captured in the Region of the Middle Madeira and Aripuanã Rivers (Amazon, Brazil) between 1986-2004: 89% poached and 11% entangled (Castelblanco-Martínez et al. 2007).

The Natütama Foundation, which has a year-round Manatee monitoring program in place since 2002, registered three Manatees hunted in Colombia from 2003 to 2013 (Kendall 2013) and more than six in Peru from 2010-2015. Manatees are still being hunted in the river Putumayo upstream from Tarapaca and above the mouth of the Igaraparana, according to interviews with local Colombian fishermen, who say most of the hunters are Peruvian (S. Kendall pers. obs.).

In the Pacaya Samiria Reserve (Peru), Soto (2007) estimated an average of 35 Manatees killed in the basins of the Punahua, Ucayali and Marañon rivers.

Incidental mortality, orphaned calves, and illegal captivity

In addition to specific gillnets to hunt Manatees, the high use of fishing nets in the Amazon has increased incidental calf mortality in the past few years. These events have been documented in all Amazonian Manatee range countries (Reeves et al. 1996, Orozco 2001, Franzini 2008, Souza 2015), and this is now a major threat for the species (Marmontel et al. 2012).

When calves survive drowning in nets, they may be kept alive for later sale as pets, kept in pools or areas close to water bodies, and sold or given to influential persons. The number of rescued calves every year has been increasing, but the number recorded represents a small sample of occurrences in the Amazon.

Between 2008 and 2010, in the Brazilian state of Pará, 28 stranded Manatees were rescued, of which only one was an adult (Sousa et al. 2010). An important threat in Pará is the use of fishing corrals, as they are usually built over submerged aquatic vegetation beds, where Manatees feed, and have already trapped a Manatee (M. Sousa, pers. com. 2016).

Presently, several institutions in Brazil (Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas da Amazônia, Centro de Pesquisa e Preservação de Mamíferos Aquáticos, Mamirauá Institute and Zoofit) care for over 150 Manatees in captivity, mostly orphans. Between 2005 and 2015, INPA received an average of 10 calves per year. Of the 98 animals rescued during this period, 30% were accidentally caught in fishing nets (D. Souza pers. obs). In the past 10 years CPPMA received 39 calves for rehabilitation (S.M. Lazzarini pers. comm. 2016).

From 2010-2015, 3 calves died in nets or captivity in Peru (S. Kendall pers obs). It is estimated that two Amazonian Manatees are presently in captivity in Colombia (Castelblanco-Martínez et al. 2015).

Between 2007 and 2010, Centro de Rescate Amazónico (Iquitos, Peru) rescued 28 Manatees (Perea et al. 2011), and until 2013 successfully rehabilitated 25 individuals (Landeo-Yauri et al. 2013). Since 2011  the Centro released and monitored 11 of those rehabilitated animals (Landeo and Castelblanco-Martínez 2015, Velásquez Varela et al. 2015).

Habitat alteration and disturbance

Other anthropogenic actions have resulted in pollution, loss, alteration, degradation and fragmentation of habitats used by the Amazonian Manatee (Rosas and da Silva pers. comm. 2005, Kendall et al. 2014).

Changes in the aquatic environment as habitat degradation due to deforestation, pollution, contamination of the rivers by mercury for the gold exploration (Amorim et al. 2000), pesticides and heavy metals from agricultural waste and oil spills are potential hazards to the Manatee´s food supply (Rosas et al. 1991). These elements are absorbed by aquatic weeds and may directly affect the staple diet of the species (Rosas 1994). Roots of floating and rooted aquatic plants (Paspalum, Eicchornia, Salvinia) have been shown to be important methylation sites (Guimarães et al. 2000). Over 300 dams are planned for the Amazon (Winemiller et al. 2016), two of which are mega-enterprises in Brazil (Madeira and Xingu rivers). The building of dams can interfere with habitat quality, altering water speed, nutrient load and dynamics of macrophyte production (Junk and Nunes de Mello 1987). Brazil has extensive plans for navigation (Fearnside 2001, Brazil, PR, 2011) with dams allowing the opening of the waterway in the Tapajos river (Fearnside 2015) planned for soy transport, giving access to the Amazon river and the Atlantic ocean (Brazil, PR 2011, Millikan 2011). Amazonian Manatees are very sensitive to noise, and intense boat traffic on the Amazonian rivers can affect their behaviour and habitat use.

Oil spills may be a particular problem in Ecuador (Brice et al. 2011, Utreras et al. 2013, Brice 2014), where oil exploitation has been permitted in important refuges for the species (Utreras et al. 2013). The use of fertilizers and weed control products in extensive monocultures (Utreras et al. 2013), incidental captures in fishing nets, the use of dynamite, the increasing use of motorized boats including in the Cuyabeno and Jatuncocha systems where there are nature tourism activities (Utreras et al. 2011a, b) are additional threats in Ecuador.

On the Peru-Colombia border, wood extraction activities are clogging lakes and stopping normal migrations of Manatees in the Atacuari area (S. Kendall pers obs).

Amazonian human populations are generally at low densities except in the large capital cities, but all of the issues above could be magnified by the increase in human population.

Tourism and transport are interfering more and more with low water resting places in the area around Puerto Nariño (Kendall et al. 2014).

Around the city of Belém and estuary of the Amazon River, boat traffic is intense and even ferries and cargo ships may interfere with Manatee movement (Miranda Leão et al. 2014).

Natural disasters, drought, climate change

Extreme droughts may help make the Manatee an easier prey item for hunters, by causing isolation and entrapment. During the 2010 drought in the Piagaçu-Purus SDR (Purus River, Brazil), 180 Manatees were estimated killed (Souza et al. 2014), but only a few cases of Manatees trapped by drought in the eastern Peruvian frontier area were recorded, and none in Colombia (S. Kendall pers obs).
population:
Most of the waters inhabited by Amazonian Manatees are very murky and, probably as an adaptation to the past and ongoing hunting pressure, Amazonian Manatees are extremely secretive. Tremendous research efforts have been made, but there are no reliable population estimates available, although numbers are almost certainly lower than historical figures due to centuries of hunting. Analysis of feeding patches, direct sightings of T. inunguis and interview surveys have been used to try to estimate population numbers with limited results, due to opportunistic sightings and small samples without standardized effort. Traditional mark-recapture studies are not appropriate due to the species’ secretive nature. More recently there have been efforts to estimate populations with the use of rotary or side-scan sonars, but still with inconclusive results (Brice 2014, Francisco et al. 2015), which hinders the development of conservation strategies for the species. Magor empirically estimated a minimum population of 10,000 Amazonian Manatees for the Amazon basin (Husar 1977). Based on the analysis of mtDNA control region, Cantanhede et al. (2005) suggested a genetic estimate of the effective female population size of T. inunguis of approximately 455,000 individuals, indicative of a recent large population size. Genetic studies do not show a population structure throughout the region (Cantanhede et al. 2005).

In Colombia, due to conservation efforts with local communities, a reduction in hunting levels and an apparent increase in Amazonian Manatee population in specific sites has been noted in the last few years. In the Colombian Amazon, the population may have stabilized, but hunting continues on the Peruvian side of the river and this affects the Colombian population. During 2010-2015, Natütama registered 3 to 4 new calves every year in Colombia. Fishermen insist that there are more Manatees now, mainly because they see groups of 7 to 10 Manatees more often (Kendall et al. 2014). Systematic monitoring with former Manatee hunters recorded 364 sightings around Puerto Nariño in 2014, including five different calves (Castelblanco-Martínez et al. 2015).

A study conducted 1996-1999 in Cuyabeno Reserve (Ecuador) contradicted Timm et al.'s (1986) prediction of extinction in 10 years. However, relative abundance in Cuyabeno River was 0.01 animal / h effort and 0.007 animal / h effort in Lagartococha River. A total 40-49 animals were sighted in the Cuyabeno Reserve between 1996 and 1998, where they are considered rare (Denkinger 2010). The use of sonar produced estimates ranging from 0.8 to 3.0 individuals / 10 km in three sites (Parque Nacional Yasuni, Lagartococha and Cocaya lake systems); no animals were detected in 58 km of the Cuyabeno lagoon system (Utreras et al. 2013). Brice (2014), using side-scan sonar observed 24 individuals in 70 hours of sampling in the same region. In Ecuador the species is considered Critically Endangered (CR) according to IUCN criteria C2a(i), which indicates an estimated population of less than 250 mature individuals, and no subpopulation with 50 mature individuals (IUCN 2001).

Guzmán (2014), also using a side scan sonar, recorded 14 Manatees in 65 km of rivers and lagoons, or 2.15 ind / 10 km in the Lagartococha river, on border Peru-Ecuador, an area partially surveyed by Utreras et al. (2013). Bodmer et al. (2006) believed the population in the Pacaya Samiria Reserve was stable due to a slight increase in counts between 2003 and 2006. However, Soto (2007) points out that the estimation method has not yet been proven.

In some sustainable development reserves (SDR) in Brazilian Amazon, hunting has been decreasing over the recent years. This is probably a reflection of the conservation actions that have occurred in the region, and the lack of interest among young fishermen for hunting the Manatee. The frequent records of sightings of adults and females with calves during the rainy and dry seasons in the Piagaçu-Purus SDR (Souza 2015) suggest that populations of T. inunguis may be stable or increasing in these regions.

Sixty two per cent of hunters interviewed by Calvimontes (2009) in Amanã SDR (Brazil) believed the population is decreasing, although they attribute this to Manatees having moved away (due to habitat alterations and increasing levels of noise) rather than hunting. Calvimontes also reported that most hunters are turning into farmers, which should decrease the pressure on the species. Seventy three per cent of interviewees in the Belém region (mouth of the Amazon) considered the Manatee population is decreasing, due to hunting, pollution, boat traffic and noise (Miranda 2014). Half of the respondents in Franzini et al.'s (2013) study believed Manatee numbers are declining.

Seventy per cent of interviewees in the Ucayali region of Peru believed the population is decreasing (Silva et al. 2014). In a preliminary survey of Manatees in the Lagartococha region, in 6.9 km of canoe transects Hidalgo (2010) observed 16 Manatees and 25 feeding patches, which lead him to evaluate that Manatees in the Lagartococha river basin may be stable due to the almost null human presence.

The progressive increase in the number of young calves arriving at rehabilitation centres in Brazil in the past five years has also led several researchers to suspect that the species may be undergoing some recovery, or that the increase is simply a reflection of the awareness campaigns implemented, with a concomitant increase in the number of rescued calves (Rosas and da Silva pers. comm. 2005). Alternatively, it may also suggest that calf takes are on the rise.

Although Manatees are widespread through a large area, there is a high level of uncertainty about population size, as no reliable method for determining abundance has been defined so far. Whatever the current population size, the overall population trend is most likely to be decreasing, given the species’ slow reproduction (sirenian populations grow at an annual rate of approximately 5-6%; Marsh et al. 2004, 2011) and levels of exploitation (Marmontel et al. 1992). In summary, although the population may be stabilizing in some parts of the Amazon region due to local awareness building and other conservation efforts, the overall trend is of a decreasing population.
range:
Amazonian Manatees occur in northern South America, and are endemic to the Amazon Basin.
