Other studies based mainly on faecal sample collection have found records of the Pampas Cat much more frequently than the Andean Cat (Lucherini and Vidal 2003, Perovic et al. 2003, Cossios et al. 2007, Viscarra 2008, Torrico 2009, Novaro et al. 2010, Villalba et al. 2012). All this information confirms that the Andean Cat is much rarer than the Pampas Cat.

The three surveyed areas outlined above are located within the two regions that are considered to have the most favourable climatic conditions for Andean Cat, and that coincide with those places where a larger number of Andean Cat records have been obtained (Marino et al. 2011). In this context, it is expected that Andean Cat density in those areas with less favourable conditions will be much lower.

A study of the population genetics of the Andean cat throughout most of its range (Cossios et al. 2012) indicated that the species has a very low mitochondrial and nuclear genetic diversity and two distinct Andean Cat subpopulations,which are latitudinally separated between 26 and 35° S, were identified that should be considered as two "Evolutionary Significant Units” (ESUs). Moreover, the northern ESU contains two genetically different groups, showing limited or no exchange of individuals between them, which should be considered as two "Management Units” (MUs).

The geographical separation between the northern and southern ESU concurs with the third biogeographic barrier, the South American Arid Diagonal and the separation between the two northern management units coincides with the transition zone between the wet and dry Puna (Cossíos et al. 2012); thus, the authors remark that these three groups of Andean Cat populations could have developed special adaptations because significant differences exist in rainfall patterns over this range.
range:
The Andean Cat has a patchy distribution due to a specialization for naturally fragmented rocky habitats and most presence records are from the central Andes above 3,600 meters in Argentina, Bolivia, Chile and Peru. However it has also been found at lower elevations in the southern Andes of Argentina at 1,800 m (Sorli et al. 2006) and more recent records of the Andean Cat in Argentina and Chile extend its distribution range to the south and outside the Andes, into Patagonian steppe and scrub habitats in Argentina, at elevations as low as 650 m (Novaro et al. 2010, Martinez et al. 2008), and at 2,200 m in Chile in the Atacama Region (Villalobos et al. in prep.).

Within the high Andes the Andean Cat was recorded at an average elevation of 4,236 m in Argentina (Perovic et al. 2003), above 3,800 m in Bolivia (Villalba et al. 2012), between 3,714 and 4,414 m in Chile (Napolitano et al. 2008), and at 4,000 m or higher in Peru (Cossios et al. 2007).

Until the end of the nineties, Andean Cat records were scarce and restricted to southern Peru, southwest Bolivia, northwest Argentina and northern Chile (Yensen and Seymour 2000). Similarly, sightings of this species were very few (Scrocchi and Halloy 1986, Sanderson 1999), and museum specimens were equally few (Garcia-Perea 2002). However in the last two decades the number of distribution records has greatly increased due to the efforts of the Andean Cat Alliance (www.gatoandino.org), a network of specialist researchers.

Currently the known northern and southern limit for the Andean cat respectively is central Peru (10°13'S), and central Argentina (38°23'S) (Cossios et al. 2007, Novaro et al. 2010), but throughout this range the Andean Cat populations are patchily distributed. The results of modelling the Andean Cat distribution considering four bioclimatic variables (annual mean and mean diurnal range temperature, annual precipitation, and coldest season winter), shows the presence of three biogeographic barriers that affect the species’ distribution: i) at the north in Peru that coincides with the Huancabamba depression, known as “Peruvian low” and defines the northern boundary of its distribution range, ii) at the centre in Bolivia, with the “Andean knee”, an extremely arid transition zone between the wet and dry Puna and where there are no records of Andean cats, and iii) at the south with the “Arid Diagonal” in Chile and Argentina, that is also an hyper-arid zone and with very few records of Andean Cats (Marino et al. 2011).

According to this model and despite the differences in elevation over the current geographic range of the Andean Cat, there are common climatic conditions that favour for their presence, which are cold, dry and extreme diurnal variations in temperature (Marino et al. 2011).
useTrade:
In Argentina, Bolivia, Chile and Perú people of Aymara origin, and in some cases Quechua, have similar beliefs regarding the Andean Cat and Pampas Cat (both known as titi or osqollo). A common tradition is the use of a skin or a stuffed cat during ceremonies that people perform for marking their domestic livestock, mainly llamas or alpacas; the titi is considered a sacred animal related with abundance and fertility of the livestock or quality of crops. It is important to note that both the Andean Cat and Pampas Cat are part of these traditions and beliefs, and in general, are used indiscriminately. There are some local variations within and between countries and in some cases the influence of western culture has resulted in a total or partial loss of the values of Andean cultures and the distortion of ancestral customs regarding the titi (Villalba et al. 2004).
Cossios et al. (2007) also reported the hunting of Andean and Pampas Cats for food and for traditional medicine in central Peru.
conservationActions:
Included on CITES Appendix I (as Leopardus jacobitus). The Andean Cat’s conservation status in the range countries was also re-assessed. The species is listed as Critically Endangered in Bolivia, Endangered and Rare in Chile, Endangered in Peru and Vulnerable in Argentina; it also has full protection at the national level across its entire range, as described below. However, law enforcement is problematic, and hunted specimens are regularly observed in the field and for sale, although with less frequency than before, in special markets to be used in religious ceremonies.

After developing the actions outlined in the Andean Cat Conservation Action Plan (Villalba et al. 2004) and the information generated in the last 10 years, the Andean Cat Alliance elaborated the Strategic Plan for Andean Cat Conservation (AGA 2011) with the following objectives and maintaining the three main lines of action: Research, Education and Conservation:

a.         To ensure long-term conservation of the Andean Cat and its natural environment, including the restoration or rehabilitation of the environments that have suffered degradation.

b.         To integrate the conservation of the Andean Cat and its natural environment within local policies in the four countries where the species is present, working locally but with a global approach.

c.         To strengthen activities of conservation and research in protected areas with Andean Cat populations, and to promote the creation or extension of existing protected areas to provide connectivity and/or protection of habitats and Andean cat populations.

d.         To promote research on the conservation threats, ecological requirements of the species, its principal prey, and other sympatric carnivores.

e.         To standardize the activities of working groups under common and more effective goals.

f.         To train protected areas staff and local communities in activities in research, education and conservation, within and outside protected areas.

The Andean Cat is found in several protected areas across its range and some were prioritized for promoting effective conservation of the species as well as their habitats and others for the need to carry out surveys and promote effective conservation actions.

Mining and oil/gas extraction are a priority economic activity in South American countries, even in protected areas, therefore lobbying with authorities and the industry sector, as well as promoting and/or supporting the implementation of mitigation plans to minimize impacts are fundamental actions to be addressed (Walker et al. 2013).

Similarly, community-based conservation is an essential approach that is being implemented by promoting or supporting sustainable economic initiatives, favouring better practices in livestock management or other activities oriented to mitigate human-wildlife conflict. Community education and support for law enforcement are also important activities to minimize or stop Andean Cat hunting and encourage positive attitudes towards Andean cats and high Andean biodiversity.

National legislation

Argentina
The Andean Cat is protected by National Law 22421 of wildlife conservation and its Statutory
Decree 666/97. Also, Resolution N°63/86 of the Secretary of Agriculture.

Bolivia
Along with other wild species of fauna and flora, the Andean cat is protected by the Supreme Decree N° 22641, promulgated in 1990, which establishes a general and undefined ban for the pursuit, capture, storing and conditioning of wild animals and its derivative products.

Chile
All felid species are fully protected since 1972 by Law N° 19473. The illegal hunting of felines in Chile is penalized with fines up to US$ 6.000 and imprisonment up to 3 years.

Peru
In 2014 a new regulation listed the Andean cat as Endangered and along with other wild species of fauna its hunting, commerce and hunting, capture, possession, trade, transport or export for commercial purposes is prohibited (Supreme Decree N°004-2014-MINAGRI).

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient because its distribution is not completely known, nor are there any quantitative population data available. The species is known from two widely separated localities, one of which is relatively well preserved and the other has experienced substantial habitat destruction. Also, the tolerance of this species to habitat degradation is not known so threat status is uncertain. This species is likely to be more widely distributed than currently understood. More research is needed to understand the range, population size and trend.
habitat: This species occurs in upper montane cloud forest. Neither of the reports for this species provide any more information about the natural history of this species. The extent to which the species occurs in disturbed habitats is unknown.
threats: This species is threatened by deforestation by small scale agriculture and the establishment of pine plantations in Bolivia. In Peru, the species is threatened by selective logging and small scale agriculture, and possibly by hydrocarbon exploration.
population: The population status of the species is unknown, as it is only known from two specimens. The locality in Peru is in a national park where there is little habitat disturbance. The Bolivian locality has suffered extensive habitat destruction since the species was found there. Although there has been some herpetological investigation near the Bolivian locality, apparently as of 2013 no one has searched extensively for this species (R. Aguayo pers. comm. 2014).
range: This species is known from two localities, one in Cochabamba, Bolivia, and one in Cusco, Peru. The species has been recorded from elevations between 2,445 and 2,500 m asl (Dixon 1989, Alonso et al. 2001).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. The species occurs in Otishi National Park, Peru, and near Carrasco National Park in Bolivia. More surveys are needed to better understand the distribution of this species.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of the large extent of occurrence (>300,000 km<sup>2</sup>), occurrence in protected areas, persistence in disturbed areas, and lack of major threats.
habitat: This fossorial species is found in lowland wet and dry forests. It can also be found in disturbed habitats such as farms and large gardens (L. Gonzales pers. comm. 2014).
threats: This species would be threatened by oil and gas drilling in Peru, and intensive agriculture across the range, but these threats are aaffecting only small portions of the overall range.
population: This fossorial species is rarely encountered. There are only a handful of specimens in Bolivian museums. Judging by its broad distribution and occurrence in disturbed habitats, the species probably is not declining very rapidly.
range: Atractus emmeli occurs east of the Cordillera of the Andes in the Departments of  Beni, La Paz and Santa Cruz, Bolivia and the Departments of Cuzco, Junin, Loreto and Ucayali, Peru (Passos and Fernandes 2008). The elevational range is from approximately 134-360 m asl.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. The species is known from Madidi National Park and Beni Biological Station in Bolivia. The species likely occurs in Peruvian national parks. No additional conservation measures are needed.

rationale: Okapi have been undergoing a decline since at least 1995 that is ongoing and projected to continue, in the face of severe, intensifying threats and lack of effective conservation action which is hindered by the lack of security. The rate of decline is estimated to have exceeded 50% over three generations (24 years), based on figures from surveys in the Okapi Wildlife Reserve (Réserve de Faune à Okapis; RFO) suggesting a 43% decline over the period 1995-2007, which some reports suggest continued in the period thereafter. The RFO remains the best protected site and it is inferred that the rate of decline here is at least equalled in other parts of the Okapi range. Although monitoring is only available to support estimates of declines in RFO since 1995, reports of declines or extirpations in other parts of the range and loss and degradation of habitat have been ongoing since 1980. The species is confirmed to be Endangered under criterion A2abcd+4abcd.
habitat: Okapi are limited to closed, high canopy forests between about 450 m asl and 1,500 m asl and they occur in a wide range of primary and older secondary forest types. They do not extend into gallery forests or the forest-savannah ecotone and do not persist in disturbed habitats surrounding larger settlements. Okapi will use seasonally inundated areas when the substrate is still wet, but they do not occur in truly inundated sites or extensive swamp forest. Tree fall gaps are selected as foraging sites for Okapi during the early stages of regeneration (Hart 2013). Okapi are unique in being the only species of forest ungulate to depend on understorey foliage and they are known to feed on over 100 species. They are mainly diurnal but have also been recorded feeding at night (Nixon and Lusenge 2008). Okapi have defined but non-exclusive home ranges, averaging 3-5 km<sup>2</sup> for adult females and up to 13 km<sup>2</sup> for adult males. Okapi are mainly solitary (Hart 2013). Generation length is broadly estimated at around eight years, based on calculations made for the global captive population (S. Hofman and K. Leus pers. comm. 2013).
threats:
Okapi can coexist with small-scale, low-level human occupation of the forest, but disappear in areas of active settlement or disturbance, and the major threat to this species is habitat loss due to logging and human settlement including illegal occupation of protected areas (Hart 2013, Kümpel et al. 2015). According to Hart (2013) approximately one-third of the Okapi’s known distribution is likely to be at risk by major incursions during the first quarter of this century. Areas at high risk include the southeastern Ituri Forest, the Kisangani area, Rubi-Tele, and the western and eastern limits of the species' range in the Ebola River basin and Virunga-Hoyo region respectively.

Hunting for meat and skins is also a threat and Okapi decline rapidly in areas where there is persistent use of snares. In some areas, Okapi are targeted for bushmeat whereas in others they are taken only incidentally (Hart 2013, Kümpel et al. 2015).

The most prominent current threat to Okapi is the presence of illegal armed groups in and around key protected areas. These groups prevent effective conservation action, even surveys and monitoring in most sites, and engage in and facilitate elephant poaching, bushmeat hunting, illegal mining (gold, coltan and diamonds), illegal logging, charcoal production and agricultural encroachment. In a notorious incident in June 2012, armed rebels attacked the RFO HQ and killed seven people and all 14 captive Okapi.
population:
East (1999) estimated that the total population may be over 10,000 and Hart (2013) estimated 35,000-50,000, though both sets of figures are perhaps better regarded as ‘guesstimates’ as they rely on extrapolation of a limited number of patchily distributed, dung-based surveys. Individual Okapi are rarely encountered and in much of their range they are uncommon or dispersed in localized areas, with dung found at low densities, commonly resulting in inadequate sample sizes for statistical analysis. Current numbers are believed to be lower and declining, but there is no reliable estimate of current population size.

It is widely considered that there was a decline in the Okapi population, along with other species, following the decade-long civil war which ended in the early 2000s. Population estimates were made in the Okapi Wildlife Reserve (Réserve de Faune à Okapis; RFO) in 1993-1995 and repeated in 2005-2007 using the same ‘monitoring’ transects and distance sampling methodology, though individual transects were not necessarily carried out at the same time of year due to insecurity limiting access to parts of the Reserve (Hart et al. 2008). These surveys showed a decline in dung density of 43% between the two survey periods. A second set of transects in 2005-2007 used an improved spatial design (systematic placement of transects covering the entire reserve), but were also conducted across seasons for the reasons above. Further analysis is required to determine whether comparison of these ‘systematic’ transects with the 1995-1997 and 2005-2007 monitoring transects, and a further set of transects conducted in 2000-2002 over part of the reserve under the MIKE (Monitoring the Illegal Killing of Elephants) program, supports the observed decline in dung density, and to specifically investigate seasonality as a variable. The same type of systematic design was used again in 2010-2011, but implemented over the three month dry season to reduce the effects of seasonality. While an overall comparison between the two systematic surveys (2005-2007 and 2010-2011) appeared to show an increase in Okapi dung density (Vosper et al. 2012), a comparison between transects undertaken at the same time of year (the dry season only), in the same area of the reserve, showed no significant difference in Okapi dung density (F. Maisels pers. comm. 2014). Seasonal differences in dung decay rates therefore complicate comparisons between these various sets of surveys.

Supporting evidence for RFO is available from Law Enforcement Monitoring (LEM) patrols from 2008 to 2013. These patrols covered distances of 10,125–25,467 km annually and showed an apparent decline in Okapi dung encounter rates between 2008 and 2013 (ICCN RFO unpubl. data). However, because the patrols were focused on anti-poaching and wildlife recording was secondary, patrol routes were not randomly located, and patrol timings and locations varied among years because of security and logistical issues, the data must be interpreted with caution.

Since the rebel attack on the RFO headquarters in June 2012 (see ‘Threats’ below), the presence of armed groups and an influx of illegal miners and poachers has reduced the ability of the reserve authorities to protect the reserve and this is likely to have ongoing implications for resident wildlife populations. RFO is still the most effectively protected Okapi site with resident rangers and an active conservation programme and the overall rate of decline here is inferred to have been equalled or exceeded elsewhere.

In the Twabinga-Mundo region, anecdotal evidence suggests that Okapi are targeted for their skins and meat, and have undergone a drastic decline in numbers over the past two decades with local people reporting that Okapi is the most prized bushmeat available (Nixon 2010). Okapi had been present south of the town of Aketi and near the town of Buta but no signs were found on recent field surveys and locals said they had recently been hunted out by Bangalema nomadic hunters (Hicks 2010).
range:
Okapi distribution extends across parts of central, northern and eastern DR Congo. North and east of the Congo River, Okapi range from Maiko Forest north to the Ituri Forest, then west through the Rubi, Tele and Ebola river basins, extending north towards the Ubangi River. Okapi have a much smaller range to the west and south of the Congo River, extending from the west bank of the Lomami River west to the upper Lomela and Tshuapa basins (Hart 2013). In the fairly recent past, Okapi occurred occasionally in the adjoining Semliki forest of western Uganda (Kingdon 1979).

Recorded presence is concentrated in and around protected areas, mainly reflecting survey effort. The remoteness and inaccessibility of much Okapi habitat make field work logistically difficult, and insecurity in DRC over the past two decades has further restricted survey activity. As a consequence, extensive parts of potential Okapi range are poorly studied. Furthermore, Okapi are secretive and their occurrence can easily go undetected, especially at low densities.

The known strongholds of the Okapi are the Ituri and Maiko landscapes, the forests of the upper Lindi, Maiko and Tshopo basins and the Rubi-Tele region in Bas Uele (Hart 2013). There are confirmed recent (2013) records of Okapi in the Abumonbanzi Reserve in Gbadolite district of North Ubangi at the northwest end of the distribution (Ngbolua et al. 2014).

Since 1980, expansion of human settlement, deforestation and forest degradation have eliminated important portions of the Okapi range, in particular in the southern and eastern Ituri Forest where the species was at one time abundant (Hart 2013).

The extent of occurrence (EOO) is 383,190 km2, but this includes unsuitable habitat such as degraded forest, swamp forest and urban areas. Excluding all these gives in an area of 244,405 km2 for the suitable or hypothesised range (Kümpel et al. 2015). The area of occupancy (AOO) is 14,112 km2, based on a grid of 5.6 x 5.6 km, the size used by most reported surveys and 450 (3.5%) of 12,764 grid squares with confirmed presence Kümpel et al. (2015). The AOO figure is however considered likely to be a substantial underestimate, surveys have been conducted in only 1,994 (15.6%) out of 12,764 grid squares so far.
useTrade: Okapi are hunted for meat and skins.
conservationActions:
This species is not included in the CITES Appendices. The Okapi is a fully protected species under Congolese law and the species is a national symbol, appearing on the insignia of the Institut Congolais pour la Conservation de la Nature (ICCN) and on Congolese banknotes.

The RFO (14,000 km2) and Maiko National Park (10,800 km2) support significant populations, but numbers in both sites have declined owing to the threats listed above. Strengthening protection of these two protected areas is the single most important means to ensure long-term survival of Okapi (East 1999, Hart 2013). A small population of Okapi still occurs in the Watalinga Forest (1,100 km2) in the northern sector of Virunga National Park, but currently receives no protection due to the presence of armed groups, though a new forest corridor project connecting Watalinga to the Mt Hoyo Reserve (200 km2), where Okapi have also been recorded, is due to start in 2015. Okapi occur in Rubi-Tele Hunting Reserve (c. 9,000 km2), though its precise legal status is unclear, in Abumonbanzi Reserve in the far west of the range, and on the west bank of the Congo River, where the proposed Lomami National Park within the Tshuapa-Lomami-Lualaba landscape (9,500 km2) is undergoing the process of official gazettement (Kümpel et al. 2015). A number of community reserves are located around Maiko National Park.

Many captive Okapi are held in international collections. In November 2011, representatives of the North American and European captive populations, including the Okapi Species Survival Plan (SSP) and the Okapi European Endangered Species Programme (EEP), met to discuss the role of the captive population in Okapi conservation and agreed to maintain a sustainable, cooperatively managed global ex situ Okapi population that contributes to a viable in situ population (Petric 2012). The zoo community is a major supporter of Okapi conservation work, in 2010 donating USD 225,000 to the Okapi Conservation Project, 33% of its budget (Gilman International Conservation, 2010).

ICCN is the government agency responsible for protected area management but is under-staffed and under-funded. The Okapi Conservation Project was established in 1987 and works within the RFO to protect Okapi and their habitat, as well as the culture of the indigenous Mbuti pygmies. Project activities include capacity building, agroforestry and community support (Gilman International Conservation 2010). The Wildlife Conservation Society started field surveys and research on Okapi in RFO and elsewhere in DRC in the 1980s. Several other international NGOs have also conducted Okapi-related work in DRC, including Fauna & Flora International, Frankfurt Zoological Society, the Lukuru Foundation, and the Zoological Society of London (ZSL). The first-ever species-wide Okapi conservation strategy was developed at a workshop held in DRC in May 2013 that was organised by ZSL in partnership with ICCN (Kümpel et al. 2015). In March 2013 a new IUCN SSC Giraffe and Okapi Specialist Group was established, co-hosted by ZSL, with the aim of coordinating research and conservation on both giraffid species and supporting implementation of the Okapi conservation strategy.

rationale: <span class="apple-style-span">This species is listed as Least Concern because it is widely distributed, is present in protected areas and because there are no major widespread threats currently affecting its population.
habitat: This species was collected in a blackwater flooded lake with sandy/muddy shore and bottom and abundant aquatic plants (Ponthederia, Eichhornia) and cyperaceans, and a white turbid water lagoon with muddy shore and bottom with aquatic plants and grasses in its margins.
threats: This species may be affected by habitat modification and pollution produced by oil extraction and transportation.
population: There are no data on population size and trends for this species.
range: This species occurs in the Madre de Dios and Amazon river basin in Peru (Ortega et al. 2012), in the Madre de Dios, Orthon, Beni, and Mamoré River basins of Bolivia (Chernoff et al. 2000, Chernoff and Willink 1999, Carvajal-Vallejos et al. 2014), in the Amazon basin of Colombia (Bogotá-Gregory and Maldonado-Ocampo 2006, Maldonado-Ocampo et al. 2008) and in the Napo-Pastaza basin in Ecuador (Barriga 2012). Its type locality is Lagartococha, a northern tributary of the Aguarico River, between 0°39'S, 75°16'W and 0°28'S, 75°21'W, in Napo, Ecuador (200-220 m asl.) (Nijssen and Isbrücker 1986). This species occurs at elevations between 100 to 400 m asl.
useTrade: Corydoras napoensis "san juan" is listed in Peru´s ornamental fish report (Sánchez et al. 2006), and it is exported from this country (Campos 2005, Prang 2007).
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species. It is present in protected areas (Tambopata National Reserve in Peru and Cuyabeño Reserve in Ecuador).

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern because it is widely distributed, is locally abundant, and its population is stable.
habitat: This species inhabits small streams with abundant vegetation and it feeds on algae and detritus.
threats: This species is locally affected by habitat modification and pollution produced by deforestation, agriculture, mining, oil extraction, and livestock.
population: Odontostible dierythura is a common to abundant fish species.
range: This species is present in the Beni, Madre de Dios and Mamoré river basins in the Bolivian Amazon (Carvajal-Vallejos and Zeballos Fernández 2011). Its type locality is Todos Santos, in the Chapare River, Bolivia (Fowler 1940). It occurs at elevations between 160 and 450 m.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: This species is present in at least one protected area (Estación Biologica Beni).

rationale: This species has a wide range. At least one subpopulation is being  affected by reduction of   water quality, mainly due to oil extraction  activities. However, several known locations are currently not    affected by any threat, and it occurs in the buffer zone of a conservation area. Hence, the  species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Tropical benthopelagic freshwater fish (Froese and Pauly 2013). It has omnivorous habits. These fish have diurnal habits, do not migrate and live in clear or black water. Reproduction is aseasonal, and they have parental care.
threats: A least one subpopulation is being affected by oil  extraction activities due to oil spills, as well as because the saline  and hot purge water is poured into the river. The subpopulation in the Rio Marañón may be affected in future by the construction and operation of a hydroelectric dam upstreams, which could lead to a decrease in water quality and habitat transformation due to retention of sediments by the dam.
population: The species is relatively common and abundant where it occurs. The population seems to be stable.
range: This species occurs in the Amazon river basin in Peru (Ortega et al. 2012) and probably in the Napo, Pastaza and Chinchipe basin in Ecuador (Barriga 2012). Its type locality is in the Carahuayte Ravine, on the road between Jenaro Herrera and Colonia Angamos in the Ucayali River drainage, Loreto, Peru (Kullander 1986). Also is present in the Putumayo river, limit of Colombia and Peru. The species occurs at altitudes between 120 and 250 m asl.
useTrade: The species may be used as a protein source by local communities.
conservationActions: The species probably occurs in the buffer zone of Area de Conservación Regional Tamshiyacu in Peru. There are no direct conservation measures in place for this species.

rationale: This species has a wide range. At least two subpopulations are being affected by reduction of   water quality, mainly due to oil extraction activities. However, several known locations are currently not   affected by any threat, and it occurs in two national parks. Hence, the species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This is a benthopelagic freshwater fish (Froese and Pauly 2013). It has omnivorous habits with a tendency to frugivory and insectivory. These fish have diurnal habits, do not migrate and live in clear water. Reproduction is seasonal, and they have parental care.
threats:
Some subpopulations (at least two of them) are being affected by oil extraction activities due to oil spills, as well as because the saline and hot purge water is poured into the river.
The subpopulations near Tarapoto, Yurimauas and Tingo Maria are being affected by a reduction in habitat quality due to urban wastewaters.
population: The number of records of this species seems to indicate that it is common in Peru. The population is probably stable.
range: This species occurs in the Amazon river basin in Peru (Ortega et al. 2012) and is probably present in the Chinchipe and Morona-Santiago basins in Ecuador (Barriga 2012). During a survey carried out in October 2005, Ortega et al. (2007) reported the presence of 211 specimens in the following river basins of the Northeast of Peru: five in Tarapoto, 59 in Pongo, 138 in Cóndor-Pumayacu, and 9 in Yurimaguas. Its type locality is near Tingo Maria, about 1/4 mile above River Huallaga, in the Huánuco Department, Peru (Kullander 1986). Also is present in the Putumayo river, limit of Colombia and Peru. It occurs at altitudes between 100 and 600 m asl.
useTrade: The species may be used as a protein source by local communities.
conservationActions: The species occurs in Parque Nacional Cordillera Azul and in Parque Nacional Tingo Maria (Peru).

rationale: This is a rare species that has a relatively large range (extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 31,000 km²), it occurs at 7-10 locations, and is affected by several human activities that are causing continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat. Hence the species is classified as Near Threatened.
habitat: This species is a small omnivorous fish that inhabits clear water rivers and streams.
threats: This species is affected by habitat modification and pollution due to agricultural activities, and it is also affected by urban waste, oil extraction, and irrigation.
population: There are no data on population size and trends for this species, but it seems to be rare.
range: This species occurs in the Mamoré river basins in Bolivia (Lauzanne et al. 1991, Chernoff et al. 2000, Carvajal-Vallejos and Zeballos Fernández 2011). Its type locality is Boca Chapare, in Cochabamba, Bolivia (Fowler 1940). It occurs at elevations between 150 m and 600 m. The EOO is estimated as about 31,000 km² and it occurs at seven to ten locations (based on the main threats affecting the species).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species. Research is needed to better determine its distribution and population size and trend and the threats that may be affecting it.

rationale: Listed as Near Threatened because, although it does not have a restricted range and it seems to have recolonized areas where it has been absent from for many years, there is continuing decline in quality and extent of its habitat, even in protected areas, and threats such as deforestation, logging and chytridiomycosis  might seriously threaten the species in the future, so careful monitoring should be addressed to this species.
habitat: It inhabits lowland and premontane wet and moist forests, living in and alongside pristine streams. It is usually not found in degraded forest but it has been recorded from forest patches which have been farmed until about thirty years ago (Maskell et al. 2009). This species inhabits the forest leaf litter, it breeds by direct development and the eggs are laid on land.
threats: Agricultural development, both at big and small-scale, is the principal reason for the disruption of its habitat. Logging, hydroelectric development, oil and mineral extraction and human population growth are other known threats (Briggs et al. 2013). Other species of its genus that are associated with streams have undergone dramatic declines and disappearances, possibly due to chytridiomycosis, so the status of this species should be monitored carefully. Moreover, several protected areas where the species occurs are not well-managed, so the level of protection they provide is not adequate to secure the species' preservation (M. Acevedo pers. comm. 2016).
population: It has suffered serious population reductions since the 1990s in Guatemala, and many surveys conducted within the Sierra Santa Cruz and other forested  areas in the Caribbean Guatemala (i.e. Sierra Caral Amphibian Reserve),  during the period 2010-2015, failed to find this species and others of  its genus (C. Vasquez pers. comm. 2016). However, it has been recently recorded again from other Guatemalan localities where it was thought to have gone extinct (M. Acevedo pers. comm. 2016) and it is still common in Belize.
range: This species is known from the foothills of eastern Guatemala, including the Montañas del Mico, the eastern portion of the Sierra de las Minas, the northern portion of the Sierra de Merendón, and the Sierra Caral. It also occurs in Belize, from the Maya Mountains to the Rio Branco Management Area (Walker and Walker 2011, Waldon 2015). Its likely occurrence in Honduras still requires confirmation. It elevational range is from near sea level to about 900 m asl and extent of occurrence (EOO) 25,992 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation actions
In Belize it is known from protected areas of the Maya Mountains and associated foothills, including the Columbia River Forest Reserve, the Bladen Forest Reserve, the Mayflower Bocawina National Park and the Rio Bravo Conservation Management Area (Walker and Walker 2011); in Guatemala it has been found in the Montanas del Mico Catchment Reserve, in the Reserva de la Biosfera Sierra de las Minas and in the Sierra Caral Reserve.

Research needed
Studies on its population size, distribution and trends, life history and ecology, and threats are needed. Further research is necessary to establish the reasons for the declines witnessed in this species in undisturbed habitat. Monitoring of population distribution and abundance at currently known sites (i.e. Sierra Caral) is needed.

rationale: This species is listed as Near Threatened on the basis that has an estimated extent of occurrence of around 28,000 km<sup>2</sup>, but due to the intensity of threats in this area of Ecuador it is thought to occur at fewer than 10, and probably fewer than six, locations based on threats from deforestation; and there is a continuing decline in the quality and extent of its habitat due to habitat change for settlement, agricultural expansion and grazing. It is consequently close to qualifying for a threatened category applying criterion B.
habitat: This species occurs in tropical dry forests, including both primary and secondary forest (J. Valencia and D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2014). It has been recorded in non-forested areas, including a beach close to a town (A. Arteaga unpubl. data), but most records are from forested situations (J. Valencia and D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2014). This diurnal species is primarily terrestrial, but sleeps in bushes.
threats: The major threats to this species are deforestation and habitat change due to agricultural expansion, settlement and cattle ranching. There is some oil infrastructure development on the coast, but this is localized. This species occurs in a heavily-populated area with very few protected areas, and where most suitable dry forest habitat has been lost in the last 50 years (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2016). This species may be subject to localized persecution due to local beliefs that it is venomous (M. Yánez-Muñoz and J. Valencia pers. comm. 2014).
population: This species is considered rare, and records are taken only once every few months in a very well surveyed area of Ecuador (M. Yánez-Muñoz, J. Valencia and D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2014).
range: This species is a near-endemic to the dry forests of Manabí, Guayas and Santa Elena in southwest Ecuador, and from La Plata Island in the same region. There are two so far unconfirmed records from northern Peru (P. Venegas unpub. data)
useTrade: There is no known use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species is found in Machalilla National Park (which includes La Plata Island) and in Manglares-Churute Ecological Reserve. Further information is needed on this snake's ecological requirements.

rationale: This species is listed as Critically Endangered because it is known only from the type locality in a small sand dune system and there is intensive oil and gas exploration and exploitation that is causing continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: Liolaemus cuyumhue is known from an isolated sand dune system in the region known as Bajo de Añelo, in eastern Neuquén. The dunes are sparsely covered by clumps of Sporobolus rigens, Neosparton darwinii, Larrea divaricata, Prosopis flexuosa var depressa, and Atriplex zampa. Individuals of L. cuyumhue are observed only on bare or sparsely vegetated dunes with extensive areas of open sand. They appear not to extend out into the more vegetated sandy flats or rocky areas that usually border the dunes. It is insectivorous and presumably oviparous, as are other members of the wiegmannii group (Avila et al. 2009).
threats: Liolaemus cuyumhue lives in a region were the oil and gas companies conduct some of the more intensive operations in Argentina; new rigs, tracks and roads are opened regularly; frequently modifying some areas with suitable habitats for L. cuyumhue that apparently do not cover large areas in the Bajo de Añelo (Avila et al. 2009, Abdala et al. 2012).
population: There are no data on population size and trends for this species. It is a rare species.
range: Liolaemus cuyumhue is known only from the type locality in Añelo basin close to the Provincial Road 7, in Neuquén Province (Avila et al. 2009). The holotype was collected at 259 m and one of the paratypes at 260 m (Avila et al. 2009). The area of occupancy is estimated to be around 5 km2, the extent of the dune system.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species is categorized as Vulnerable in Argentina (Abdala et al. 2012). The species is not known to occur in protected areas.

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient. as although it is common within its very restricted distribution and it is found within a protected area, any impacts on this species from oil exploration within the area are unknown. Monitoring the population is recommended.
habitat: The Auca Mahuida Volcanic Field is an isolated basaltic plateau with the Auca Mahuida volcano in its center, surrounded by dunes fields or sandy flatlands with extremely arid characteristics, and is an island of Patagonian-like environment in the middle of Monte phytogeographic region (Martínez et al. 2011). It is terrestrial, oviparous that feeds mainly on insects.
threats: There is oil exploitation in the area where this species occurs and oil platform rigs. However, it is unknown if this activity is affecting the population of this species (L. Avila pers. comm. 2014).
population: There are no data on population size and trends for this species. It is locally common.
range: This species is known only from the area of the type locality in Auca Mahuida Volcano, Pehuenches Department, Neuquén Province, Argentina; where it has been found from 1,332 to 1,983 m asl (Martínez et al. 2011). The extent of occurrence is estimated in approximately 100 km2 (the extent of the Auca Mahuida volcano).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: Classified as Insufficiently Known because the information about its distribution is scarce and natural history is unknown (Abdala et al. 2012). The entire range of this species is within the Auca Mahuida provincial park. Population monitoring is nevertheless recommended to clarify the impacts, if any, from oil exploration.

rationale: This species is listed as Near Threatened due to is small range (an extent of occurrence of 2,700 km<sup>2</sup>) and occurrence in fewer than ten locations threatened by ongoing petroleum extraction (even within the one provincial protected area where the species occurs). Thus the species nearly classifies for Vulnerable B1ab(iii), however, there is presently insufficient information to determine whether the population is declining and the species is always recorded when herpetologists visit its range despite ongoing degradation of its habitat.
habitat: From its distribution it can be inferred that this species is found in a transitional region between Monte and Patagonia phytogeographic provinces. Like other members of the genus is a saxicolous, viviparous and herbivorous species (Abdala et al. 2012).
threats: This species lives in fairly inaccessible rocky areas. In the La Payunia region there is much oil extraction activity, which, although it does not directly affect the rocky outcrops where the species occurs, may indirectly affect the species by interrupting dispersal between habitat patches because of the numerous roads that are being constructed (Abdala et al. 2012).
population: This species is uncommonly encountered within its range. The range has been visited on several occasions by herpetologists, most recently in 2012 (C.S. Abdala, unpublished data), and the species has always been found. Due to the infrequency of the visits and the rarity of the species, the population trend is unknown.
range: Phymaturus payunae is endemic to Argentina, occurring in la Payunia, southern Mendoza province at elevations of 1,200-1,500 m asl (Avila et al. 2011, Abdala et al. 2012).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade.
conservationActions:
There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. It occurs in the La Payunia Provincial Reserve, although oil exploration occurs within the reserve.

Classified as Vulnerable in Argentina because of its small distribution and habitat specialization (Abdala et al. 2012).

rationale: Listed as Least Concern because, although the extent of occurrence is limited (11,250 km<sup>2</sup>), the only known current or future threats affect a minority of the range, the species is abundant, and there is no evidence of a population decline, and the species occurs in two protected areas.
habitat: This species is found in Monte phytogeograhic province. Like other members of the genus is a saxicolous, viviparous and herbivorous species (Abdala et al. 2012).
threats: This species lives in fairly inaccessible rocky areas. In the La Payunia region there is much oil extraction activity, which, although it does not directly affect the rocky outcrops where the species occurs, may indirectly affect the species by interrupting dispersal between habitat patches because of the numerous roads that are being constructed (Abdala et al. 2012).
population: This species is commonly encountered within its range. The range has been visited on numerous occasions by herpetologists, most recently in 2013 (C.S. Abdala, unpublished data), and the species has always been reported as common. There is no evidence of a population decline.
range: Phymaturus roigorum is endemic to Argentina, where it occurs in the Sierra Nevado, La Payunia, and Malargüe in the province of Mendoza and in Auca Mahuida in the province of Neuquén. Its elevational range is 1,500 to 2,300 m asl (Lobo and Abdala 2007).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions:
There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. It occurs in the La Payunia Provincial Reserve and the Auca Mahuida Natural Protected Area.

Classified as Vulnerable in Argentina because of its restricted distribution, it is a habitat specialist. Phymaturus species are viviparous and take between seven and nine years to reach sexual maturity and have a low litter size from one to two individuals per female (Abdala et al. 2012).

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification and presumed large population.
habitat: Its habitat is grasslands, prairies, plains and aspen parklands; areas with relatively soft soil. It is usually found in or near water and burrows into soil when inactive. Eggs are laid and larvae develop in shallow water of lakes, ponds, quiet streams, marshes, potholes, and roadside ditches.
threats: Generally, there are no major threats to this species. However, local declines and low abundance in Alberta have been attributed to loss of wetlands; low abundance/population fluctuation in Manitoba possibly was due to drought (see Green 1997). Oil and gas exploration has more recently become a threat to habitat.
population: Some local declines have been reported (Green 1997), but provincial conservation data centres rank this species as apparently secure in the main portion of its range in Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba.
range: This species can be found in south-central Canada and north-central USA, from southern Northwest Territories through Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba to northern Montana, North Dakota, northeastern South Dakota, and west-central Minnesota (Conant and Collins 1991).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Research Needed
Better information on abundance and population trends is needed.

rationale: This species has a wide distribution, with no known major widespread threats. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species inhabits open water and vegetated areas of lakes, rivers, lagoons and irrigation canals. According to Bailey (1994), this species is mainly insectivorous, feeding on the bottom and in vegetation. Females grow larger and are more frequently caught than males.
threats: There are no known widespread threats to this species. Subpoulations in the Niger Delta are threatened with habitat loss and degradation due to oil exploration, and pollution related to urban and industrial development.
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range:
This species is widespread in lakes and rivers throughout central, north-east and western Africa:

Central Africa: It is known from the Chad river basin.

Northeast Africa: This mormyrid is known from the Nile river basin.

West Africa: This species is known from the Benue, Comoe, Gambia, Niger and Volta river basins.
useTrade: This species is harvested for human consumption.
conservationActions: Little information is available on this species. Research is recommended into its population and ecology, alongside motioning of its population trend. Within western Africa, part of the range is included within the Ramsar sites at the Lake Chad Basin.

rationale: This species has a wide distribution, with no known major widespread threats. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This is a demersal potamodromous fish that grows to a standard length of 84 cm.
threats: This species may be threatened with loss of habitat in Lake Chad, where drought has reduced the lake surface area drastically, and in the Niger Delta, where there has been incidences of oil pollution. However, there are no known widespread threats to this species.
population: There is no information on the population of this species.
range: This species is known from the Chad, Bénué, Niger and Volta basins in west Africa.
useTrade: This fish is harvested for human consumption.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation actions in place for this species, but research into its population size, trend and distribution is recommended, alongside monitoring of habitat trends.

rationale: Pelvicachromis pulcher has a wide distribution, with limited threats. It is therefore listed as Least Concern
habitat: Pelvicachromis pulcher is a demersal substrate spawner. It occurs in freshwater and in brackish water, and is able to survive in anoxic conditions. It feeds on worms, crustaceans and insects (Mills and Vevers 1989).
threats: Oil exploration and oil spills in the Niger delta threaten this species, as does deforestation in south-west Nigeria.
population: No data are available on the population.
range:
This species is found in eastern Benin, southern Nigeria and western Cameroon. 

Central Africa: In Lower Guinea, Pelvicachromis pulcher is known from the Cross River basin, and from western Cameroon (Ndonga) (Stiassny et al. 2008). 

Western Africa: This species is known from eastern Benin and south-western Nigeria to the River Cross (Teugels et al. 2003).
useTrade: This species is part of the aquarium trade.
conservationActions: Part of the distribution of this species falls within the Korup National Park in Cameroon. Population trends of this species should be monitored, and habitat maintenance is required in Nigeria.

rationale: Nothobranchius hengstleri is listed as Endangered. The species is currently known only from an ephemeral pool of the type locality and wetland habitats in the adjacent Afungi peninsula, representing two threat-based locations. This species is expected to occur at other sites within the same small coastal plateau, with an EOO expected to have a maximum estimate of around 200 km². The distribution is thought likely to remain restricted, with an AOO of up to 48 km², and potential additional populations are expected to be fragmented, at less than five threat-based locations. The only known habitat has been modified due to the expansion of agricultural activities and is currently cultivated as a rice-field. Increasing pressure on land resources and the consequent habitat degradation represents a significant threat to the species. Based on this threat there are two known locations and a maximum estimate of five threat-based locations. This category is assigned based on using the upper estimates of the EOO, AOO and number of locations as best estimates.
habitat:
This species has an annual life cycle (Valdesalici 2007) and reproduces in the seasonally arid savannah biome (Watters 2009, Nagy 2015). It inhabits relatively small ephemeral bodies of water, temporary pools and marshes, during the rainy season. Eggs are deposited directly into the uppermost layer of the substratum, which comprises predominantly soft, dark grey to black mud and is always of a vertisol-type containing swelling clays (Watters 2009). The eggs undergo development and diapause in the substratum through the dry season. During the next rainy season, the eggs hatch, the fish mature, and breed before the pool dries up again.

Water parameters determined at the type locality by Hengstler (Valdesalici 2007) are: pH of 7.5; and turbid. Water parameters as determined in ERM (2014) are: temperature of 26.9–30.3; pH of 5.8–6.1.
threats: This species is known only from a relatively restricted area in a small coastal plateau in Cabo Delgado province in north-eastern Mozambique, where it inhabits a small seasonal wetland habitats, including its type locality. A second visit to the type locality, 13 years after its discovery, showed that the original habitat was altered. Due to road construction, the locality moved from left side of the road to the right side, and it is presently cultivated as a rice-field. This type of activity modifies habitats in ways that render them unsuitable to support the annual life cycle of the species over the long term. Consequently, the ephemeral pool was no longer a typical habitat of seasonal fishes and there were only a few fishes in the habitat (Hengstler pers. comm.). At some sites in the Afungi peninsula, there is extensive cultivation of cassava. Recently, there have been very significant natural gas discoveries in Palma Bay, directly offshore from the Afungi peninsula, and the subsequent exploration and development work might impact the coastal ecosystem (ERM 2014). The increasing pressure on land resources, and consequent habitat degradation, will continue to raise the vulnerability of this species in terms of conservation status.
population: Including the discovery in 2005, only a few observations are available, two from the type locality and four in the Afungi peninsula near the coast. This is an area of a small coastal plateau, which drains towards the ocean. The type locality is found along the road that crosses the area. Further populations are likely to exist at less accessible places within the drainage of the river.
range: This species is endemic to seasonal freshwater habitats in north-eastern Mozambique. It is known from the type locality, an ephemeral pool in a small coastal plateau, and seasonal wetland habitats in the adjacent Afungi peninsula in Cabo Delgado province in north-eastern Mozambique (Valdesalici 2007, ERM 2014).
useTrade: This species is maintained and bred by a few specialists in aquarium hobby. It has no significant commercial value.
conservationActions: No conservation measures are in place for this species. It is not known from any protected areas. There is a need for improved habitat protection at the sites where the species is known to occur. Further surveys aimed at investigating population size and trends, threats and habitat trends within the entire range of distribution are needed to better determine the appropriate measures for conservation.

rationale: The species has a restricted range and is probably suffering from a continuous decline in the quality of its habitat from deforestation for coca plantations, oil extraction, and soil erosion. However, it is likely to occur in more than ten locations and the population is not severely fragmented. It is therefore listed as Near Threatened.
habitat: Gephyrocharax chaparae is a pelagic species that occurs in small and large streams, and is probably insectivorous.
threats: The main threats to this species are from deforestation for plantations of fruit and coca (use of agrochemicals), oil extraction, and soil erosion. However, these tend to be localized to the Chapare basin in the Cochabamba Department.
population: There are no data on population size and trends for this species, but seems to be a common species.
range: Gephyrocharax chaparae is endemic to Bolivia. It occurs in the Mamore River basin (Rio Chapare, Ichilo, Isiboro) at elevations between 190 and 270 m (Carvajal-Vallejos et al. 2014).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species. Further research is needed into the taxonomy and population size and trends of the species.

rationale: Liolaemus austromendocinus is listed as Least Concern because it is common, there are no major threats affecting its population and is present in protected areas.
habitat: This species is found in arid rocky areas. It is viviparous.
threats: There are no known major threats to this species, although in parts of its range there is oil exploitation.
population: There are currently no population data available for this species. It is a common species.
range: This species is found in southern Mendoza and northern Neuquen, Argentina, between 34 and 37 degrees latitude. This species has an elevation range of 900 to 2,310 m above sea level.
useTrade: This species is not utilized or traded.
conservationActions: There are currently no conservation measures in place for this species. It is present in several provincial protected areas.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat: It is an arboreal species from forest and open areas, and it inhabits Amazonian rainforest, inter-Andean valleys, Bolivian-Tucumano montane forest, and Yungas forest (De la Riva et al. 2000). Köhler (2000) points out that this species occurs in semi-deciduous forest, in dry valleys, and in humid and cloud forest. It can be found near streams and ponds. It lays its eggs underwater. Some larvae were observed in slow streams, inside small pits (15 cm; Lötters et al. 1999).
threats: There are no major threats to this species in Bolivia, although oil exploration and exploitation is a localised threat. In Argentina, selective logging, clear cutting of old-growth forest, trout introduction and the alteration of watersheds are localised threats.
population: This species is common in Bolivia. It is rare in Argentina, although the subpopulations are protected within Parque Nacional Baritú and possibly in provincial reserves (Lavilla et al. 2000 – Cuad. de Herp.; M. Vaira pers. obs.). The population is considered to be relatively stable, although there may be localised declines due to habitat loss.
range: This species is found east of the Andes from central Bolivia to northern Argentina. In Bolivia, it occurs from 450–2,000 m asl in the Departments of Cochabamba, Chuquisaca, Tarija, and Santa Cruz (Duellman et al. 1997, De la Riva et al. 2000). In Argentina, it is found between 500–1,500 m asl. Frost (2019) reports an elevational range extending up to 2,650 m asl for this species.
useTrade: There are no records of the species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
It occurs in Parques Nacionales Carrasco, Amboró, Tariquia, and Iñao in Bolivia. In Argentina, it occurs in Parque Nacional Baritú.

Research Needed
More information is needed on the species' distribution, population status, and trends. Further research is required to fully resolve the taxonomic status of the species.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification, and presumed large population.
habitat: This species inhabits lowland forest and is found in terra firme and seasonally flooded forest with a close canopy and wide leaves. Individuals are usually found perched on leaves at night (10–15 m); by day they have been found in bromeliads and sleeping on the undersides of leaves on bushes and trees (Duellman 1978, Rodríguez and Duellman 1994). It is present in cultivated areas. It feeds on ants and termites. This is a direct developing species.
threats: There are no major threats; it is a widespread species with large areas of suitable habitat remaining. There is some localized habitat loss to general human activities such as agriculture (crops, livestock etc.). Within Peru, selective wood extraction and oil exploitation (northern Peru) and colonization (central Peru) are specific threats.
population: It is locally abundant in Ecuador; known from relatively few individuals in Peru. The population is presumed to be stable.
range: This species was previously reported in the lowland reaches of the Andes in southern Ecuador; Loreto Department in northern Peru, southern Colombia, and Acre State in Brazil. However, following genetic and morphological analysis, subpopulations from eastern Ecuador (Morona-Santiago, Orellana, and Pastaza provinces) and northern Loreto Department in Peru, up to 960 m asl, have now been assigned to other species (Ortega-Andrade et al. 2015). This species is now restricted to the lowland reaches of the Andes in southern Ecuador (Morona-Santiago and Pastaza provinces) and in northern Peru, through the Pastaza Trench. It can be found in elevations of 100–900 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
It is present in a number of protected areas. Within Peru, the range of this species overlaps with Parque Nacional Cordillera Azul. In Ecuador, it occurs in the Reserva Biológica Limoncocha, Parque Nacional Yasuní, and Parque Nacional Sumaco Napo-Galeras. 

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, and trends.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat: This species can be found in Amazonian primary lowland forest, including terra firme forest (nonflooded forest), várzea (flooded forest), and seasonally flooded forest (Guayasamin et al. 2006). Individuals can be most often found up to 40 m into the canopy, often associated with bromeliads, although they may also occur on low vegetation and on the forest floor (Guayasamin et al. 2006). Breeding occurs by direct development.
threats: No major threats are known for this species. Deforestation and forest fragmentation caused by petroleum operations and subsequent road building and colonization have been observed in the vicinity Tiputini Biodiversity Station (McCracken and Forstner 2014b). Nonetheless, Tiputini Biodiversity Station is only accessible by river and the area is still surrounded by undisturbed primary lowland rainforest (McCracken and Forstner 2014a). Four out of seven specimens collected during May–August of 2004 and 2006 from sites surrounding Tiputini Biodiversity Station tested positive for Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (McCracken et al. 2009), however whether Bd constitutes a threat to this direct developing species remains unknown.
population: This appears to be an abundant species in the canopy; bromeliad patch sampling of 40 bromeliads among eight trees resulted in the collection of eight specimens (Guayasamin et al. 2006). The scarcity of this species in herpetological collections is likely an artifact of survey methodology (Guayasamin et al. 2006). Its population trend is generally stable.
range: This species is known from below 350 m asl in the upper Amazon Basin of eastern Ecuador and Loreto Region in northern Peru (Guayasamin et al. 2006).
useTrade: There are no records of the species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
The species occurs within two biological stations in Ecuador, Yasuní Scientific Research Station and Tiputini Biodiversity Station.

Research Needed
Further research on this species' population size, distribution and trends is recommended.

rationale: This species is assessed as Vulnerable. It has an area of occupancy (AOO) best estimated at 1,376 km<sup>2</sup>. Its distribution is affected by extensive deforestation of headwaters and riparian forest, extraction of  water directly from rivers, urban and agro-industrial untreated  effluents and transformation of channels by dams and canalization. There are two locations based on these threats and an inferred continuing decline in habitat quality.
habitat: The habitat for Creagrutus atratus includes creeks, streams and rivers principally in piedmonts and mountains. It inhabits slow currents, clear waters and varied substrates (mud, sand, gravel). The fishes of the genus Creagrutus are omnivorous and feed on aquatic and terrestrial insects, plants and seeds. They can reach 70 mm in standard length. The reproduction is probably periodic and in the rainy season.
threats: Some drainages and rivers where Creagrutus atratus occurs remain in good condition. However, in many others drainages impacts include extensive deforestation of headwaters and riparian forest, extraction of water directly from rivers, urban and agro-industrial untreated effluents and transformation of channels by dams and canalization. These threats have not ceased and are expected to expand in the future.
population: According to the natural abundance and broad distribution of Creagrutus atratus, the total population size is suspected to be greater than 10,000 individuals.
range:
Creagrutus atratus is endemic to Colombia and known from the Andean piedmont. Its type locality is Río Caqueza, a tributary to Río Negro, about 2 km upstream of village of Caqueza, Meta drainage, Cundinamarca (Vari and Harold 2001). The species inhabis upper sections of rivers Upía, Meta and Arauca (Maldonado-Ocampo et al. 2008, Urbano-Bonilla et al. 2009).

The distribution of Creagrutus atratus in this assessment is a summary based on scientific reports and records compiled, arranged and reviewed from the following sources: Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF 2020), FishNet2 (Fishnet2 2020), FishBase (Froese and Pauly 2019), SiB Colombia (SiB Colombia 2020) and SpeciesLink (SpeciesLink 2020), and complemented with records from the databases of the following ichthyological collections from Colombia: CZUT-IC (Colección Zoológica, Universidad del Tolima, Ibagué), IAvH-P (Colección de Peces de Agua Dulce del Instituto de Investigación de Recursos Biológicos Alexander von Humboldt, Villa de Leyva), ICN-MHN (Instituto de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional de Colombia, Bogotá), IMCN (Colección Zoológica de Referencia Científica del Museo de Ciencias Naturales Federico Carlos Lehmann Valencia del INCIVA, Cali), and MPUJ (Museo Javeriano de Historia Natural "Lorenzo Uribe, S.J." de la Pontificia Universidad Javeriana, Bogotá), and Venezuela: MCNG (Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional Experimental de los Llanos Occidentales Ezequiel Zamora, Guanare, Venezuela) and CPUCLA (Colección Regional de Peces, Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Centroccidental Lisandro Alvarado, Barquisimeto, Venezuela).
useTrade: There are no known uses for the species.
conservationActions: It is not known from any conservation sites or protected areas (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020) but is possibly in Natural Park Chingaza. There are no laws, regulations and educational programs for its protection. Awareness raising and communications are recommended. It is necessary to research the population size and distribution, threats and habitat.

rationale: This species has a wide extent of occurrence in the Orinoco basin and is reported in protected areas. The data in biological collections and different regional reports do not suggest a perceptible reduction in the population of the species. Consequently, Astyanax integer is classified as Least Concern. However, threats affect several rivers within the distribution, principally in the Andean versants. Monitoring and research on the habitat and population are necessary.
habitat: Astyanax integer is most common in streams and rivers in mountains and piedmonts, but it also occurs in lagoons and rivers in lowlands. It inhabits clear, white and black waters, usually on heterogeneous substrates. It is omnivorous and stays in the current waiting for water-derived food, such as seeds, fruits or insects (Taphorn 1992). It can reach 120 mm in standard length. Reproduction is annual and during the first months of rains. It can reach a fertility of 8,400 eggs/female and the generation length is 12 months  (Winemiller and Taphorn 1989).
threats: Various drainages which Astyanax integer inhabits (e.g. Meta, Torbes, Guanare, Cojedes) have strong urban and agricultural impacts with deterioration of aquatic habitats (e.g. Taphorn 1992, Briceño 2015). In piedmonts and mountains, the combined actions of agriculture and deforestation are common (Oliveira-Miranda et al. 2010), with the loss of riparian forests and non-native food sources for the species (Winemiller et al. 1996). In the Guiana Shield, gold mining has a detrimental effect on the river ecosystem and the habitat of the species. In some drainages there is oil exploitation and eventually this will impact nearby rivers where the species inhabits, as Apure and Meta drainages. All these human stressors threaten the species, mainly in the transition zone of piedmont with the plains.
population: Astyanax integer is a frequent species in samples and databases. The subpopulations must be large according to samples applied in rivers in piedmonts, plains and llanos. No data exist for to estimate the actual population size and trend, but the trend is suspected to be stable considering the abundance and the conditions of several rivers in the piedmonts and mountains where it lives. A potential reduction in the population in the future is expected due to a decline in the quality of habitat given the expansion of the human frontier, principally in the Andes slopes, where the degree of intervention is very high (Rodríguez-Olarte and Taphorn 1995, Oliveira-Miranda et al. 2010, Briceño 2015).
range:
Astyanax integer is described from the upper Meta river basin in Colombia, at the junction of Río Guavio and Río Upía (Myers 1930). The species occurs in Andean tributaries of the Orinoco. In Colombia reports include the rivers Duda, Ariari, Cravo Sur, Cusiana, Casanare and Meta (Maldonado-Ocampo et al. 2008, Urbano-Bonilla et al. 2009, DoNascimiento et al. 2018). For Venezuela the species occurs in Apure drainage, including several rivers between Uribante and Portuguesa (Taphorn 1992). There are records in river Aguaro in central llanos (Taphorn et al. 2005) and Morichal Largo in eastern llanos. In the Guiana Shield the species is known in the Caura (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2003) and Caroní rivers, and small tributaries in lower Orinoco. There are unconfirmed and doubtful records from Ecuador in the río Napo drainage, upper Amazon Basin and they are not included here. The species is reported in 500 sites with elevation from 52-509 m above sea level.

The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated at 620,692 km2 based on georeferenced point records.

The geographic attributes for Astyanax integer in this assessment were compiled, arranged and reviewed from the following sources: Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF 2020), FishNet2 (Fishnet2 2020), FishBase (Froese and Pauly 2019), SiB Colombia (SiB Colombia 2020) and SpeciesLink (SpeciesLink 2020), and complemented with records from the databases of the following ichthyological collections from Colombia: CZUT-IC (Colección Zoológica, Universidad del Tolima, Ibagué), IAvH-P (Colección de Peces de Agua Dulce del Instituto de Investigación de Recursos Biológicos Alexander von Humboldt, Villa de Leyva), ICN-MHN (Instituto de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional de Colombia, Bogotá), IMCN (Colección Zoológica de Referencia Científica del Museo de Ciencias Naturales Federico Carlos Lehmann Valencia del INCIVA, Cali), and MPUJ (Museo Javeriano de Historia Natural "Lorenzo Uribe, S.J." de la Pontificia Universidad Javeriana, Bogotá), and Venezuela: MCNG (Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional Experimental de los Llanos Occidentales Ezequiel Zamora, Guanare, Venezuela) and CPUCLA (Colección Regional de Peces, Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Centroccidental Lisandro Alvarado, Barquisimeto, Venezuela).
useTrade: Astyanax integer is occasional in subsistence fisheries (criollo and indigenous people) but the volume of harvest is unknown. It has little ornamental interest.
conservationActions: Astyanax integer is detected in protected areas (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020). In Colombia the species is detected in National Natural Parks Sierra de la Macarena, Natural Parks Laguna de San Vicente and Laguna Loma Linda, in Venezuela the species inhabit in National Parks El Tamá, Sierra Nevada, Tucuragua, Aguaro-Guariquito, Caura and Forest Reserve Ticoporo. It probably occurs in National Park Tapo Caparo (Uribante) and Wildlife Refuge Esteros de Chiriguare (Portuguesa). There are no known regulations and educational programs to the protection of Astyanax integer. Site and habitat protection, and awareness and communications raising are recommended. It is necessary to research the population size and distribution, threats and habitat.

rationale: Records in biological collections, regional reports and scientific publications suggest that the species Hemibrycon metae has a stable and widespread population and it is therefore evaluated as Least Concern. In some drainages (e.g. Tuy, Neverí, Torbes, Guanare) the habitat of Hemibrycon metae is impacted by different stressors (deforestation of watersheds and riparian areas, pollution by urban, agricultural and industrial effluents, dams and water extraction), which may indicate a greater level of threat to those subpopulations.
habitat: The habitats for the Hemibrycon metae includes creeks, streams and rivers in piedmont and mountains, but it is less frequent in the plains. This species inhabits clear waters, with the following variables: 24-26 °C, 3.7-57 μS, 4.9-5.9 pH and 7.0-8.0 mg/l O2 (Urbano-Bonilla et al. 2014), on heterogeneous substrates, principally rocks and gravel. The fish of the genus Hemibrycon are omnivorous and prefer Diptera, Trichoptera, terrestrial insects and seeds in the drift (Ortáz 1992). Hemibrycon fishes reproduce periodically in drought and rain, and show a fertility of around hundreds of eggs.
threats: In various drainages (e.g. Tuy, Neverí) evidence suggests a reduction in the quality and quantity of fluvial habitat in the near future as a consequence of the increase in environmental stressors (e.g. Oliveira-Miranda et al. 2010, Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2018), which would likely reduce the population of Hemibrycon metae and similar species. Threats to the species are greater in the drainages of the Caribbean Sea (Yaracuy, Tuy), but also in large sections of rivers associated with urban centers that generate effluents without treatment, as is the case of all cities and towns along the the Orinoco basin.
population: Hemibrycon metae is common and the total population size is suspected to be greater than 10,000 individuals, given its natural abundance and broad distribution. The current population trend is considered stable.
range:
The type locality for Hemibrycon metae is Guaicaramo, at the junction of Río Guavio and Río Upía, in Colombia (Myers 1930). In the drainage of Meta it has been found in the rivers Pauto, Cravo Sur, Cusiana, Ocoa and Túa (Urbano-Bonilla et al. 2009). In Apure drainage it occurs in rivers Torbes, Canaguá, Portuguesa, Tucupido reservoir, Cojedes and Guárico (Taphorn 1992). It is reported in Valencia Lake drainage (rivers Cumaca, San Diego), eastern llanos of Venezuela (Amana, Orupe) and Guiana Shield (Caura, Ventuari). It is also present in coastal drainages in rivers Neverí and Tuy (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2009) and drainages to Paria Gulf (El Pilar, Tiquirito, San Juan, Clavellino reservoir) (Bertaco and Malabarba 2010). Guiana Shield specimens need verification. The species is reported in 423 sites with elevation from 72-845 m above sea level.

The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated at 680,308 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around georeferenced point records. Specific threat-based locations are not counted.

The geographic attributes for Hemibrycon metae in this assessment were compiled, arranged and reviewed from the following sources: Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF 2020), FishNet2 (Fishnet2 2020), FishBase (Froese and Pauly 2019), SiB Colombia (SiB Colombia 2020) and SpeciesLink (SpeciesLink 2020), and complemented with records from the databases of the following ichthyological collections from Colombia: CZUT-IC (Colección Zoológica, Universidad del Tolima, Ibagué), IAvH-P (Colección de Peces de Agua Dulce del Instituto de Investigación de Recursos Biológicos Alexander von Humboldt, Villa de Leyva), ICN-MHN (Instituto de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional de Colombia, Bogotá), IMCN (Colección Zoológica de Referencia Científica del Museo de Ciencias Naturales Federico Carlos Lehmann Valencia del INCIVA, Cali), and MPUJ (Museo Javeriano de Historia Natural "Lorenzo Uribe, S.J." de la Pontificia Universidad Javeriana, Bogotá), and Venezuela: MCNG (Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional Experimental de los Llanos Occidentales Ezequiel Zamora, Guanare, Venezuela) and CPUCLA (Colección Regional de Peces, Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Centroccidental Lisandro Alvarado, Barquisimeto, Venezuela).
useTrade: There are no known uses for the species.
conservationActions: There are no laws, regulations and educational programs for its protection. Conservation sites and protected areas occur within its distribution (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020). In Colombia the species is registered in National Parks Sierra de la Macarena, Regional Management District Cuchillas Negra y Guanaque, Nature Reserve Mesetas de Versalles and Forest Reserve Cuenca del Río Tame. In Venezuela the species occurs in National Parks El Tamá, Guache, Yacambú, Guatopo and Caura, Forest Reserve Caparo. Probably in Tucuragua and Waraira Repano. Habitat protection and awareness are recommended. Research into taxonomy, population, distribution, threats and habitat is recommended.
