rationale: Corydoras axelrodi is restricted to upper Guaviare and Meta tributaries in the plains. The area of occupancy (AOO) is best estimated at 1,536 km². Extraction for ornamental fisheries is a threat, and there is an inferred continuing decline in mature individuals based on this. Furthermore, the habitat of the species is continuously affected by the expansion of the agricultural and urban frontier, leading to an inferred continuing declines in habitat. There are 2-4 locations based on these threats. Therefore, it is assessed as Vulnerable.
habitat: Corydoras axelrodi inhabits creeks, streams and rivers, including springs. It can be found in clearwater, streams with flow over heterogeneous substrates. It is a sociable fish, forming schools of varying size and capable of air breathing. The species is a benthic omnivore. It has parental care of eggs and young, and can be 42 mm in standard length (Reis 2003).
threats: Ornamental fishing pressure has an important effect on the natural populations of Corydoras species. Another threat is the destruction of its habitat by sedimentation and pollution associated with urban centers, deforestation, agriculture and industrial developments, and oil exploitation (Etter et al. 2006, Romero-Ruíz et al. 2012, Briceño 2015).
population: No data are available to estimate the population size. The current population trend probably is decreasing according to its exploitation in the ornamental fishery. Also, in the future a population decline is likely due to the effects of fisheries and a loss of habitat quality given the regional expansion of the human frontier.
range:
The catfish Corydoras axelrodi was described from the Meta rivers in the Orinoco basin (Rössel 1962). This species is endemic to upper Guaviare and Meta drainages in Colombia. The species has been found in rivers Guayabero, Guatiquía, Manacacías, Guavio, Upamena, Vichada and Cusiana (Maldonado-Ocampo et al. 2008, Urbano-Bonilla et al. 2009). The species is distributed in a range of elevations from 140-660 meters above sea level.

The extent of occurrence (EOO) is best estimated at 50,594 km2, and the area of occupancy (AOO) is best estimated at 1,536 km2.

The geographic attributes for Corydoras axelrodi in this assessment were compiled, arranged and reviewed from the following sources: Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF 2020), FishNet2 (Fishnet2 2020), FishBase (Froese and Pauly 2019), SiB Colombia (SiB Colombia 2020) and SpeciesLink (SpeciesLink 2020), and complemented with records from the databases of the following ichthyological collections from Colombia: CZUT-IC (Colección Zoológica, Universidad del Tolima, Ibagué), IAvH-P (Colección de Peces de Agua Dulce del Instituto de Investigación de Recursos Biológicos Alexander von Humboldt, Villa de Leyva), ICN-MHN (Instituto de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional de Colombia, Bogotá), IMCN (Colección Zoológica de Referencia Científica del Museo de Ciencias Naturales Federico Carlos Lehmann Valencia del INCIVA, Cali), and MPUJ (Museo Javeriano de Historia Natural "Lorenzo Uribe, S.J." de la Pontificia Universidad Javeriana, Bogotá).
useTrade: Corydoras axelrodi is harvested in the ornamental artisanal fishery in Colombia and is subject to regulations for its fishing and commercialization. The actual volume of harvest is unknown. It is reported in landing from ports in the rivers Inírida and Villavicencio, and in this last port about 16,000 individuals of this species were reported between January and December 2013 (Ortega-Lara et al. 2015).
conservationActions: It is included in ornamental fishing regulations (Ortega-Lara et al. 2015) and the range includes conservation sites and protected areas. The species occurs in the Parque Nacional Natural Sierra de la Macarena and DMI Ariari Guayabero (DoNascimiento et al. 2018, IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020). Awareness and communications are recommended, as well as research into trends for the population, habitat, trade and harvest.

rationale: Farlowella colombiensis is placed in the category Vulnerable. The extent of occurrence (EOO) is best estimated at 19,988 km2 and the area of occupancy (AOO) is best estimated at 1,212 km2. There is continuing decline in the habitat inferred based on threats of pollution and water abstraction, relating primarily to agriculture. There are 4-6 locations based on these threats.
habitat: The fishes of genus Farlowella inhabit rivers of plains and low piedmonts, usually in small rivers with moderate currents in heterogeneous substrates mixed with plants (branches, leaves, roots) on the banks, where they find refuge and usually feed on algae (e.g. Bacillariophyceae). Farlowella fishes have moderate fecundity (García-Alzate et al. 2012). Reproduction is believed to occur during the rainy season. This species can reach around 160 mm in standard length.
threats: The habitat of Farlowella colombiensis is facing strong threats: deforestation, sewage, oil spills, sedimentation, and water extraction. Fishing for ornamental purposes is considered an important threat (García-Alzate et al. 2012, Ortega-Lara et al. 2015).
population: Data on population size or trend are not available.
range:
Farlowella colombiensis was described from the Río Upia drainage, Guaicaramo, Meta Department (Retzer and Page 1997). This species is endemic to Colombia and known from upper Guaviare (Guayabero river) and Meta drainages (Retzer and Page 1996, Ballen and Mojica 2014). The records include the piedmont region of the Casanare where it has been recorded from the Upía sub-basin (Urbano-Bonilla et al. 2009). The species has a elevational distribution ranges from 180-600 m above sea level.

The extent of occurrence (EOO) is best estimated at 19,988 km2 and the area of occupancy (AOO) is best estimated at 1,212 km2.

The distribution in this assessment is a summary based on scientific reports and records compiled, arranged and reviewed from the following sources: SiB Colombia (SiB Colombia 2020), Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF 2020), FishNet2 (Fishnet2 2020), and SpeciesLink (SpeciesLink 2020), and complemented with records from the databases of the following ichthyological collections from Colombia: CZUT-IC (Colección Zoológica, Universidad del Tolima, Ibagué), IAvH-P (Colección de Peces de Agua Dulce del Instituto de Investigación de Recursos Biológicos Alexander von Humboldt, Villa de Leyva), ICN-MHN (Instituto de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional de Colombia, Bogotá), IMCN (Colección Zoológica de Referencia Científica del Museo de Ciencias Naturales Federico Carlos Lehmann Valencia del INCIVA, Cali), and MPUJ (Museo Javeriano de Historia Natural "Lorenzo Uribe, S.J." de la Pontificia Universidad Javeriana, Bogotá).
useTrade: Farlowella colombiensis is common as an ornamental fish in Colombia. The species is subject to regulations for its fishing and commercialization (Ortega-Lara et al. 2015). It is reported in various centres in Inírida, Puerto Carreño and Villavicencio, and in this last centre near 141,000 individuals of Farlowella were commercialized in 2013 (Ortega-Lara et al. 2015).
conservationActions: There are known laws and programs around ornamental fishing in Colombia (Ortega-Lara et al. 2015) but no other conservation plans for the species. There are conservations sites and one protected area within the distribution (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020): DMI Ariari-Guayabero. Habitat protection in the most impacted drainages is recommended, as well as regulation and monitoring of the fishery. Research into the taxonomy of group, and monitoring of threats, population and habitats, are recommended.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern because is widely distributed, is common and there are no major threats affecting it, and also it occurs in a couple of protected areas. But this species need surveys to determine exact range, population size, and threats.
habitat: This benthopelagic fish inhabit permanent rivers. The juveniles stages are omnivorous, and adults are carnivorous.
threats: This species could be affected by habitat modification and pollution produced by oil extraction.
population: There are no data on population size and trends for this species, but in Ecuador seem to be common (Barriga, pers. com.).
range: This species occurs in the Napo River of Ecuador (Barriga 2012) and in the Amazon River basin of Colombia (Maldonado-Ocampo et al. 2008). The type locality is the Dedo River, a tributary of the Orteguasa River near Florencia, Caqueta Department, Colombia (Kullander 2003). This species occurs between 200 to 400 m asl.
useTrade: This species has been caught from the wild and successfully bred by aquarists. There are no records of number of specimens being collected from the wild.
conservationActions: This species occurs into the Cuyabeno and Yasuní reserves in Ecuador. There are no direct conservation measures in place for this species.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern because, although the distribution is limited - its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 416 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in an area of extensive, suitable habitat which appears not to be under significant threat.
habitat:
This species is abundant in extremely wet montane forest that surrounds Sawetau Camp at 1,600 m asl. All specimens that were not vocalising were collected from the forest floor at night, usually after rain. In contrast, calling males were all found on elevated perches on mossy logs between 15-50 cm above the ground where they called from semi-exposed positions (Günther et al. 2014). It has been recorded near roads, but has largely been observed in good forest; and its tolerance to habitat disturbance remains uncertain (S. Richards pers. comm. July 2019). Asterophryine microhylid frogs are known to breed by direct development (Melanesia RL Workshop 2019). 

The size of females at maturity is 3.2 cm, and the size of males is 2.8 cm.
threats:
There are no documented threats to this species. The forest in the areas where this species occurs are in good condition, particularly in Muller Range (S. Richards pers. comm. July 2019). There are some development activities in the Southern Highlands (e.g. oil and gas), but they have a low footprint and are unlikely to expand or intensify in the foreseeable future (S. Richards pers. comm. July 2019).

Presently, there are no records of infectious amphibian chytrid fungi (Batrachochytrium spp.) on New Guinea (Bower et al. 2017, 2019). There is a risk that human activities may introduce these fungi to the island. While there is no known significant impact on closely-related microhylids in Australia, there are records of declines caused by chytridiomycosis on direct-developing species in other families. Therefore, should chytrids be detected on New Guinea, this species should be re-assessed as a matter of urgency as it could be at risk of infection and decline (Melanesia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019).
population: This species is common and the population is considered to be stable within the Southern Highlands subpopulations (S. Richards pers. comm. July 2019).
range: This species was formerly only known from Sawetau Camp, Muller Range, Western Province, Papua New Guinea at 1,600 m asl (Günther et al. 2014). It is now also known from several additional sites in Southern Highlands Province, between 1,600-1,700 m asl (S. Richards pers. comm. July 2019). It is likely to occur more widely than is currently known, particularly between documented localities (S. Richards pers. comm. July 2019). Its current known extent of occurrence (EOO) is 416 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
The species is not known from any protected areas, and no conservation measures are in place. 

Conservation Needed
Declines due to the arrival of chytrids are known to be rapid and severe. Therefore, a common analogue species should be identified and the capacity for ex-situ conservation (e.g. captive assurance populations and genome banking) should be developed in country. There is a high risk that the introduction of chytrids could be caused by human activities, “enforcing quarantine measures through policy changes, investing in compliance, promoting education, and minimizing risks, including transportation of infected sources” (Bower et al. 2019) is strongly recommended (Melanesia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019). 

Research Needed
Further research is required on its population status, distribution, and natural history.

rationale:
In view of the small subpopulation sizes estimated to date (Table 1 in the Supplementary Material) it is plausible that there could well be fewer than 10,000 mature individuals, and an assessment of the threatened status of the Australian Humpback Dolphincan be inferred under criterion C. Australian Humpback Dolphins live in small geographically isolated subpopulations connected by limited gene flow. No subpopulation studied to date (Table 1 in the Supplementary Material) is estimated to contain more than 104 mature individuals. Therefore, it is highly likely that the largest subpopulation across their range would be < 1000 mature individuals. Anthropogenic mortality of only 3.7, 4.1 and 5.3 individuals per year from a population of 100 individuals would result in 30%, 50% and 80% declines in population abundance after 3 generations, respectively (see Moore 2015 Table 5).

Given the number of development projects that are underway or proposed throughout a great proportion of the species’ range in Australia (Fig. 2 in the Supplementary Material) a continuing decline in the number of mature individuals is projected. There are indications already of considerable declines in at least some locations along the Queensland coast, which are potentially linked to environmental stressors (Cagnazzi 2013). Habitat degradation and loss is ongoing and expected to increase across the species’ range in Australia (Allen et al. 2012; Bejder et al. 2012; Cagnazzi et al. 2013b). The loss and fragmentation of suitable habitats is one of the primary drivers of population declines for species following a metapopulation structure model such as humpback dolphins (Brown et al. 2014, Cagnazzi 2010, Schnell et al. 2013). Additionally, the species’ range is considered a hotspot of future extinction risk for marine mammals because of cumulative human impacts (Davidson et al. 2012).

Considering the available evidence and following a precautionary approach we considered this species as Vulnerable under IUCN criterion C2a(i) because the total number of mature individuals is plausibly fewer than 10,000, a projected continuing decline due to cumulative impacts; and each of the defined subpopulations studied to date is estimated to contain fewer than 1,000 mature individuals. Although the species may not meet any of the criteria for Endangered at this time, it is likely to do so in the near future considering It is possible that 1) number of mature individuals is less than 2,500, 2) the reductions in population size have been larger and pervasive enough to cause a net reduction for the entire species of at least 20% over a period of 2 generations and 3) that the number of mature individuals in each subpopulation across their range is ≤ 250 individuals.
habitat:
Within their geographical range Australian Humpback Dolphins are found primarily in coastal waters. Opportunistic data collected during aerial surveys designed to estimate the distribution and abundance of Dugongs (Dugong dugon) in the Great Barrier Reef indicated that Australian Humpback Dolphins were sighted on average 6.4 km (se = 1.26, Range 0-55.6 km) from the nearest point of land and 2.7 km (std. err. = 0.27, range = 0-8.1 km) to the nearest shallow area (either point of land or charted reef, less than 2m deep at low tide) (Corkeron et al. 1997). In Queensland and in the Northern Territory humpback dolphins are found mostly within 10 km off the coast (Palmer et al. 2014b, Parra et al. 2004, Parra et al. 2006b). Accordingly, in Keppel Bay, Central Queensland, where up to 10 km offshore waters still remain below 10m in depth, Australian Humpback Dolphins were recorded on average 2.8 km (SD = 4.21, Range = 0-24 km) off the coast. In Western Australia, sightings obtained from recent exploratory surveys and ongoing studies seem to confirm a similar pattern, with the majority of the sightings obtained within 5 km off the coast (Brown and Hunt personal communication). In Papua New Guinea, the first tentative sightings of Australian Humpback Dolphins were made in the Kikori Delta region; close to the coastline and in waters 1.6-11.4 m deep (Beasley et al. 2014).

While coastal waters are arguably the primary habitat of Australian Humpback Dolphins, most survey work has been conducted close to the coast, thus the extent to which humpback dolphins use offshore waters is not yet fully understood. Observations of Australian Humpback Dolphins at least up to 55.6 km from land, indicate that this species may occasionally venture further offshore especially in sheltered and protected waters such as in the Great Barrier Reef where sand flats occur almost continuously from the mainland to the outer reefs (Corkeron et al. 1997).

Along the Australian Coast Humpback Dolphins are more likely to be found in relatively shallow and protected coastal habitats such as inlets, estuaries, shallow bays, inshore reefs and coastal archipelagos rather than in open stretches of coastline. In Queensland and Northern Territory, humpback dolphins are mainly found in water less than 20 km from the nearest river mouth and in water less than 15-20 m deep (Parra et al. 2004). Few animals have been observed in waters up to 30-50 m deep, but remained in close proximity (within 5 km) to the coast (Parra et al. 2004). In both Queensland and Northern Territory humpback dolphins have been also recorded as far as 20-50 km upstream in large rivers such as the East Alligator River, Northern Territory, and in the Fitzroy and Brisbane rivers in Queensland (Cagnazzi 2010, Palmer et al. 2014b, Parra et al. 2004). No studies on habitat use have been conducted in Western Australia. Preliminary surveys and ongoing studies in few locations indicate that Australian Humpback Dolphins appear to utilize a wide range of near-shore habitats. For example, around the North West Cape, dolphins have been sighted in clear waters over Ningaloo Reef, and in turbid waters in Exmouth Gulf, and in depths ranging from 1 to 40 m deep (T. Hunt 2015, pers. comm., 19 February)

Among subpopulations there appear to be some differences in habitat selection suggesting high adaptability of this species to local environment characteristics. For example, in Cleveland Bay Australian Humpback Dolphins showed preferences for waters close to the coast and 2-5 m deep, followed by waters 1-2 m deep whereas in Keppel Bay (~630 Km south) humpback dolphins showed preference for waters 2-5 and 5-10 m deep, while In Port Curtis (~700 km further south) humpback dolphins showed preference for water 5-10 and 10-15 m deep. Within these regions humpback dolphins showed selection for various types of habitats including dredged channels, reefs, seagrass flats and mangroves.

Across Australia, humpback dolphins have been observed feeding in a wide range of inshore-estuarine coastal habitats including rivers and creeks, expose banks, shallow flats, rock and coral reefs as well as over submerged reefs in waters at least up to 40 m deep (Allen et al. 2012, Cagnazzi 2010, Parra 2006, Parra et al. 2006b). The analysis of stomach contents of 6 humpback dolphins stranded in Queensland indicated they are opportunistic-generalist feeders, preying on a wide variety of fishes including both bottom-dwelling species (e.g., grunts, tooth ponyfishes, croakers, flatheads, and whitings) as well as pelagic species (e.g., cardinal fishes, gizzard shads, anchovies, false trevally and barracudas) (Parra and Jedensjö 2014). Among these, Grunt fish (Pomadasys sp.) were the most numerically important prey accounting for more than half (52.9%) of all prey items, followed by the cardinal fish (Apogon sp., 10.4%) and smelt-whiting (Sillago sp., 9.7%) (Parra and Jedensjö 2014)
threats:
Habitat Loss and Degradation
Several regions across Humpback Dolphins’ range in Australia have been substantially modified both inland, to allow mining, agricultural and grazing activities and along the coast to allow industrial ports; marinas, aquaculture and residential developments. Concurrently, several mining industries are undergoing major upgrades and extensions, while new extraction sites have been proposed to meet an increasing export demand of primary resources (carbon, oil, natural gas, woods, aluminium and uranium), particularly in northwestern Australia and along the central coast of Queensland (Fig. 2 in the Supplementary Material) (Allen et al. 2012, Bejder et al. 2012, Queensland Government 2012). As a result significant expansions of existing ports facilities are underway across the coastal range of Australian Humpback Dolphins (Fig. 2 in the Supplementary Material) For example, by 2020 the port capacity along the coast of the Great Barrier Reef World Heritage Area (GBRWHA), Queensland, is expected to triple to support the predicted growth in Queensland’s annual coal production (Grech et al. 2013). The IUCN considered this unprecedented scale of development as a serious threat to biodiversity in the GBRWHA (Douvere and Badman 2012).

Activities associated with coastal zone developments such as land reclamation, dredging, seismic surveys, drilling, blasting, shipping and resource extraction may result in habitat loss and degradation for Australian Humpback Dolphins. For example, it has been estimated that in the Fitzroy River, Queensland, between 14 to 25% of Australian Snubfin Dolphin (Orcaella heinsohni) habitat (which largely overlaps with that of Australian Humpback Dolphins) will be directly modified if a planned industrial port development were to occur (Cagnazzi et al. 2013b). Besides their influence on dolphins’ habitat, these activities have the potential to cause disturbance of humpback dolphins’ normal activities through physical displacement and increasing underwater noise pollution (Dungan et al. 2011, Jefferson et al. 2009, Wang et al. 2014). Dredging involved in the construction, maintenance and expansion of ports is of particular concern as it may potentially displace dolphins from important habitats as a result of changes in fish distribution, increased vessel activities, declining water quality and underwater noise (Pirotta et al. 2013, Todd et al. 2015). Because most ports across the Australian Humpback Dolphins range are located in relatively shallow waters, they all require large volumes of dredging. For example, the Gladstone Western Basin project in Queensland involved the dredging of 22 million cubic meters of soil (Ports Australia 2014).

Additionally habitat loss and fragmentation from coastal zone developments and associated activities can influence the population genetic structure of biological populations through their isolation (Keyghobadi 2007). Given the small densities, strong population genetic structure and limited gene flow found among subpopulations of Australian Humpback Dolphins; loss of genetic variation may reduce the ability of individuals to adapt to a changing environment, cause inbreeding depression, reduce survival and reproduction and increase their probability of extinction (Andrews 2014, Brown et al. 2014, Dixon et al. 2007).

By-catch
Human-related mortality of humpback dolphins in Australian waters is thought to be largely attributable to by-catch in shark nets set for swimmers protection by the Queensland Shark Control Program (QSCP) and in inshore gillnets set across creeks, rivers and shallow estuaries for Barramundi (Lates calcarifer Bloch 1970) and Threadfin Salmon (Polynemus sheridani Macleay 1884) and Eleutheronema tetradactylum Shaw 1804) (Hale 1997, Paterson 1990). There are no estimates of the magnitude of these indirect takes or of their trend over the time.

Fisheries observers on gillnet vessels operating in northern Australian waters between 1981-1985 reported one Australian Humpback Dolphin among the cetacean species incidentally taken (Harwood and Hembree 1987). At least 18 Humpback Dolphins were collected from shark nets along the Queensland coast between 1968-2001 (Haines and Limpus 2002, Heinsohn 1979). Between 1997-2007 a further 13 humpback dolphins were reported caught in the QSCP shark nets and drumlines (Beasley et al. 2012).

Shark nets have now been removed from most of the Queensland coast and captures of dolphins appear to be small at a state level (Gribble et al. 1998). For example, between 2008 and 2011 no humpback dolphin was reported caught in the shark nets, despite QSCP accounting for 73% of all cetaceans mortalities (Meager et al. 2012). However, given the low population sizes at which this species occurs, the death of even a few individuals per year at a local level could have detrimental consequences on the viability of local subpopulations.

Water pollution
Sources of anthropogenic contaminants are likely to increase in the future across northern Australia, as a result of a widespread contamination by several new pesticides (Smith et al. 2012), increasing annual runoff (Chiew and McMahon 2002), and rapid urban and industrial development. As coastal top predators, humpback dolphins may accumulate high concentrations of anthropogenic contaminants through bioaccumulation (Cagnazzi et al. 2013a).

The water discharge by many rivers across the Humpback Dolphin’s range in Australia is of poor quality, often with contaminant concentrations likely to cause environmental harm (Brodie et al. 2012, Francey et al. 2010, Schaffelke et al. 2012). For example an assessment of the relative risk of pollutants from agricultural and land uses ranked most of the rivers in Queensland as relatively high priority (Waterhouse et al. 2012). Agricultural and industrial-sourced pollutants have been identified as the major threats to the coastal water quality especially along the Great Barrier Reef. As a result various contaminants, were detected in sediments samples as well as in several marine species known to be part of the humpback dolphin diet (Jones et al. 2005). Accordingly, a recent study detected high levels of organochlorine compounds (DDTs, PCBs, HCB) and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) in biopsy samples collected from humpback dolphins along the Queensland coast (Cagnazzi et al. 2013a).

Although exposure to contaminants may not directly cause the death of an animal, it may affect the dolphins’ health in numerous ways, including an increased susceptibility to diseases and impairment of metabolic functions (Bossart 2011, De Swart et al. 1996). The immunosuppressive effect of contaminants may play an important role in the death of humpback dolphins following large floods and major industrial coastal developments (DEHP 2012, Smith et al. 2012).

Underwater Noise
Sounds introduced into the marine environment by anthropogenic activities (e.g., dredging, pile-driving, underwater surveying, shipping) may have detrimental effects on marine mammals by interfering with their ability to communicate, echolocate, and/or mask other important natural sounds (Richardson et al. 1995, Nowacek et al. 2007).

For example, impulsive hammering sounds can be loud, and levels as high as 165 dB re 1 mPa were measured 1 km from a hammer used for pipe installation (Bailey et al. 2010). A recent study conducted in the Pearl River Estuary of China, near Hong Kong, to monitor the effects of the world's largest vibration hammer (OCTA-KONG) on Indo-Pacific humpback dolphins has suggested that the vibration zone detectable by individual animal extends beyond 3.5 km. While Indo-Pacific humpback dolphins clicks do not appear to be adversely affected, the whistles were susceptible to auditory masking and a safety zone of 500 m radius was proposed (Wang et al. 2014).

Floods
Peak mortality of inshore dolphins In Queensland, including Australian Humpback Dolphins, followed sustained periods of elevated freshwater discharge (9 months) (Meager and Limpus 2014). In Queensland floods exceed their natural ranges of variation due to inland catchment modifications that result in a large amount of sediments, heavy metals, nutrients and pesticides being discharged into the estuaries and adjacent coastal areas (Brodie et al. 2003, Furnas 2003). Increases in freshwater discharge may also increase exposure to infectious pathogens such as toxoplasmosis; which has been observed and thought to be the cause of death of four Australian Humpback Dolphins (Bowater et al. 2003). Modelling studies estimated that in some areas the annual runoff in catchments across Australia could increase to up to 15% by the year 2030, due to the increased in rainfall associated with global warming (Chiew and McMahon 2002). Thus, the resilience and recovery capacity of the entire coastal ecosystem including humpback dolphins’ preferred habitat may be put under great threat.

Cumulative threats
The cumulative impact of environmental factors and anthropogenic activities is arguably the primary threat to humpback dolphins (Dungan et al. 2011). The continuous alteration of coastal systems have greatly undermined the resilience of many wildlife communities, populations, and species living in estuaries, making them more vulnerable to environmental stochasticity events and anthropogenic stressors (Hobday and Lough 2011). The loss of habitat quantity and quality has been identified among the primary drivers of population declines of marine animals. The reduction of suitable habitat may force local populations of humpback dolphins to adjust to the remaining resources through a reduction in survival rate and population size, or emigration to more suitable areas (Andren 1994, Fahrig 1997, Jefferson 2000). Such effects are likely to be exacerbated when natural systems are simultaneously subjected to multiple stressors as a result of cumulative impacts and negative synergistic interactions (Crain et al. 2008, Halpern et al. 2008, Venter et al. 2006).

Recent studies on other inshore dolphin populations living in highly industrialized regions have reported negative population trends. In the Pearl River estuary, China, modelling of demographic data from strandings of humpback dolphins predicted that the population was declining at about 2.4% per annum (Huang et al. 2012), in the Yangtze River the population of Yangtze Finless Porpoise is declining at a rate of about 6% p.a. (Mei et al. 2012), while in Doubtful Sound, New Zealand, the local isolated bottlenose dolphin population has declined at a rate of about 30% over the last 12 years (Currey et al. 2007). According to this evidence a reduction in the number of Australian Humpback Dolphins could be expected if the impacts of multiple port expansion, development projects, water pollution, vessel traffic and increasing frequency of natural catastrophic events are not properly addressed.
population:
At present, there is no range-wide estimate of the abundance of Australian Humpback Dolphins. Estimates of abundance are available from several discrete locations across Australia (Supplementary Material: Table 1, see Fig. 1 for locations). Additionally, monitoring to estimate abundance is currently underway at several new locations in Western Australia, Northern Territory and Queensland (Table 1 in the Supplementary Material). Overall, available abundance estimates indicate that humpback dolphins occur in small subpopulations averaging 54-89 individuals and 0.1-0.19 individuals per km² (Table 1 in the Supplementary Material).

Proportion of mature individuals
Estimating the global number of “mature individuals” (i.e. individuals known, estimated or inferred to be capable of reproduction) of Australian Humpback Dolphins is challenging, because relevant demographic data are insufficient or non-existent. If we assume that the proportion of mature individuals (Nm) is similar to that estimated for the Indo-Pacific Humpback Dolphin (Sousa chinensis), which is 50% (Taylor et al. 2007), each subpopulation studied to date (Table 1 in the Supplementary Material) numbers <105 mature individuals. Considering that all available abundance estimates for Australian Humpback Dolphins are low (typically less than 150 individuals; Table 1 in the Supplementary Material), the total number of mature individuals across their range is unlikely to exceed 10,000 individuals.

Population Trend
Estimates of population size trends across the species’ range are unknown. Surveys in Cleveland Bay, northeast Queensland, (1999-2002) showed low population sizes (34-54 individuals) and no clear trends, but indicated that even with relatively unbiased and precise abundance estimates population trends will be extremely difficult to detect in less than three years unless changes in population size were greater than 20% p.a. (Parra et al. 2006a). A longer multiyear study (2006-2011) in the Capricorn and Curtis Coast regions, Central Queensland, showed that abundance estimates declined throughout the study in Keppel Bay and Curtis coast region from 115 and 84 individuals in 2007 to 104 and 45 in 2011, respectively (Cagnazzi 2013). The decline in abundance estimates was associated with a large flood event in 2010 and the concurrent expansion of the Port Curtis port facilities (Cagnazzi 2013). Analyses of data collected until 2014 will clarify whether the observed decline is permanent or just a temporary shift in dolphin distribution.

Ongoing monitoring studies (2011-2014) in Bynoe Harbor, Darwin Harbor and Shoal Bay in the Northern Territory, have shown that the numbers of humpback dolphins in these areas are quite small (Table 1 in the Supplementary Material) but have remained fairly stable throughout the years (Brooks and Pollock 2014). Estimates in Port Essington Harbor, Northern Territory, varied widely (48-207) among sampling periods (2008-2010). This variation was likely due to movements in and out of the study area, temporary emigration, temporal changes in behaviour, or temporal changes in detectability (Palmer et al. 2014a).

Australian Humpback Dolphins live in small and localized subpopulations connected by limited gene flow. No subpopulation studied to date (Table 1) is estimated to contain more than 104 mature individuals. Therefore, it is highly likely that the largest subpopulation across their range would be <1,000 mature individuals and that there could well be fewer than 10,000 mature individuals. As with other cetaceans, the low reproductive rates of Australian Humpback Dolphins make them vulnerable to even low rates of anthropogenic mortality. For example, assuming a 3% recruitment rate (as estimated for S. chinensis and S. plumbea in Moore 2015) a discrete subpopulation of 100 individuals would decline by 30%, 50% and 80% over 75 years (three generations) if only 3.7, 4.1 and 5.3 individuals were removed, respectively, per year due to anthropogenic mortality (see Table 5 in Moore 2015).

Given the number of development projects that are underway or proposed throughout a great proportion of the species’ range in Australia (Fig. 2 in the Supplementary Material) a continuing decline in the number of mature individuals is projected. There are indications already of considerable declines in at least some locations along the Queensland coast, which are potentially linked to environmental stressors (Cagnazzi 2013). Habitat degradation and loss is ongoing and expected to increase across the species’ range in Australia (Allen et al. 2012, Bejder et al. 2012, Cagnazzi et al. 2013b). The loss and fragmentation of suitable habitats is one of the primary drivers of population declines for species following a metapopulation structure model such as humpback dolphins (Brown et al. 2014, Cagnazzi 2010, Schnell et al. 2013). Additionally, the species’ range is considered a hotspot of future extinction risk for marine mammals because of cumulative human impacts (Davidson et al. 2012).

Population Structure
Overall, the genetic data available suggest that Australian Humpback Dolphins exist as a metapopulation of small and relatively isolated subpopulations with limited gene flow (Brown et al. 2014, Parra et al. unpub. data). Analysis of population structure using both microsatellite markers and mitochondrial DNA sequence data from humpback dolphins from the Dampier Archipelago, and the North West Cape in north Western Australia (~300 km apart) showed significant levels of population structure with limited gene flow (Brown et al. 2014). Similarly, analysis of population structure among eight sampling locations (from tens to 1,500 kilo meters apart) along the east coast of Queensland indicated significant population differentiation and low levels of migration rates between most sampling locations (Parra et al. unpub. data).

The available evidence on abundance estimates (Table 1 in the Supplementary Material) and population genetic structure indicates Australian Humpback Dolphins live in small, localized populations with limited gene flow. Abundance estimates suggest that there are fewer than 10,000 mature individuals. Additionally, no subpopulation studied to date is larger than 200 mature individuals (Table 2 in the Supplementary Material). Substantial numbers of humpback dolphins have been killed in localized areas along the east coast of Queensland in anti-shark nets set to protect bathers (Heinsohn 1979, Parra et al. 2004) . Humpback dolphins are also known to die in inshore gillnets set across creeks, rivers and shallow estuaries primarily for |Barramundi (Lates calcarifer) and T|hreadfin Salmon (Polynemus sheridani) and Eleutheronema tetradactylum (Anderson 1995, Hale 1997). Given the continuing vulnerability to bycatch in shark nets and gillnets, low densities in surveyed areas, and increased habitat degradation throughout their range (see threats section) it is likely that a continuing decline of at least 10% will occur over a period of 3 generations (about 75 years, assuming generation length is similar to that estimated for S. chinensis in Moore 2015).
range:
Australian Humpback Dolphins are found in tropical/subtropical waters of the Sahul Shelf from northern Australia to the southern waters of the island of New Guinea(Jefferson and Rosenbaum 2014). In Australia humpback dolphins are thought to be widely distributed along the northern Australian coastline from approximately the Queensland-New South Wales border (31°27´S, 152°55´E) to western Shark Bay, Western Australia (25°51´S, E113°20´E). However, no dedicated wide-scale surveys throughout this range have been conducted and at present, this continuous distribution is inferred primarily from localized studies; strandings, museum records and aerial surveys for other species (Allen et al. 2012, Palmer et al. 2014b, Parra et al. 2004). Similarly, the extent of their distribution in the southern waters off the island of New Guinea is also still unclear due to the limited amount of marine mammal survey work carried out in this region. Recent surveys in the Kikori Delta region of Papua New Guinea reported a total of 7 groups of humpback dolphins (Beasley et al. 2014). Photographic records of these animals indicate that they are likely S. sahulensis but genetic studies are needed to solidly clarify which Sousa species occurs off the island of New Guinea. It is also uncertain if the species occurs in the deep waters (~30-90 m depth) over the continental shelf between Australia and Indonesian New Guinea (the Arafura Sea).

Most studies to date indicate that Australian Humpback Dolphins occur mostly close to the coast (within 20 km from land) and in relatively sheltered offshore waters near reefs or islands (Allen et al. 2012, Corkeron et al. 1997, Palmer et al. 2014b, Parra et al. 2004, Parra et al. 2006b). Furthermore, stomach content analyses indicate Australian Humpback Dolphins feed mainly on fishes associated with coastal-estuarine waters (Parra and Jedensjö 2014). As most survey work has been conducted in coastal waters, this apparent coastal distribution and preference for inshore habitats might be biased.

For purposes of this assessment and in line with discussions on the distribution range for S. sahulensis at the IUCN Workshop to Assess/Re-Assess IUCN Red Listings for Indo-Pacific Genera of Coastal Small Cetaceans (San Diego, 20-21 May 2015), we assume Australian Humpback Dolphins occur 1) continuously across northern Australia and southern New Guinea and 2) up to the 30 m isobath (Fig. 1 in the Supplementary Material). Given these assumptions we estimate their geographic range to be approximately 562,193 km² comprised of: ~405,091 km² for Australia (QLD: ~202,344 km², NT: ~98,769 and WA: ~ 103,978 km²) and ~157,102 km² for southern New Guinea. The lack of spatial information on the occurrence of Australian Humpback Dolphins throughout their inferred range precludes an accurate estimation of their extent of occurrence (EOO; i.e. area contained within the shortest continuous imaginary boundary which can be drawn to encompass all the known, inferred or projected sites of present occurrence of a taxon, excluding cases of vagrancy) and area of occupancy (AOO; i.e. area within its 'extent of occurrence' which is occupied by a taxon, excluding cases of vagrancy). Although both EOO and AOO are likely to be significantly less than the geographic range estimated here, the large extent of their potential distribution suggests that their EOO and AOO are very likely to be above 20,000 km².
useTrade: There is no robust evidence of traditional use for consumption or medicinal use across the Australian humpback dolphin’s geographical range. In the 1960-70s live-captures (at least 8 individuals) took place in Queensland, Australia, for oceanarium displays (Parra et al. 2004). A female humpback dolphin wild caught in 1968 and currently held at Sea World (Amity) is estimated to be over 48 years of age. Capture for the purposes of public display is no longer permitted under Australian law.
conservationActions:
As a recently described new species, Australian Humpback Dolphins have not been listed under any national and International listing. Previous conservation assessments as S. chinensis are summarized in Table 2. The most recent assessment of the conservation status of humpback dolphins (as S. chinensis ) in Australia, concluded the species should be listed as Data Deficient (Woinarski et al. 2014).

In 2012 The Australian Federal Government commissioned a comprehensive review of the current knowledge and conservation status of Australian tropical inshore dolphins (Beasley et al. 2012) and a Draft Coordinated Research Strategy to address knowledge gaps and assess their national conservation status (Parra et al. 2012). These reports led to a technical workshop attended by researchers, statisticians and government and indigenous representatives to review the proposed research objectives identified in the draft research strategy, and agree on research priorities that would allow the assessment of the conservation status of Australian inshore dolphins at a national level. The resulting research strategy (DSEWPaC 2013) identified three specific research objectives applicable to Australian snubfin and humpback dolphins: (1) to conduct a broad-scale assessment of their extent of occurrence and area of occupancy (2) to conduct dedicated multi-year studies of their distribution, abundance and habitat use at selected sites across northern Australia with differing levels of threatening processes; and (3) to undertake a spatial and temporal risk assessment of current and projected threatening processes. Sampling and statistical methods to achieve these objectives have been recently described in Brooks et al. (2014). Following these advances, the Australian Federal Government released in 2014 the Whale and Dolphin Protection Plan, which includes a National Dolphin Conservation Plan. This plan aims to guide research and conservation assessment of Australian Humpback Dolphins and snubfin dolphins by supporting research into their ecology and major threats over the next three years.

Multiple-use marine protected areas in Western Australia (e.g. Shark Bay and Ningaloo Reef Marine Park), the Northern Territory (e.g. Garig Gunak Barlu), and Queensland (Great Barrier Reef Marine Park, Dugong Protected Areas; Moreton Bay Marine Park) cover a substantial portion of the known and presumed habitat of Australian Humpback Dolphins in Australian waters and may provide some protection for humpback dolphins. To improve the quality of water discharged into the Great Barrier Reef, in 2008, the Australian Government invested $200 million in The Reef Rescue initiative to help farmers in the Great Barrier Reef catchments to improve farming practices to reduce sediment and nutrient run-off.

In Australia, humpback dolphins have also been identified as a conservation value in Commonwealth waters around Australia in the North, North-west and Temperate East Marine bioregional plans (DSEWPaC 2012a, b, c). These plans were developed under section 176 of the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act) and are aimed at improving management and decision making in relation to Australian marine biodiversity and resources. Biologically Important Areas (i.e. areas where species of conservation value displays important behaviors such as breeding, foraging, resting and migration) for the conservation of humpback dolphins were identified using available information at the time and expert scientific knowledge about species’ distribution, abundance and behavior in these regions.

National Guidelines for Whale and Dolphin Watching and for interaction with seismic explorations provide some protection for inshore dolphins (DOE 2005, 2008). Strategies to reduce the entanglement and death of Australian Humpback Dolphins in nets set by The Queensland Shark Control Program for protection of bathers include the use of acoustic alarms, mixed use of nets and drumlines, overall reduction in the number of nets, and establishment of mammal rescue squads (DPI 2001, Gribble et al. 1998).

rationale: This widely distributed species is not generally abundant. It occurs in muddy bays and estuaries. It may be susceptible to impacts from habitat degradation due to coastal development and pollution, however, this is not considered to be a major threat to the overall population. Therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This demersal species prefers muddy bays and estuaries. It also inhabits freshwater over muddy bottoms near large river mouths (Cervigón 1994). It appears to use estuaries as nurseries and feeding grounds. Its diet is dominated by filamentous algae and detritus (Mata-Cortès et al. 2004). It is the largest goby in the Caribbean (Smith 1997) and reaches maturity at 10 cm SL (Dawson 1969).
threats: Gobioides broussonnetii may be threatened by habitat loss from coastal development and degradation of freshwater and estuarine environments. It is vulnerable to shrimp trawls. Habitat degradation by oil exploration and spills may also be a threat.
population: Gobioides broussonnetii is usually found in small numbers (F. Pezold pers. comm. 2011, Contente et al. 2011), but larger subpopulations appear to exist at least in the Tecolutla Estuary (Veracruz, Mexico) (Mata-Cortès et al. 2004).
range: Gobioides broussonnetii is distributed in the western Atlantic from Charleston, South Carolina south along the U.S. coast, throughout the Gulf of Mexico except along the northern Yucatan Peninsula, Mexico, in the Caribbean from Cuba to Puerto Rico, and along the Central and South American coast from Costa Rica to Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil (Murdy 1998, Reiz-Filho and Oliveira 2014). It has also been collected in Martinique (collection number MNHN A-1373). It is absent from the Cayman Islands, Jamaica, the Bahamas and the islands off Venezuela.
useTrade: Gobioides broussonnetii occurs in the aquarium trade as Dragon Eel.
conservationActions: Gobioides broussonnetii is listed as a Species of Concern in the state of Louisiana, USA. The range of this species includes a number of protected areas (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2019).

rationale: Cyprinodon dearborni is broadly distributed throughout coastal habitats in Venezuela and the islands of Aruba, Bonaire, and Curaçao in the Netherland Antilles. Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 163,122 km2. This species is dominant in coastal habitats throughout Caribbean drainages in Venezuela, and there is currently no indication of major population declines. Therefore, C. dearborni is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Cyprinodon dearborni occupies a range of coastal estuarine habitat, including lagoons, quiet backwaters, and mangrove pools (Pérez et al. 2012, Hylkema et al. 2015). This species is capable of temporary emersion, and can persist in thin films of water for several days when evaporative processes reduce available water in salt marshes and inland lagoons (Turko and Wright 2015). This species can withstand a broad range of salinities, and most often occurs in hypersaline lagoons (Feltkamp and Kristensen 1970). Diet is comprised of detritus, unicellular algae, small macroalgae, zooplankton (Artemia), small crustaceans and bryozoans (Feltkamp and Kristensen 1970, Carmona 1983, Cervigón 1991). Maximum reported body size is approximately 6.1 cm total length (TL) (Cervigón 1991).

Hypersaline estuaries are common on the northern coast of South America, due to their shallow depth (<1 m), rain regime with little rainfall and fresh water inputs, very high sunlight throughout the year, high water temperatures and consequently high evaporation. The salinity of these water bodies can vary between 36 ‰ to more than 60 ‰ in marginal areas of the lagoons, and between 80 ‰ and close to 140 ‰. In areas referred to as “Salinas”, depth can be just a few centimetres (Mago 1965, Kristensen 1970, Kristensen and Hulscher-Emeis 1972, Boer et al 1973, Cervigón and Gómez 1986, Cervigón 1991, Cervigón and Ramírez 2003, 2012).

Cyprinodon dearborni does not occur in freshwater rivers (lotic ecosystems) or freshwater inland lagoons (lentic ecosystems). In a number of studies, this species has been reported from lagoons that vary dramatically in salinity depending on the season. However, it is rarely found at salinities lower than 35 ‰ for any extended periods of time (Hulscher-Emeis 1972, Chung 1997, López et al. 1996, Marín 2000, Toledo et al. 2000, Torcatt 2015).

Females mature at an average size of 2.5 cm and an average age of 86 days (Carmona 1983, Cervigón 1991). Fecundity increases with size, ranging from 87 oocytes in females of 20 to 29 mm TL and 298 oocytes in females greater than 40 mm TL. Embryogenesis is temperature dependent and is completed in three days at 35 ° C and in six days at 26 ° C and is not affected up to a salinity of 51 ‰. There is diurnal territorial behaviour among males, for the defence of a mating and spawning area, as well as parental care by these of the fertilized eggs. The larvae are born with 3.42 and 3.96 mm TL and the yolk sac is reabsorbed five days after hatching and larval development is completed in 44 days at 12.5 mm TL.
threats:
In Venezuela, deforestation rates are exceeding 164,000 hectares annually, primarily resulting from agricultural expansion (Mazón et al. 2017). Coastal pollution including the discharge of heavy metals into coastal waterways is probably negatively impacting aquatic habitat in Laguna de Chacopata, Laguna de Los Patos, and in other regions characterized by urbanization and industrial processes (Toledo et al. 2000). In the Western region, north of Lake Maracaibo and the Gulf of Venezuela, as well as the coasts of the Falcón states, and the central eastern coasts of the Miranda, Anzoátegui, Sucre and Nueva Esparta states (Isla de  Margarita and Coche), oil spills, deforestation (slash and burn) of forests in the headwaters of the basins and mangrove forests, alteration of natural drainages (reservoirs, dredging and canals, dikes, channels, artificial lagoons), erosion and sedimentation, destructive floods, physical modification of Salinas associated with shrimp aquaculture and salt exploitation, contamination by domestic and industrial effluents, use of agrochemicals in upper and middle river basins, extraction of mineral material, and improper disposal of artificial solid waste (domestic and industrial waste) all continue to impact habitat quality (Rodríguez Altamiranda 1999, Conde and Carmona-Suarez 2003, Medina and Barboza 2006, Colonnello and Lasso-Alcalá 2011, Flores 2016, Suarez 2016, Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2018).

The non-native Oreochromis mossambicus was introduced in 1964 in Laguna de los Patos (Sucre state) (Carvajal 1965) and its impact on native species has been well documented, displacing 80% of native species in a decade (Aguilera and Carvajal 1976). Likewise, this species has been recorded in some coastal lagoons on the Isla de Margarita (Lasso-Alcalá et al. 2008). Oreochromis nilotucus has been recorded in peripheral lagoon systems of Lago de Maracaibo, as well as in the Ciénagas de El Gran Eneal and Los Olivitos in the Gulf of Venezuela, though its impact on the native species has not yet been evaluated (González-Bencomo and Borjas 2003, Andrade et al. 2005, Lasso-Alcalá et al. 2008). Eleotris picta is an estuarine piscivore registered in a locality near the Morrocoy National Park and the “Cuare” Wildlife Refuge (Falcón state), where C. dearboni is present (Pezold and Cage 2002).

In the Netherland Antilles, naturally occurring freshwater habitat is vulnerable to human impact, including water extraction, impoundment, channelization, and contamination (Debrot 2003). There is anecdotal evidence suggesting that loss of connection with coastal habitat reduces the success of this species in inland waters due to alterations in food availability (Feltkamp and Kristensen 1970). The economies of Aruba, Bonaire, and Curaçao are driven largely by tourism, and continued coastal development will likely impact the availability and quality of habitat (Nijman et al. 2009).

The Mozambique Tilapia (Oreochromis mossambicus) has established throughout coastal habitats on Aruba, Bonaire, and Curaçao, where it comprises a dominant portion of ichthyofaunal biomass and has apparently reduced the abundance of native species (Debrot 2003, Debrot et al. 2011, Buurt and Debrot 2012). Similarly, the Guppy (Poecilia reticulata) is established on all three islands, where it has been widely introduced as a biological control to mosquito larvae (Debrot 2003). There is a single collection of Xiphophorus helleri reported from Bonaire, but there is currently no evidence to suggest permanent establishment (Hulsman et al. 2008).

Despite inferred continuing decline in habitat quality, there is currently no indication that existing threats have resulted in major declines in population size or range extent.
population: The total population size of this species is unknown. However, it is reported as common to dominant throughout much of the western Caribbean province of Venezuela (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2007, 2011). Population trend is suspected to stable in the absence of major documented declines.
range:
Cyprinodon dearborni is broadly distributed throughout coastal habitats in Venezuela (Esmaeili et al. 2018), and the islands of Aruba, Bonaire, and Curaçao in the Netherland Antilles (Hulsman et al. 2008, Smith et al. 2011). Its reported coastal distribution extends from the Guajira Peninsula in eastern Colombia eastward to Isla de Margarita, Venezuela (Haney et al. 2009). The type locality of this species is Willemstad, Curaçao (Esmaeili et al. 2018). Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 163,122 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around georeferenced collection records.

In Colombia, this species is reported by de Beaufort (1940) from a single collection locality on the Península de la Guajira (station 114; 11.710, -72.664).

In western Venezuela, this species occurs in coastal lagoons of Pájaro (Goajira Península), Laguna Borrachón, Salina Rica, Salina Santa Rosa, Laguna Las Peonías, adjacent to Lago de Maracaibo, (Zulia State), and Tucacas salt flats, near the current Morrocoy National Park (Falcón State) and different lagoons and Salinas adjacent to Puerto Cabello (Carabobo state) (Beaufort 1940, Schultz 1949, Andrade 1984, Moscó and Viloria 2000). In the Gulf of Venezuela, it has been recorded from Laguna de Carapátida, the hypersaline lagoons of Sauca and Punta Caimán (Golfete de Coro), the Paraguaná Peninsula, and in the lagoon system of the “Cuare” Wildlife Refuge in the State of Falcón (Schultz 1949, Valdéz and Aguilera 1987, López et al. 1996, Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2015).

In the Netherlands Antilles, this species is known from Willemstad Bay, Curaçao, and from numerous coastal lagoons, salt flats and closed bays of Aruba, Curaçao (María Pompuna, Saint Joris Bay, Zaquito), Bonaire (Pos Francés and Pos Lansberg, Salinas Plenchi, Oranje Pan, Pekelmer, Goto, Slagbaai, Bartool, Cay) and Klein Bonaire (Salina klein Bonaire) (Meek 1909, Metzelaar 1919, Beaufort 1940, Hummelinck 1940, de Boer et al. 1973).

In the eastern region of the coasts and islands of Venezuela, this species has been collected from numerous hypersaline littoral lagoons on Isla de Margarita (Laguna de La Restinga, Punta de Mangle, Punta de Piedras Los Portillos, Boca de Palo) and Isla de Coche (salinas) (Cervigón 1966, 1991, Cardona 1983, Cervigón and Gómez 1986, Ramírez Villarroel 1994a, 1994b, Nirchio 1996, González and Nirchio 1997, Cervigón and Ramírez 2003, 2012,)  and in lagoons of the Archipiélago de Los Roques (Laguna del Gran Roque, Cayo Sal) (Martín Salazar 1956, Cervigón and Ramírez 2003, 2012). Likewise, it is widespread throughout coastal lagoons to the northwest of Barcelona (Anzoategui State) (Schultz 1949), Salinas to the West of Cumaná (Laguna de Los Patos: Sucre State), in areas near the sea of Laguna de Unare (Anzoategui State) (Mago 1965, Marín 2000), in Laguna de Los Patos (Chung 1997, Toledo et al. 2000, Alfonsi et al. 2003) and in the Laguna de Bocaripo (Chacopata and Pérez et al. 2012).

According to the databases of the national museums of Venezuela (Museo de Historia Natural La Salle: MHNLS, Museo Oceanológco Benigno Román: MOBR, Museo de Ciencias Naturales de Guanare: MCNG, Museo de Biología Universidad Central de Venezuela: MBUCV and Museo de la Estación Biológica de Rancho Grande: EBRG, Colección Regional de Peces, Universidad Centrocidental Lisandro Alvarado: CP-UCLA), this species has 70 records in coastal marine lagoons or coastal lagoons hypersaline in the Isla de Margarita, Coche, Archipiélago de Los Roques, and continental coasts of the Zulia, Falcón, Miranda, Anzoátegui and Sucre states.

The presence of Cypinodon dearborni in Trinidad and Guyana, as suggested by Wildekamp (1995) and Haney et al. (2009), is unlikely, given high rainfall in the region that is not conducive to the development of hypersaline estuaries where this species lives. Additionally, in the most recent and complete listings for that region (Ramjohn 1999, Lasso et al. 2009, 2010, Vari et al. 2009, Phillip et al. 2013, Lemopoulos and Covain 2018), Cyprinodon dearborni has not been recorded.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions:
In Venezuela, some 400 areas have been decreed under the Special Administration Regime Areas, among which 98 protected areas stand out, such as two biosphere reserves, 43 national parks and 36 natural monuments, seven refuges and a fauna sanctuary (Flores 2016). However, only 32 have management plans and use regulations, and none have defined management programs (Flores and Aponte 2016). Therefore, their effectiveness is highly speculative. Some have suggested the need for modification and expansion of existing protected area networks to improve their effectiveness for aquatic conservation (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2011).

The range of this species extends into a number of these coastal protected areas (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020), including Médanos de Coro and Morrocoy National Parks (Falcón State), Archipiélago de Los Roques (Francisco de Miranda State), Laguna de Tacarigua (Miranda State), Laguna de La Restinga (Margarita Island, Nueva Esparta State), and Laguna Las Marites Natural Monuments (Margarita Island, Nueva Esparta State), Ciénaga de Los Olivitos (Zulia State), and Cuare (Falcón State) Wildlife Refuges, Hueque-Sauca, Tucurere (Falcón State) and Ciénaga de La Palmita and Isla de Pájaros (Zulia State) Wildlife Reserves, and Cabos, Puntas, Islands and Lagoons of Isla de Margarita (Nueva Esparta State) and Playa Norte (Falcón State) Protected Zones.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its fairly wide distribution, there are no major threats and because the population is unlikely to be substantially declining.
habitat: This species occurs on red sand/loamy soils and sand dunes, as well as low-lying spinifex and Acacia shrubs (Doughty et al. 2012). Also found on pale coastal dunes (S. Wilson pers. comm. 2017).
threats: Land clearing may pose a potential threat to the species but is not a major concern due to the large distribution. The has been clearing of approximately 1000 hectares of area in which Diporiphora adductus occurs for the Chevron-operated Wheatstone LNG project (Thompson and Thompson 2015). There is no information regarding other threats to the species and as such further research into population trends and the biology of the species is needed.
population: They can be common (S. Wilson pers. comm. 2017). The populations seems to be stable in general.
range: This species is restricted to the northern section of the Carnarvon Basin in Western Australia (Doughty et al. 2012).
useTrade: There is no use or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no current conservation measures for Diporiphora adductus. This species is known to occur in conservation reserves (Atlas of Living Australia 2015).

rationale: This species is listed as Data Deficient, because it occurs as a severely fragmented population, and there is a continuing decline in the area of the very limited gilgais habitat to which the species is restricted, and while it has an extensive distribution range it has an area of occupancy at most below 6,000 km<sup>2</sup> and the high degree of uncertainty surrounding this value suggests that the species could either have an area of occupancy below 2,000 km<sup>2</sup> (and possibly below 500 km<sup>2</sup>), and so warrant listing in a threatened category or as either Near Threatened or Least Concern. It has not been possible to quantify rates of habitat - and presumed attendant population decline over the past 10 years, or to project rates of decline into the future, however, these too are associated with a high degree of uncertainty and may approach or exceed the threshold for listing in a threatened category.
habitat: This species favours low-lying 'gilgai' (ephemeral wetland) areas with cracking clay soil; habitat mapping indicates that the maximum available area of this habitat within the snake's range is around 11,000 km2, although due to finer-scale heterogeneity than the map resolution allows the maximum area of occupancy is probably less than 50% of this area (M. Venz pers. comm. 2017). This is a nocturnal snake species that shelters in soil cracks and sometimes under fallen timber and ground litter during the day. It is viviparous with 3 to 11 young per litter (an average of 6-8). It is an ambush predator that mainly feeds on frogs (Litoria spp., Platypectrum spp.) but has rarely also been documented taking lizards (agamids, gekkonids, scincids) (Shine 1983, Reed and Shine 2002, Cogger 2014).
threats: Changes to soil structure within this species' habitat is a significant threat to subpopulations. This habitat has been very heavily impacted through conversion to agricultural use for crops (sorghum, sunflower, cotton, etc.) that need ploughing. Coal and gas extraction, though both direct impacts on water quality (S. Wilson pers. comm. 2017) and associated habitat loss, is a significant threat within the species' range. Potential threats include water extraction, with the consequent drying of gilgais, and contamination either through chemical spills into the gilgais or diffusion of polluted water into these wetlands (S. Wilson pers. comm. 2017). The majority of the population is found within an "intense resoutce extraction footprint" (S. Wilson pers. comm. 2017), and there are plans to further intensify this activity. It has not been possible to quantify rates of habitat decline resulting from agricultural intensification over the past 10 years on the basis of available data, but it is known to be ongoing and will continue into the future (M. Venz pers. comm. 2017). This is a specialist feeder on amphibians (which may be highly sensitive to water pollution) and consequently these impacts may both directly reduce habitat quality for the snake and potentially reduce prey availability (S. Wilson pers. comm. 2017).
population: Although the species is typically hard to detect, it can be fairly common within the limited extent of suitable habitat within its range. It occurs in pockets of high density, but its abundance is strongly tied to gilgai habitats and densities exhibit a "sharply delineated" drop off away from these waterbodies (Wilson and Swan 2014, S. Wilson pers. comm. 2017). The population is expected to be declining in response to habitat degradation and loss, and the species is thought to occur as a severely fragmented population due to the fragmentary nature of its habitat and its inability to disperse between sites. More than half of the population lies within an area of intense resource extraction, and even relatively moderate disturbance to the species' habitat, such as a spillage of contaminated water, may render individual subpopulations unviable (S. Wilson pers. comm. 2017).
range: This species is found in central-eastern Queensland (Cogger 2014), from around Taroom in the south, north to Charters Towers.
useTrade: The species does not really appear in trade.
conservationActions: Under the the federal Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999, this species is listed as 'Vulnerable'. This species occurs in a limited number of protected areas including Dipperu National Park, Queenland. Gilgai habitat conservation is the lead conservation measure needed, as this is a specialized habitat which is limited in extent within this snake's range, and on which subpopulations are largely reliant.

rationale: This species is widely distributed in the Caribbean. It occurs in shallow coastal waters and estuaries over soft bottoms. It occurs as bycatch in shrimp trawl fisheries, however, this is not considered a major threat. Therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species occurs over sandy mud bottoms in coastal waters and commonly inhabits river estuaries and at the edge of reefs. Its diet includes small crustaceans. The maximum recorded length is 20 cm total length (Chao 2002).
threats: There are no known major threats. Its occurrence as bycatch (though uncommon) may be a potential threat, especially for mature individuals. Off eastern Venezuela, developing offshore oil and gas extractive activities on the continental shelf may also be considered a potential threat. Short-term research on the possible impacts of these activities on this species is highly recommended. In Santa Marta (Colombia), a dynamite fishery directed to snapper and groupers affects a large number of other species, including Stellifer colonensis (O. Aguilera pers. comm. 2009).
population: This species is abundant in parts of its range (Torruco et al. 2018).
range: This species is distributed in the western Atlantic in the Caribbean Sea from Haiti in the Gulf of Gonave, Puerto Rico, southern Belize, and from Costa Rica to Isla de Margarita off Venezuela. Its depth range is 0-25 m (Cervigón 1993, Chao 2002, R. Robertson pers. comm. 2014). Records from Veracruz, Mexico are not likely to be valid (Castro-Aguirre et al. 1999). The depth range is 0-25 m.
useTrade: There is no directed fishery for this species, but it commonly occurs as bycatch in coastal bottom trawls, and occasionally in seines.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place. Bottom trawling has been banned off Venezuela since 2008.

rationale: This species is widely distributed and occurs in shallow coastal waters and estuaries over soft bottom. It occurs as bycatch in shrimp trawl fisheries, however, this is not considered a major threat. Therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species occurs over sandy-mud bottoms in coastal waters and estuaries. It feeds on benthic invertebrates. The maximum recorded length is 25 cm total length (Chao 2002).
threats: There are no known major threats. Its occurrence as bycatch (though uncommon) may be a potential threat, especially for mature individuals. Off eastern Venezuela, developing offshore oil and gas extraction activities on the continental shelf may also be a potential threat. Short-term research on the possible impacts of these activities on this species is highly recommended. In Santa Marta (Colombia), a dynamite fishery directed to snapper and groupers affects a large number of other species, including Stellifer colonensis (O. Aguilera pers. comm. 2009).
population: Population data are not available for this species.
range: The species is distributed in the western Atlantic along Central and South America from Laguna de Caratasca, Honduras to the Orinoco River mouth, Venezuela (Cervigón 1993, R. Robertson pers. comm. 2014). The depth range is 0-30 m.
useTrade: There is no directed fishery for this species, but it occurs as bycatch in bottom trawls. Larger specimens may be found in local fish markets.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place. Bottom trawling has been banned off Venezuela since 2008.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it occurs in XX threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 10,947 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in five to seven threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the quality of its Yungas forest habitat throughout its range.
habitat: This is a ground dwelling, leaf litter species which can be found under thick and wet understories of subtropical Yungas Andean forests (Pereyra et al. 2014). It mainly inhabits primary forest, but is frequent in secondary forest with some degree of vertical structure (M.S. Akmentins pers. comm. May 2018). It is not likely to be tolerant of anthropogenic habitat disturbance. This species occurs in sympatry with Oreobates barituensis throughout most of its geographic range (M.S. Akmentins pers. comm. September 2017). Males call at dusk and night from forest floor, exhibiting territorial behavior and defending their calling sites against conspecific males (Akmentins et al. 2011, 2015). Reproduction is by direct development and egg clutches are laid under rocks and fallen trunks (Vaira 2002; M.S. Akmentins pers. comm. September 2017).
threats: Yungas Andean forests face serious conservation threats, such as selective logging of valuable woody species; clear cutting of primary forest and forestation with exotic species; extensive cattle raising; oil investigation and exploitation; and development of civilian engineering projects (Lavilla and Heatwole 2010). The recent increasing interest in developing bio-ethanol industries will result in the clear cutting of large areas of forest for extensive sugar cane crops (M.S. Akmentins pers. comm. September 2017).
population: It is locally abundant where it occurs, however subpopulations are patchily distributed throughout its range (M.S. Akmentins pers. comm. September 2017). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is endemic to the northern portion of the Yungas Andean forest ecoregion of northwestern Argentina, and is known from Salta and Jujuy Provinces (Pereyra et al. 2014, Ferro et al. 2016). All geographical localities lie between 1,100 and 2,700 m asl. Its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 10,947 km2 and all individuals occur at five to seven threat defined-locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species has been recorded at Baritú National Park and Nogalar de los Toldos National Reserve in Salta province (Ferro et al. 2016; M.S. Akmentins pers. comm. September 2017), and in Calilegua National Park and Serranias de Zapla Provincial Reserves in Jujuy province (M.S. Akmentins pers. comm. September 2017).

Conservation Needed
Given threats occurring throughout the Yungas ecosystem and outside of these protected areas, additional habitat protection is recommended.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' taxonomy, distribution, population status, and natural history.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
habitat: This species inhabits in primary and secondary lowland evergreen forest. Individuals have been found active at night on leaves of low vegetation, up to 3 m above ground. It is suspected that is an inhabitant of forest canopy. It is presumed to breed by direct development.
threats: The Peruvian record is within an oil concession which could represent a threat to that subpopulation (Ortega-Andrade et al. 2015, O. Rojas Padilla pers. comm. May 2018). Otherwise there are no known major threats at this time.
population: The species is known from the 24 specimens that comprise the type series: nine males, six females, four sub-adults, and five juveniles (Ortega-Andrade et al. 2015). There is little additional information available on the population size and trends of this species.
range: This species is known from northern Ecuador (Napo and Orellana provinces) and one locality from Loreto Department in Peru (Ortega-Andrade et al. 2015). It occurs at elevations ranging from 150–400 m asl. It is expected to occur in adjacent Colombia and possibly in Brazil based on ecological niche models (Ortega-Andrade et al. 2015). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 27,459 km2, but a wider distribution is likely, up to 147,787 km2 in the upper Amazon Basin (Ortega-Andrade et al. 2015).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs within Jatun Sacha Biological Reserve and Yasuní National Park in Ecuador. It has not been recorded from any protected areas in Peru, though it may occur in Pucacuro National Reserve. It is considered to be Least Concern in Ecuador.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population and tolerance of a degree of habitat disturbance.
habitat: This diurnal species has been collected in lowland tropical rainforest, and 'rolling hills' where it can be found in leaf-litter. It is a secretive species that is found mainly in primary forest and less frequently in secondary or regenerating forest. In Ecuador, it has been found in secondary forest and vegetation along streams in agricultural areas (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. September 2017). Males have been heard calling concealed above the leaf-litter and from boulder crevices. Eggs are laid in leaf-litter and the larvae are carried to streams (Jungfer 1989, Almendáriz 1991, Lötters et al. 2007).
threats: There is localised habitat loss due to deforestation for agriculture and livestock and the pollution of water sources from livestock, agriculture and mining. Roads for oil exploration and production have become a major factor in agricultural expansion, deforestation and colonization in the Ecuadorian Amazon. The Yachana Reserve is surrounded by large areas of pastureland, small active cacao farms and forest.
population: It is a locally abundant species. In Ecuador, it is considered to be common (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. September 2017). In February 2004, surveys along an 8-km transect recorded c. 2.6 individuals/day for 10 consecutive days near the Río Arajuno in Napo Province, Ecuador (Darst and Cummings 2006). During April 2009–December 2010, 5.50 frogs per 70 trapping days (n=44) were encountered in pitfall traps in primary forest and 0.5 frogs per 70 trapping days (n=2) were found in regenerating plantations, throughout Yachana Reserve, Ecuador (Beirne et al. 2013). Visual survey transects during the same study detected 0.24 frogs per 450 m2 in primary forest (n=12), whereas no individuals were found along transects in regenerating plantations or abandoned pastureland (Beirne et al. 2013). In Peru (Province of Datem del Marañón, Loreto), 27 and 29 frogs were detected during wet season (February–March, 2009) and dry season (June–July, 2009) surveys, respectively (Valqui Schult 2015).
range: This species is known from the Napo and Pastaza drainages of Ecuador, east of the Andes, extending to the Region of Loreto, northern Peru. Its altitudinal range is 200–1,000 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It has been recorded from Yasuní National Park, Sangay National Park, Yachana Reserve, and Jatun Sacha Biological Station in Ecuador, however it is not known from any protected areas in Peru. This species is listed on Appendix II of CITES.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of 279 km2, it occurs in two threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in the Apurimac River valley in Peru.
