It is possible that it has been extirpated from Angola, and from much of the area south of the Kasai River.
useTrade: Illegally hunted for local consumption
conservationActions:
This species is listed on Appendix II of CITES and as Class B of the African Convention. It is on the partially protected species list in DRC (Enerunga 2006). In Angola, all monkeys have been officially protected by Presidential Decree since 2005.

It is present in Salonga National Park (which is probably its main stronghold), Lomami National Park, where it is protected by wildlife guards (Hart et al. 2012), and has been recorded in Sankuru Natural Reserve (in very low numbers). It is also found in Lomako-Yokokala Wildlife Reserve (Lushimba 2012). In the west of their range, they still occur in the Tumba-Ledima Natural Reserve (Beudels-Jamar et al. 2015, Petre and Haggis 2017).

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable, Cercopithecus hamlyni has undergone past reductions and continues to decline due to hunting and, increasingly, to habitat loss and fragmentation. The primary drivers of these threats—human population growth and the expansion of artisanal mining—are likely to increase into the foreseeable future. Most of the species’ range is in a region of endemic and ongoing human conflict, which has exacerbated known threats, and weakened organised efforts to protect these primates. It is suspected that the population decline of C. hamlyni will continue, resulting in an overall population reduction of more than 30% over a 30-year time frame from 2003 to 2033 (given a 10-year generation length). The taxon thus meets the Vulnerable threshold for criterion A4cd.
habitat:
A predominantly terrestrial species recorded from lowland to mid-montane tropical moist forest and montane bamboo forest. In the lowland forest zone (450–1,000 m), which comprises the major portion of the range, C. hamlyni occurs mainly in primary forest areas. The species occupies older secondary forest in the Okapi Wildlife Reserve, but does not favour young secondary forests, and is not known to occur in gallery forests in savannas at the southern limit of its range (Hart et al. 2013). The isolated forest blocks south of the species’ contiguous EOO, where C. hamlyni have been recorded historically, range in size from 200–450 km² and are located on small chains of hills. There is no evidence that these blocks were isolated due to historic human activities, and they may represent relictual range areas, isolated by climate-induced habitat change during the Quaternary or Holocene. In any case, they suggest that isolated populations of C. hamlyni may be able to persist even in a fragmented landscape. Further investigation of the current status of these populations, and exploration of other isolated forest massifs in this region for presence of the species is urgently needed.

Mean group size in the Kahuzi-Biega lowlands and Ituri Forest is 2–3 animals (Hall et al. 2002-2003), In Nyungwe National Park group size averaged 3.6 animals (Easton et al. 2011). These estimates are based on sightings of animals from line transects. However, given the difficulties of directly observing these monkeys, this may be an underestimate of group size. The species feeds primarily on the ground. Diet is poorly documented but known to include fruits and seeds. In the Ituri Forest (elevation 700–750 m) C. hamlyni forages opportunistically on sprouting seedlings when Gilbertiondendron dewevrei undergoes mast fruiting. Fungi and herbaceous vegetation are eaten during periods of fruit scarcity (Hart et al. 2013). The Nyungwe population feeds extensively on bamboo shoots, and this is likely to be the case in other montane locations such as Kahuzi-Biega and Mt. Tshiaberimu, where the species occurs in the bamboo zones. Given the range of habitats occupied, C. hamlyni appears to have a wide dietary tolerance with specialization based on local and seasonal food availability.

Leopards and crowned eagles are known to prey on C. hamlyni in the Ituri Forest; nonetheless, the species was recorded at a low frequency in one study of leopard diets (Hart et al. 1996).
threats:
This species is threatened by habitat loss and poaching. Habitat loss and degradation, due primarily to deforestation by shifting cultivators and small holder farmers, is the most significant threat at present and is growing rapidly. Forest loss in DRC increased by a factor of 2.5 between 2011 and 2017 (Harris et al. 2017). Forest loss and associated degradation have been particularly intense in the eastern and southern portions of C. hamlyni’s range. The impact is most severe in the submontane and montane portions of the range, where human population densities are highest.

Factors promoting habitat loss include rural population growth and expansion of artisanal mining. These will continue to prevail into the foreseeable future. Within the range of C. hamlyni, high rates of forest loss are particularly evident around growing settlements of Beni, Kalima, Kindu, Kisangani, Lubutu, Mambasa, Opienge and Punia. Deforestation and forest degradation are expanding along networks of abandoned roads emanating from these centres, leading to fragmentation of previously intact forest blocks. East of Kisangani, and in the peripheries of Kahuzi-Biega and Maiko national parks, large roadless forest blocks have been invaded by artisanal miners leading to new clearings in remote areas. A recent deforestation hotspot analysis (Harris et al. 2017) indicates that about 40% of C. hamlyni range has been affected by moderate to severe forest loss and degradation. Vast areas of newly-emerging deforestation hot spots intersect with intact primary forests and extend into several protected areas (Harris et al. 2017).

For the past two decades, eastern DRC has been the theatre of entrenched conflict promulgated by a multiplicity of rural militia, a number of whom are based in national parks. The militia attack and loot villages, and exploit artisanal mining or are involved in it themselves. The conflict has led to large movements of internally displaced people (IDPs) and has contributed to the opening of new settlements and expansion of existing settlements. In 2017, over 850,00 unsettled IDPs were registered in administrative territories within the geographic range of C. hamlyni (UNOCHA 2018).

Expanding settlement and artisanal mining are associated with increased hunting and poaching. Cercopithecus hamlyni is shy and difficult to detect. Although this species is not a frequent target of hunters, its terrestrial habits make it vulnerable to snares set for other species. A recent survey of bushmeat market vendors in Kalima, a mining centre in the southern portion of its range, revealed only one fresh C. hamlyni carcass among 38 primates (dried and fresh) on sale. According to vendors interviewed, as recently as five years ago, they could expect to offer 3–5 fresh C. hamlyni per day. Four hunters in three villages to the south and west of Kalima, bordering the region’s remaining forest areas, stated that snare captures of C. hamlyni have been declining for the past 15 years, and are now uncommon. (J. Hart unpublished data 2018).
population: Cercopithecus hamlyni is widespread and variably abundant. Important populations have been documented in the lowland sector of Kahuzi-Biega National Park, with densities of 5-7 individuals per km² (Hall et al. 2002-2003) and the species persists throughout this park (Kujirakwinja et al. 2015; Spira et al. 2015a, 2015b, 2017). Populations surveyed at montane sites at the species’ altitudinal limit appear to be small. In Nyungwe Nation al Park, encounter rates averaged 0.08 groups/km (Easton et al. 2011). Cercopithecus hamlyni is a cryptic and quiet species, which is difficult to census and characteristically moves away from observers before detection, therefore population estimates based on visual contact probably underestimate population sizes. Surveys at dawn in the Okapi Wildlife Reserve of “booming” male vocalisations suggest that C. hamlyni is locally common, and that this is a stronghold for the species (J. Hart, unpublished data 2012). Methods appropriate for estimating C. hamlyni population size, such as camera trap surveys, show promise (Easton et al. 2011), but have not yet been conducted.
range:
The range of Cercopithecus hamlyni resembles that of Allochrocebus lhoesti, with a continuous EOO from the Congo/Lualaba River in the west, through the forested basins of the Lindi, Ituri, Maiko, Lowa, Ulindi and Elila rivers in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), where the bulk of the range falls, into the submontane and montane forests of the Albertine Rift, where a small portion of the range is located. The range is bounded in the north by the Lindi-Nepoko river system and in the south by the southern limit of tropical moist forest (about 4° S). The only known population outside DRC occurs in an area of about 32 km² in Rwanda's Nyungwe National Park (Easton et al. 2011). A second Rwandan population in Gishwati is now likely extirpated due to habitat loss (Hart et al. 2013). Historically, populations of C. hamlyni have been reported from several small, isolated forest blocks, south to nearly 6° S (Hart et al. 2013); however, its current status in these areas is unknown. The eastern-most highland populations of C. hamlyni are now isolated in fragmented habitat islands, some of which have been recently extirpated, such as the forest islands between Kahuzi-Biega National Park and Masisi. The species has not been reported from areas of Burundi adjoining the Nyungwe population and its possible former occurrence in Uganda is not supported by museum specimens.

We estimate that the species’ elevational range extends from 450 m, where C. hamlyni has recently been recorded east of Kindu, 40 km from the Congo/Lualaba River (Hart pers. obs. 2018), to 3,200 m on Mt. Kahuzi and Mt. Tshiaberimu (Hart et al. 2013).
useTrade: Owl-faced Monkey meat is eaten, but the contribution of this species to total bushmeat sale volume is low (J. Hart unpublished data 2018). Commerce of C. hamlyni meat is illegal (Enerunga 2006).
conservationActions:
Cercopithecus hamlyni is listed on Appendix II of CITES and is included among DRC’s nationally protected species (Enerunga 2006); however, this law is largely unenforced outside protected areas. Given current trends in habitat loss, the single most important intervention for the in situ conservation of this species is guard patrols in national parks and other protected areas.

Owl-faced Monkeys occur in several protected areas with large blocks of intact habitat, including: Kahuzi-Biega and Maiko national parks, the Itombwe Massif Nature Reserve, the Okapi Wildlife Reserve and the Tayna Reserve. A large area in the Ituri Forest (Mai Tatu Forest) also harbours this monkey (Wildlife Conservation Society, unpublished data 2008, 2014), as does a small isolated forest block (North Balala) to the southeast of Itombwe (Wildlife Conservation Society, unpublished data 2014). It is found in small numbers at two sites in in Virunga National Park: Watalinga Forest in the north and Mt Tshiaberimu – a remnant patch of formerly contiguous habitat now covering only 75 km². Both of these populations, as well as the population in the upland sector of Kahuzi-Biega National Park, are isolated from other populations. The small population in Rwanda's Nyungwe National Park is also isolated. Additional research on population numbers and distribution is required, so as to better focus conservation efforts.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern, despite increasing hunting and persecution of this taxon. Cercopithecus agilis usually occurs at low density and a significant population decrease is suspected; however, data needed to quantify the threats and any resulting declines are lacking.
habitat:
In the west of its range, this species is generally found in riparian or periodically-flooded swamp forest (Gautier-Hion and Brugière 2005). In Odzala-Kokoua National Park in Congo, they use seasonally-inundated and riverine habitats and occasionally the Marantaceae-dominated terra firma forests (Maisels 1995, 1996). In the area east of Makokou in Gabon, they were found in riverine forests (Quris 1975). By contrast, a study group at Mondika in CAR spent most of its time in terra firma mixed forest, and was never observed along the Mondika River, nor in swamp forest along the Ndoki River (Shah 2003), whereas a group at Bai Hokou, also in CAR, spent some time along rivers and streams (N. Shah pers. obs. 2003). Cercocebus agilis also uses open-understorey Gilbertiodendron dewevrei dominated forest (Shah 2003, Devreese 2011). In the north of its range, the species will use the gallery forests in savanna-forest mosaics of northern CAR (Fay 1988), and in the east (e.g., Okapi Wildlife Reserve), it uses terra firma forests, but will sometimes forage on crops (Kambale Saambere 1999). These monkeys are usually active in lower strata (0–10 m) of the habitat (Quris 1975, Shah 2003), although they spend less time on the ground than other Cercocebus spp. (Shah 2003). Home-range size was estimated to be ca 3 km² in Dzanga-Sangha in CAR (Shah 2003), and 2 km² in Gabon (Quris 1975).

Agile Mangabeys have strong dietary preferences for fruit, seeds and monocotyledon shoots, and can bite through the hard shells of some fruits, such as Strychnos (Shah 2003). They also prey on animals up to the size of infant Peters’ Duikers (Knights et al. 2008, Shah 2013).

In CAR, mean group size was 21 at Mondika, but a habituated group at nearby Bai Hokou numbered 135 animals, and on occasion it reached 330 individuals (Devreese et al. 2013). In northeastern Gabon, group size ranged between 8 and 18 (Quris 1975). In Odzala-Kokoua National Park (Congo), group size was usually >20 (Maisels 1996). In Ituri (DRC), it was 24 (Kambale Saambili 1999), in Ngotto Forest (CAR) it was 20 (D. Brugière, pers. comm. 2013). Groups of 50–200 have been observed in southeast Cameroon (Usongo and Fimbel 1995), northeast Gabon (Quris 1975) and northeast DRC (Kambale Saambili 1999).
threats:
Cercocebus agilis is hunted throughout its range for bushmeat and sometimes persecuted for crop raiding. Because these monkeys spend a fair proportion of time on the ground, they are vulnerable to snaring – a method of hunting used throughout its geographic range. Snares are usually set for forest antelopes and rodents, but can catch any terrestrial animal.

At the western, northern and eastern edges of its range, this species is threatened by habitat loss caused by deforestation for timber and firewood. An analysis of forest loss suggests that 1.3% of the forest in its range was lost between 2001 and 2016 (13,368 km² of the 1 million km² range). However, because this taxon occurs primarily along rivers, this may be an underestimate of the true loss of habitat, as forest loss in the savanna-forest mosaic will be concentrated along rivers and galleries.
population:
Few data exist on abundance relative to human pressure, but even in 1996, in the more westerly part of its range (Lobéké NP, Cameroon), the abundance of C. agilis was an order of magnitude lower than the smaller-bodied, sympatric guenons at that site, and it was recorded only at distances of over 20 km from a road (an indicator of high hunting pressure), whereas smaller-bodied primate species still occurred close to the road (WCS unpublished data 1996). In the most easterly part of its range, in the Okapi Wildlife Reserve, encounter rates on surveys declined by an order of magnitude (WCS unpublished data 2018) over the last decade. This is attributed to increased hunting pressure, due to easier access along a much-improved main road, to the influx of large numbers of people into the area for artisanal mining, and to ongoing civil unrest in eastern DRC.

Densities of Agile Mangabeys appear to be highly variable, presumably influenced by both habitat type and hunting pressure. Population density in Gabon has been recorded at between 6.7 and 12.5 individuals/km² (Quris 1975). At Mondika in Nouabalé-Ndoki National Park (Congo), density was 6.9 individuals/km² (Shah 2003). In Odzala-Kokoua National Park (Congo), group size was usually at least 20, and there were between 0.5 and 2 groups/km² (10–40 animals/km²), depending on the habitat type (Maisels 1996). In the Ituri Forest (DRC), densities varied between 2 individuals/km² (Thomas 1991) and 38 individuals/km² (Kambale Saambili 1998). In the Ngotto Forest (CAR), densities varied between 7.2 and 41 individuals/km² – variation here was related to hunting intensity by humans (D. Brugière pers. comm. 2013).
range:
The geographic range of Cercocebus agilis is not well known, despite covering about 1,010,000 km². This species occurs in Cameroon, Central African Republic (CAR), the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), northeast Gabon and northern Republic of Congo. It remains to be confirmed whether it still occurs in Equatorial Guinea.

The most westerly subpopulation, which may be isolated, appears to be in Campo Ma’an in southern Cameroon, as recorded by three different surveys (Etoga and Foguekem 2008, 2009; Nzooh Dongmo 2015). The Agile Mangabey is, therefore, expected to occur in Equatorial Guinea; however, since the 1960s, when a single adult female was recorded by Sabater Pi and Jones (1968), no survey has re-confirmed the presence of this species (Larison et al. 1999, Puit and Ghiurghi 2004, Sunderland 2005, Ruffler et al. 2012).

The northerly range limit is the forest ecotone from north of the Dja Biosphere Reserve in Cameroon, perhaps at 5°N, across to the Ubangui River, the gallery forest areas in CAR, up to about 9° N (Fay 1988). East of 22° E, the northern limit is likely around 6° 45’ N across to about 30°E, including the area of DRC southwards to at least the Tshopo River.

The southern limit is the right bank of the Congo River, probably from its confluence with the Tshopo (J. Hart pers. obs.) westward to the Sangha-Congo confluence at 1°6’ S. The range is then limited by the southwestern edge of the swamp forests (around 0°18’S up to just south of Odzala National Park (NP) at about 0°30’ S, and continues westwards across Gabon to Cameroon – west of the Dja Biosphere Reserve, near Sangemelima at around 11°30’ E (Gautier-Hion et al. 1999).
useTrade: <span class="msoIns">This species is hunted throughout its range for bushmeat.
conservationActions:
Cercocebus agilis is listed on Appendix II of CITES and on Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources. Nationally, it is listed as partially protected in Cameroon, Congo and DRC. The hunting, sale, and consumption of primates are forbidden in Equatorial Guinea by Presidential Decree. It is on List C of Annex 2 to Ordinance 84.045 of 1984 in CAR, and not mentioned in Gabon’s protected species list. Cameroon, Gabon and Congo are currently revising their protected species lists.

To determine the western limits of its distribution, it is recommended that people familiar with both the call and appearance of C. torquatus, C. agilis (and Lophocebus albigena) undertake surveys in Campo Ma’an National Park and the areas between there and Dja Biosphere Reserve to be sure whether or not the two Cercocebus spp. are indeed sympatric. If C. agilis is confirmed there, then it may well also still occur in Equatorial Guinea and efforts should be made to look for this species there also.

Agile Mangabeys have been recorded in a number of protected areas; here we cite only the most recent survey information available:

Cameroon: Lobéké NP (Nzooh Dongmo et al. 2016a); Boumba Bek NP and Nki NP (Nzooh Dongmo et al. 2016b); Mengame Gorilla Sanctuary (Ekobo 2006); Dja Biosphere Reserve – already uncommon in 2009 (Latour 2010) and not recorded in 2015 (MINFOF/IUCN 2015; Campo Ma’an NP (Nzooh Dongmo 2015). Not recorded in Abong Mbam or Deng Deng in 2001 (Fotso et al. 2002), nor in Deng Deng in 2012 (Maisels et al. 2013a).

CAR: Dzanga-Ndoki NP (N’Goran et al. 2016), Mbaéré-Bodingué NP (Brugière et al. 2005); Zemongo Reserve (Roulet et al. 2007), Chinko Reserve (R. Hickisch & T. Aebischer, unpublished data 2016).

Congo: Nouabalé-Ndoki NP and Lac Télé Community Reserve (Brncic et al. 2018); Odzala-Kokoua NP (Maisels et al. 2013b).

DRC: Bili-Uéré Hunting Domain (Hicks 2014), Garamba NP (Hillman-Smith et al. 2014), Okapi Wildlife Reserve (Wildlife Conservation Society, unpublished data 2018).

Gabon: an early study of this species (Quris 1975) recorded its presence south of the Ivindo River (just to the east of what is now the north of Ivindo NP). C. agilis has not been recorded in protected areas of Gabon since. However, Shah (2013) mentions personal communications from well-informed scientists (L.J.T. White and S.A. Lahm) suggesting that Agile Mangabeys may still occur in Ivindo NP, Minkébé NP and Mwagna NP.

rationale: Leptophilypnus guatemalensis occurs in the Ixcan and upper La Pasión drainages in Huehuetenango and El Quiche, Guatemala and the Lacantun river basin in southern Chiapas, Mexico. The population status of the species as well as the potential impact of threats (which include dams, mining, and clearance for agricultural purposes) are unknown. The species is listed as Data Deficient as the extinction risk to the species cannot be determined given the data which is currently available. Additional research is needed to better characterize the species’ distribution, population trend, life history, and the impact of threats in the region.
habitat: The species occurs in large freshwater river systems and possibly wetlands and swamps (Thacker et al. 2006).
threats: Dams have the potential to negatively impact the species’ population. Oil exploitation, mining activities, and small-scale agricultural development occurs in the immediate area (Perez 2005, Eisermann 2006, Aguilar-Støen and Hirsch 2015, Navas et al. 2018). However, the scope and magnitude of impacts to aquatic habitat availability and quality have not been evaluated. There is no direct evidence that these threats have negatively impacted the population status of L. guatemalensis.
population: No comprehensive population data is available for this species and the current population trend is unknown.
range: Leptophilypnus guatemalensis occurs in the Ixcan and upper La Pasión drainages in Huehuetenango and El Quiche, Guatemala and the Lacantun river basin in southern Chiapas, Mexico (Espinosa-Pérez et al. 2014). The species has an estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of 5,700 km2 based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around georeferenced point collections (Espinosa-Pérez et al. 2014, GBIF 2020).
useTrade: The species is not known to be used or traded for any purpose.
conservationActions: The species incidentally occurs in the Reserva de la Biósfera de Montes Azules (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020). Additional resarch regarding distribution, population size, population trend, and the scope and magnitude of existing threats is needed to accurately assess the extinction risk of this species.

rationale: Awaous bustamantei is found on the Gulf of Guinea islands of Bioko, Sao Tome, Principe, and Pagalu, only on islands. The rivers are currently being degraded by pollution, and oil exploration is a further potential threat. It is therefore assessed as Vulnerable.
habitat: Awaous bustamantei lives in cascade rivers: rivers with high velocity, cold, clear water.
threats: High population density, therefore domestic pollution and small scale agriculture (pers. comm. Victor Mamonekene, Cyrille Dening). Oil exploitation is a potential threat (pers. comm. Victor Pouomogne).
population: No information available.
range: Awaous bustamantei is found on the Gulf of Guinea islands of Bioko, Sao Tome, Principe, and Pagalu, only on islands. Specimens collected from the lower Ndian River, Cameroon that were tentatively identified as A. bustamantei are more likely Awaous lateristriga according to recent comparative studies.
conservationActions: None known.

rationale: This species is known from a relatively small range, much of which is possibly impacted by oil extraction. However, there are very few museum records, and in general this type of species is known to be difficult to collect. At this time, it is not possible to assess whether the species is scarce or simply difficult to catch. Also, there is no information on how the oil industry has affected (or not) the Napo River and populations of this species. Therefore, this species is assessed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This species buries itself in sand or gravel on the river bottom. It is found in shallow areas with slow to moderate current. It is presumed to feed on benthic aquatic invertebrates.
threats: No current threat assessments were found for the Napo River region where this species occurs, but nearby areas are known to have oil wells under production. However, specific threats to this species are unknown.
population: No population data are available.
range: This species is apparently restricted to the Napo drainage in the Ecuadorian Amazon, but seldom collected and known from very few museum records. The type locality is Río Aguarico, 1 km upstream from confluence with Río Shushufindi, Napo Province, 0°17'S, 76°24.5'W, Ecuador (Stewart 1985). Records from Colombia and Venezuela are misidentifications of H. sexpapilostoma.
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: There is no specific information about conservation measures protecting this species.

rationale: This species is widespread, occurring in some protected/conservation areas and remote regions. The data in biological collections and different regional reports do not suggest a perceptible reduction in the populations of the species. Therefore, it is evaluated as Least Concern (LC).
habitat: Hoplomyzon sexpapilostoma is found associated with gravel bottoms of tributaries with moderate to strong current in the piedmont region, with forested margins (Taphorn and Marrero 1990). It is presumed to feed on benthic aquatic invertebrates. It can reach a maximum size of 3.2 cm standard length.
threats: Some the drainages where Hoplomyzon sexpapilostoma lives are in good condition, but others close to urban and agricultural fields are negatively affected (Winemiller et al. 1996, Briceño 2015). Agriculture and deforestation are common (Oliveira-Miranda et al. 2010). Pollution from mining is another threat.
population: The current population trend is probably stable, but there are no data available. The total population size is suspected to be large. It is possible that the habitat of the species will be reduced in the future due to increasing sedimentation of channels as a result of deforestation and erosion of the upper basins of Andes (Oliveira-Miranda et al. 2010, Briceño 2015).
range:
Hoplomyzon sexpapilostoma was described from Masparro river at Masparro dam, Barinas state (Taphorn and Marrero 1990). It is widely distributed in Western Andean tributaries of the Orinoco basin, along the piedmont region from the river Ariari (Guaviare drainage) to the Guache river in Portuguesa drainage (Taphorn and Marrero 1990). In Colombia it occurs in rivers Ariari, Caja, Upamena, Cusiana, and Cravo Norte. In Venezuela the species is reported from rivers Torbes, Bumbum, La Yuca, Masparro, Boconó, Guanare, Las Marías and Guache, all in Apure drainage. The species has an elevational distribution ranges from 59-1,406 m above sea level.

The distribution of Hoplomizon sexpapilostoma in this assessment is a summary based on scientific reports and records compiled, arranged and reviewed from the following sources: Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF 2020), FishNet2 (Fishnet2 2020), FishBase (Froese and Pauly 2019), SiB Colombia (SiB Colombia 2020) and SpeciesLink (SpeciesLink 2020), and complemented with records from the databases of the following ichthyological collections from Colombia: CZUT-IC (Colección Zoológica, Universidad del Tolima, Ibagué), IAvH-P (Colección de Peces de Agua Dulce del Instituto de Investigación de Recursos Biológicos Alexander von Humboldt, Villa de Leyva), ICN-MHN (Instituto de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional de Colombia, Bogotá), IMCN (Colección Zoológica de Referencia Científica del Museo de Ciencias Naturales Federico Carlos Lehmann Valencia del INCIVA, Cali), and MPUJ (Museo Javeriano de Historia Natural "Lorenzo Uribe, S.J." de la Pontificia Universidad Javeriana, Bogotá), and Venezuela: MCNG (Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional Experimental de los Llanos Occidentales Ezequiel Zamora, Guanare, Venezuela) and CPUCLA (Colección Regional de Peces, Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Centroccidental Lisandro Alvarado, Barquisimeto, Venezuela).
useTrade: There are no known uses for the species.
conservationActions: They are no known conservation plans for Hoplomizon sexpapilostoma. DNI Ariari Guayabero and National Park Tapo-Caparo cover part of the distribution (Villa-Navarro et al. 2017, IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020). Habitat protection and communications are recommended. It is necessary to research and monitor the population and habitat.

rationale: Entomocorus gameroi occurs in different environments throughout the lowlands of Orinoco basin. It is suspected to have a stable population, despite being common in ornamental fishing. This species is evaluated as Least Concern. The habitat of this species is subject to several progressive impacts by environmental stressors, which require further evaluation.
habitat: Entomocorus gameroi inhabits a variety of environments, including swamps (morichales, cananguchales), lagoons, streams and rivers, in foothills, upper plains and floodplains in the Orinoco basin. The habitat include clear, white and blackwater streams. It is nocturnal and has sexual dimorphism. This species feeds on zooplankton (crustacea), cladocerans, copepods and water mites. It reaches sexual maturity in only one year, breeding once at the end of that period and perishing soon after (Rodríguez et al. 1990). The species can reach 70 mm in standard length (Ferraris 2003). It can reach a fertility of 238 eggs per female, with a generation length of 12 months (Winemiller and Taphorn 1989).
threats: Deforestation of large extensions of primary forests, agroindustrial developments, dams and riverbed transformations, oil exploitation and gold mining occur within its distribution (e.g. Etter et al. 2006, Oliveira-Miranda et al. 2010, Romero-Ruíz et al. 2012). These impacts are greatest in the drainages of Meta, Arauca and Apure rivers, The combined action of the stressors has a deleterious effect on the integrity of fish communities and the structure of the aquatic habitat (Rodríguez-Olarte and Taphorn 1995, Winemiller et al. 1996, Usma 2000, Briceño 2015).
population: The total population size is suspected to be greater than 10,000 individuals, given its natural abundance and broad distribution. The current population trend is suspected to be stable.
range:
Entomocorus gameroi was described originally from Bolivar state in Venezuela. It is widely distributed in lowland and piedmont rivers of the Orinoco basin (Mago-Leccia 1984). The species occur from the Inírida in the south, Meta, Apure, Portuguesa, Caura, main channel of the Orinoco River, up to the delta. The species is distributed in a range of elevations from 5-207 meters above sea level.

The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated at 497,488 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around georeferenced point records.

The geographic attributes for Entomocorus gameroi in this assessment were compiled, arranged and reviewed from the following sources: Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF 2020), FishNet2 (Fishnet2 2020), FishBase (Froese and Pauly 2019), SiB Colombia (SiB Colombia 2020) and SpeciesLink (SpeciesLink 2020), and complemented with records from the databases of the following ichthyological collections from Colombia: CZUT-IC (Colección Zoológica, Universidad del Tolima, Ibagué), IAvH-P (Colección de Peces de Agua Dulce del Instituto de Investigación de Recursos Biológicos Alexander von Humboldt, Villa de Leyva), ICN-MHN (Instituto de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional de Colombia, Bogotá), IMCN (Colección Zoológica de Referencia Científica del Museo de Ciencias Naturales Federico Carlos Lehmann Valencia del INCIVA, Cali), and MPUJ (Museo Javeriano de Historia Natural "Lorenzo Uribe, S.J." de la Pontificia Universidad Javeriana, Bogotá), and Venezuela: MCNG (Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional Experimental de los Llanos Occidentales Ezequiel Zamora, Guanare, Venezuela) and CPUCLA (Colección Regional de Peces, Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Centroccidental Lisandro Alvarado, Barquisimeto, Venezuela).
useTrade: Entomocorus gameroi is reported as an ornamental fish in Colombia and Venezuela. In Colombia the species is subject to regulations for ornamental trade (Ortega-Lara et al. 2015). It is reported in landings of Arauca and Villavicencio. The volume traded is unknown.
conservationActions: It is included in regulations for the ornamental fishery (Ortega-Lara et al. 2015). EFI Ramsar site, Wildlife Reserves Caño Guaritico, Esteros de Camaguán, National Parks Aguaro-Guariquito and Caura are within its distribution (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2003, Taphorn et al. 2004, Villa-Navarro et al. 2020, IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020). Awareness and communications are recommended, as well as research into trends for the population, habitat, trade and harvest.

rationale: This species has a wide distribution in many drainages (Orinoco and Caribbean rivers) and is reported in protected areas. The records in biological collections and databases do not suggest a reduction in the population of the species. In the wide distribution there are many environmental stressors (e.g. deforestation, sedimentation, contamination by agroindustrial effluents) and that affect the rivers, such as the Torbes and Yaracuy, for example. Therefore, monitoring and research on the population and habitat are necessary. Given its widespread distribution, this species is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: Cetopsis orinoco prefers clear and flowing waters in streams and rivers of piedmonts and plains. It is observed in backwaters and pools, usually hidden under stones, logs, branches and in caves. It is nocturnal, benthic and carnivorous, feeding on macroinvertebrates, and possibly a scavenger. Aspects of its reproduction are not known. It can be over 9.4 mm in standard length.
threats: The principal threat to Cetopsis orinoco is the expansion of the anthropic frontier on piedmont drainages, as is happening in several Andean and coastal drainages (Winemiller et al. 1996, Oliveira-Miranda et al. 2010). In Torbes river (Apure drainage) the species was not registered in recent evaluations, despite having historical presence (Usma 2000). Similarly, other rivers in the coastal drainages are heavily altered, such as Yaracuy and Urama (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2018). However, in the wide extent of occurrence of the species there are still several drainages with good conservation status and protected areas.
population: Cetopsis orinoco is not common in museum records, probably due to the difficulty in capturing it. In standardized electrofishing in piedmont coastal streams (Aroa and Yaracuy drainages) this species comprised around 0.1% of relative abundance (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2011). Given its natural broad distribution of the species in Orinoco basin and Caribbean drainages, the population size must be large and with stable trend, but there may be a decline in quality of habitat in the future due to the advance of the urban and agricultural frontier and the alteration of the integrity of drainages and rivers where the species inhabits (Oliveira-Miranda et al. 2010, Briceño 2015).
range:
Cetopsis orinoco was described for Río Torbes, one kilometer above of Táriba, Río Orinoco system, Venezuela (Schultz 1944). The species occur in rivers Chitamena, Upamena and Cusiana (upper Meta drainage), Arauca, Torbes, Guanare, Boconó, Tucupido, Portuguesa, Suripá, Orupe (Apure drainage) and Aguaro in central llanos (Usma 2000, Vari and Ferraris 2003, Vari et al. 2005, Taphorn et al. 2005, Urbano-Bonilla et al. 2018). It is also in the Aroa and Yaracuy in Caribbean drainages (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2011). The species is reported in 122 localities with elevation from 97-900 m above sea level.

The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated at 369,525 km2 based on georeferenced point records.

The geographic attributes for Cetopsis orinoco in this assessment were compiled, arranged and reviewed from the following sources: Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF 2020), FishNet2 (Fishnet2 2020), FishBase (Froese and Pauly 2019), SiB Colombia (SiB Colombia 2020) and SpeciesLink (SpeciesLink 2020), and complemented with records from the databases of the following ichthyological collections from Colombia: CZUT-IC (Colección Zoológica, Universidad del Tolima, Ibagué), IAvH-P (Colección de Peces de Agua Dulce del Instituto de Investigación de Recursos Biológicos Alexander von Humboldt, Villa de Leyva), ICN-MHN (Instituto de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional de Colombia, Bogotá), IMCN (Colección Zoológica de Referencia Científica del Museo de Ciencias Naturales Federico Carlos Lehmann Valencia del INCIVA, Cali), and MPUJ (Museo Javeriano de Historia Natural "Lorenzo Uribe, S.J." de la Pontificia Universidad Javeriana, Bogotá), and Venezuela: MCNG (Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional Experimental de los Llanos Occidentales Ezequiel Zamora, Guanare, Venezuela) and CPUCLA (Colección Regional de Peces, Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Centroccidental Lisandro Alvarado, Barquisimeto, Venezuela).
useTrade: The species is occasionally harvested as bycatch in commercial and artisanal fisheries. It is rare in subsistence fishing, except probably for indigenous groups. The total volume of harvest is unknown.
conservationActions: There are no regulations and educational programs oriented to its protection. This species is included in the digital platform for dissemination and training about freshwater fish, their monitoring and conservation in coastal drainages of Venezuela (Rodríguez-Olarte and Taphorn 2007). Previously it was assigned to the category Data Deficient in a regional assessment restricted to coastal drainages of Venezuela (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2011). The national natural parks Sierra de la Macarena (Colombia), National Park Yurubí and Natural Monument María Lionza in Caribbean versants, and National Park Aguaro-Guariquito in central llanos of Orinoco (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020) occur within its range, and it is probable that the species occurs in national parks San Miguel de los Farallones, Tamá (Colombia), El Tamá, Páramos del Batallón y La Negra, Sierra Nevada, Guache and Tucuragua (Venezuela). Recommended conservation actions are awareness and communications, and it is necessary to research the population size and distribution, threats and habitat.

rationale: The species is widespread, abundant and occurs in several protected areas in both Colombia and Venezuela. Therefore, it is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: The Siapa and Cataniapo Rivers, from which this species was originally described, have black and clearwater tributaries and are typical rivers that flow off the Guiana Shield, with sand, gravel or rocky substrates, high transparency, low pH, low conductivity and low nutrients. However, this species has also been recorded from whitewater rivers of the Venezuelan llanos and several other rivers in Colombia, indicating that it has a wide range of habitats.
threats: Specific threats to this species are unknown, and those indicated here  are suspected threats known to occur where this species has been found. The Orinoco River Basin is undergoing transformation due to the expansion of the agricultural frontier, and many tributaries have been dammed. Deforestation is most extensive in the Andes, piedmont and high plains and has led to sedimentation of most of the Andean river drainages. Agriculture has led to an increase in nutrients and pesticides in the water. This species has probably suffered decreases in its total population as a result. However, no reliable measures of the population before human impacts began, or of current population levels are available.
population: Since it is widespread and locally abundant, the population of this species is thought to greatly exceed 10,000 individuals.
range: The type locality of this species is the Rio Siapa, tributary of Rio Casiquiare, campamento Siapa II, about 1°40–1°41'N, 64°22'–64°28'W, Amazonas, Venezuela. This species is recorded from the Siapa and Cataniapo Rivers in Amazonas state in Venezuela, as well as Apure and Cojedes states in the Venezuelan llanos. In Colombia, there are records from the Bita and Cinaruco rivers. It is probably widespread throughout the Orinoco River Basin, and could also be expected in the upper Río Negro drainage of southernmost Venezuela and northern Brazil.
useTrade: Occasionally it is caught in subsistence fishing by indigenous peoples.
conservationActions: Even though there are no specific conservation plans for this species, there are several protected areas (national parks and natural monuments) that cover important sections of the rivers in regions where it is known to occur.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Vulnerable because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, its population is considered to be severely fragmented, and there is a continuing decline in the area and quality of its habitat in [location]."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Endangered because of its extent of occurrence (EOO) of 3,920 km<sup>2</sup>, its population is considered to be severely fragmented, it occurs in two threat-defined locations, and there is a continuing decline in the area and quality of its habitat outside of protected areas in the Cordillera Azul.
habitat: This species occurs in undisturbed premontane forest, particularly in habitats adjacent to streams, though it appears to have extremely specific habitat requirements. In Contamana, it has been found alongside three different streams, but only in restricted areas along these streams. Adults are found under logs or under piles of leaf litter and appear to be more active after a heavy  rain. Males appear to call from the leaf litter throughout the day, but usually remain well-hidden beneath the leaf litter. Reproduction likely takes place near small streams and forest pools, and tadpoles are deposited within shallow forest pools.
threats: There is a small amount of habitat loss in the Cordillera Azul near Río Huallaga caused by agricultural activities, including coffee, banana and palm oil plantations (Brown and Twomey 2009). The Sierra del Divisor also faces imminent threats from oil and mining development, road and pipeline construction and illegal logging. However, the degree of impact of these threats on this species remains unknown.
population: This species is exceedingly cryptic and is nearly impossible to detect, especially if males are not calling. It appears to be patchily distributed, but can be common in some areas (Twomey and Brown 2009). The population appears to be severely fragmented, as only two disjunct subpopulations have been encountered and these are restricted to small areas (Brown and Twomey 2009). During 2007 surveys in Callanayacu, only three individuals were captured within a 200 m stretch of habitat (68 person-hours), despite the fact that numerous male were calling in the vicinity the entire time. Surveys in Contamana were only able to detect a total of six frogs despite 60 person-hours in 2006 and 48 person-hours in 2007. Due to ongoing decline in the quality and extent of its habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This recently described (2009) species is known from two locations, one in the Serranía de Contamana in the Loreto Region and the  other in the Huallaga Canyon in the northern Cordillera Azul (Brown and Twomey 2009). These two  sites are 130 km apart and separated by the Ucayali floodplain,  which may represent a significant barrier between these two subpopulations (Twomey and Brown 2009). While this species may range widely throughout the Cordillera Azul and Sierra del Divisor, it may just as likely be restricted to the Serranía de Contamana and extreme northern Cordillera Azul (Brown and Twomey 2009). Its elevational range is 230–600 m asl and its EOO is 3,920 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species is present within Cordillera Azul National Park and in the buffer zone of the Sierra del Divisor National Park, established in 2015. Much of this species’ potential habitat is protected in the Cordillera Azul National Park, although the extent to which this species occurs in the park remains unknown (Twomey and Brown 2009). It is listed as Near Threatened (NT) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes. It is included in Appendix II of CITES, in which trade must be controlled in order to avoid utilization incompatible with the species' survival.

Conservation Needed
Ongoing management and protection of the species' habitat is required.

Research Needed
More information about this species' distribution, population status, natural history, and threats are needed.

rationale: This species is abundant and widespread, and occurs in more than one protected area. Therefore, it is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This fish inhabits white-water streams originating in the Andes. They typically have low visibility, pH around neutral, moderate to high dissolved nutrients and muddy substrates. Knodus alpha is an oviparous omnivore, feeding mainly on invertebrates.
threats: Threats listed here are general ones, known to occur where this species has been found. Until recently the Orinoco River Basin in Venezuela experienced strong human activity expansion, with new and growing urban centers, industrialized agriculture of corn, sorghum, sugar cane, and sunflowers, and piedmont production of coffee bananas and plantains, as well as widespread cattle ranching in the llanos (Winemiller et al. 1996, Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2017). This led to extensive deforestation with loss of riparian forests, heavy sedimentation and run-off of fertilizers and pesticides. In addition, oil was exploited throughout much of the savannas of Apure, Barinas, Portuguesa, Cojedes, Guárico Anzoátegui and Monagas. An industrial center in Ciudad Bolivar produced iron, aluminum gold and diamonds, and created large deposits of byproducts of those industries such as red clay that has been known to drain into the Orinoco River channel. Today, most of those activities have ceased, except for gold and diamond mining which have increased greatly. In Colombia the opposite was true for most of the Orinoco River Basin which was under the control of anti-government military forces that preclude development. However, the government routed the rebels and the Orinoco River Basin in Colombia is now experiencing a boom in agriculture and cattle ranching, and commercial fishing, as well as urban expansion, with all concomitant negative impacts along with the economic prosperity. As a widespread species, all of these impacts must have led to a decrease in the total population of Knodus alpha, however, there are no hard data to support this supposition.
population: Although there are no data on the population size of this species, it is common and widespread and so estimated to be greater than 10,000.
range: This species is reported from the southern flank of the Andes in piedmont and upper llanos (Guaviare, Meta, Arauca, Apure river drainages). The type locality is Villavicencio, Río Orinoco system, Colombia.
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures to specifically protect this species.

rationale: This species is fairly widespread in the upper Meta and Guaviare drainages, and is present in one protected area. Therefore, it is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: Hemibrycon cristiani lives in clear mountain streams with gravel, rock or sandy substrates, high oxygen saturation and high transparency. It is an omnivore, feeding on aquatic and terrestrial invertebrates and plant material.
threats: No data are available for impacts specifically impacting this species, but agriculture and oil drilling occur in the area occupied by Hemibrycon cristiani.
population: No data are available on the population, but the population size is assumed to be greater than 10,000.
range: This species has been collected from upland streams and rivers in the Meta and Guaviare river drainages of the upper Orinoco River Basin. The type locality is the Upper Meta River, tributary to Río Guayuriba, 4°07'N, 74°15'W, Meta Dept., Colombia.
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: No specific conservation plans are known for this species, but it is widespread and present in one protected area and as such does not face imminent threats to its population.

rationale: This species has a small area of distribution in the Maracaibo basin. The area of occupancy (AOO) is best estimated at 1,112 km<sup>2</sup>. The current population trend is considered stable, but there is a lack of information about its situation. The species is not registered in protected areas, but may occur in some. In the habitat of the species there are several environmental stressors with negative effects on rivers integrity, some with extreme impacts (e.g. oil and coal exploitation and transport), which are thought to be causing a continuing decline in the habitat. There are 2-4 locations based on these threats. Therefore, this species is assessed as Vulnerable.
habitat: In the Maracaibo basin Bryconamericus motatanensis is found in plains, piedmonts and mountains. The species inhabits swamps, creeks, streams and rivers with clear and white water currents on varied substrates. As with other species of the genus Bryconamericus, it is probably an omnivore that seeks its food (aquatic and terrestrial insects, and small seeds) while drifting with the current. It can reach over 40 mm of standard length (Román-Valencia 2005).
threats: In the plains, piedmonts and mountains around the Maracaibo Lake intense anthropic impacts are reported including oil and coal extraction, their refinement and conduction, and also deforestation, water extraction, urban effluents and dredging of channels (Oliveira-Miranda et al. 2010, García et al. 2016, Rincón 2017, Segnini and Chacón 2017). All these stressors have deleterious effects on habitat of B. motatanensis and are expected to continue to expand in the future. The loss of integrity of several rivers in the region, such as Machango and Misoa, for example, has been quantified (García et al. 2016). The ichthyofauna in the tributaries to the Maracaibo Lake are experiencing population declines, which are associated with the fragmentation, reduction and loss of aquatic habitats, and the introduction of non-native species. Added to this are the possible effects of climate change on freshwater ecosystems (Rincón 2017, Segnini and Chacón 2017).
population: There are no data available to estimate the actual population size, but it is suspected that it must be large given the natural abundance for the genus Bryconamericus and its relatively broad distribution. It is a common species, mainly in piedmont and plains. The current population trend is stable.
range:
Bryconamericus motatanensis was described from the Motatán river, Maracaibo basin (Schultz 1944). Almost all the records of this species are between plains and mountains rivers of the Maracaibo basin. The species is registered in La Pedregosa, near of Cúcuta (Colombia) and rivers Catatumbo, Aricuasá, Socuy, Muyupá, San Pedro, Misoa and Machango, according to Galvis et al. (1997), Ortega-Lara et al. (2012) and fish collections. It occurs in Perijá-Andes biogeographic subprovince (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2009). It is possible that the species inhabit in drainages to the Gulf of Venezuela in eastern slopes of Falcón state. A set of isolated records in river Las Marías (upper Portuguesa, Orinoco) are not considered valid. It is necessary to review the taxonomy of the group (Taphorn 1992). The species is reported in 14 localities with elevation from 25-1,200 m above sea level.

The extent of occurrence (EOO) is best estimated at 26,914 km2, and the area of occupancy (AOO) is best estimated at 1,112 km2. There are 2-4 threat-based locations.

The geographic attributes for Bryconamericus motatanensis in this assessment were compiled, arranged and reviewed from the following sources: Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF 2020), FishNet2 (Fishnet2 2020), FishBase (Froese and Pauly 2019), SiB Colombia (SiB Colombia 2020) and SpeciesLink (SpeciesLink 2020), and complemented with records from the databases of the following ichthyological collections from Colombia: CZUT-IC (Colección Zoológica, Universidad del Tolima, Ibagué), IAvH-P (Colección de Peces de Agua Dulce del Instituto de Investigación de Recursos Biológicos Alexander von Humboldt, Villa de Leyva), ICN-MHN (Instituto de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional de Colombia, Bogotá), IMCN (Colección Zoológica de Referencia Científica del Museo de Ciencias Naturales Federico Carlos Lehmann Valencia del INCIVA, Cali), and MPUJ (Museo Javeriano de Historia Natural "Lorenzo Uribe, S.J." de la Pontificia Universidad Javeriana, Bogotá), and Venezuela: MCNG (Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional Experimental de los Llanos Occidentales Ezequiel Zamora, Guanare, Venezuela) and CPUCLA (Colección Regional de Peces, Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Centroccidental Lisandro Alvarado, Barquisimeto, Venezuela).
useTrade: There are no known uses for the species
conservationActions: There are no known conservation plans specific for Bryconamericus motatanensis. The species is not registered in protected areas (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020), but might occur in the national parks of Catatumbo-Bari, Perijá and Ciénagas de Juan Manuel de Aguas Negras y Aguas Claras. Habitat protection, awareness and communications are recommeded. It is necessary to research the taxonomy, population and habitats.

rationale: There are very few collections of this species, and few individuals in those collections. The taxonomic validity of this species has not been adequately determined. It is known from just three disparate localites: one on the Guiana Shield, one in the low llanos floodplain, and one in the Andean piedmont, each with different types of threats. However, it is not possible to determine how the threats have impacted those subpopulations. Therefore, this species is evaluated as Data Deficient.
habitat: This species is reported from all three major types of river: black (Guiana Shield Rivers), clear (Ventuari river and tributaries) and whitewater (upper Meta River drainage in Andean foothills).
threats: The habitat of the species is threatened by different environmental stressors, such as the expansion of the agricultural frontier (Andes), and gold mining, which degrades the basins and destroys the channels, due to the action of machinery and sedimentation. Specific threats to this species are unknown, and those indicated here are suspected threats known to occur where this species has been found.
population: The total population size is suspected to be greater than 10000, but no data are available.
range: This species has been recorded from the Río Maniapure at crossing of Caicara-Puerto Ayacucho highway, 6°55'48"N, 66°33'22"W, Estado Bolívar, Venezuela (Chernoff and Machado-Allison 1990) and it also inhabits in Bita, Negro, Siapa and Ventuari rivers. In Colombia it occurs in the DNMI Cinaruco (Córdoba et al. 2016). Many museum records lack coordinates and so the distribution area may be underestimated. Here it is considered to be endemic to Orinoco River Basin. Records from other places are probably misidentifications.
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: There are no known plans for the conservation of this species.

rationale: This species is abundant, and widespread, and although it faces several kinds of threats is also present in some protected areas. Therefore, it is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This lowland species inhabits both lotic and lentic whitewater habitats, with mud substrate, low visibility, moderate dissolved nutrients. It is predatory, feeding on small fishes and aquatic invertebrates.
threats: Specific threats to this species are unknown, and those indicated here are  suspected threats known to occur where this species has been found. Since this species lives in a wide variety of habitats it faces many different threats. In the llanos of Colombia and Venezuela, these are small scale agriculture and cattle ranching, but in Guiana Shield rivers, the major threats come from gold miners. However, there are still many areas of the Orinoco Basin that are nearly pristine. As a whole, the Orinoco River Basin is undergoing transformation due to the expansion of the agricultural frontier and many tributaries have been dammed. Deforestation is most extensive in the Andes, piedmont and high plains and has led to sedimentation of most of the Andean river drainages. Agriculture has led to an increase in nutrients and pesticides in the water. This species has probably suffered decreases in its total population as a result. However, no reliable measures of the population before human impacts began, or of current population levels are available.
population: The population size is assumed to be more than 10,000, given its wide distribution.
range: This widespread, common species was described from the Río Cañito, near San Fernando to Cunaviche, Estado Apure, Venezuela (Lucena 1987). It also ocurrs in Portuguesa river (caño Maraca), llanos (Módulos de Apure) (Venezuela), Alto Meta and Guaviare rivers in Colombia.
useTrade: This species is taken sporadically for the ornamenal fish trade, as well as by subsistence fishers for human food.
conservationActions: There are no plans or legislation protecting this species.

rationale: This species is widespread in Venezuela and Colombia. Therefore, it is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This moderately sized predator feeds mainly on small fishes, but also on aquatic invertebrates. Little specific habitat information is avaiable, but most of the drainages where this species has been collected are whitewater, muddy waters, over mud substrate, fairly low transparency, higher nutrient content.
threats: Specific threats to this species are unknown, and those indicated here are  suspected threats known to occur where this species has been found. Since this species lives in a wide variety of habitats it faces many different threats. In the llanos of Colombia and Venezuela, these are small scale agriculture and cattle ranching, but in Guiana Shield rivers, the major threats come from gold miners. However, there are still many areas of the Orinoco Basin that are nearly pristine. As a whole, the Orinoco River Basin is undergoing transformation due to the expansion of the agricultural frontier and many tributaries have been dammed. Deforestation is most extensive in the Andes, piedmont and high plains and has led to sedimentation of most of the Andean river drainages. Agriculture has led to an increase in nutrients and pesticides in the water. This species has probably suffered decreases in its total population as a result. However, no reliable measures of the population before human impacts began, or of current population levels are available.
population: No population information is available.
range: The type locality is a small caño near mouth of Caño Soroco, Río Orinoco, Venezuela. It is also found in the Meta and Apure rivers and the middle section and delta of the Orinoco River.
useTrade: This species is probably not identified as distinct from other Charax species by ornamental or subsistence fishermen. It is only probably sporadically harvested for either purpose.
conservationActions: No plans for the conservation of this species are known.

rationale: Corynopoma riisei has a wide distribution in Andean tributaries of Orinoco, Caribbean slopes, and Trinidad Island. The species is frequent in biological collections and occurs in protected areas. In some drainages there is little human intervention (e.g. protected areas) but in most rivers there are moderate to high concentration of human impacts. However, the extent of occurrence is large. The species is therefore evaluated as Least Concern.
habitat: The habitats for Corynopoma riisei are lagoons, creeks and streams in piedmonts and lowlands with heterogeneous waters and substrates (Taphorn 1992). It is usual in ponds, with slow and intermittent currents. It is considered a tolerant species with respect to brackish conditions. It also occurs in artificial channels and lagoons. It is a carnivore, feeding mostly on insects. It can reach 80 mm in standard length. It is oviparous, with internal fertilisation and extended spawning coincident with high rainfall (Phillip et al. 2013). Fertility was counted as 135 eggs per female and the generation length is four months (Winemiller and Taphorn 1989).
threats: Various drainages where Corynopoma riisei inhabits (e.g. Torbes, Lake Valencia, Tuy, Trinidad Island) face extensive environmental stressors: deforestation, urban and agricultural settlements and their effluents, damming, water extraction and dredging channels (e.g. Usma 2000, Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2018). In addition, the Andean rivers have lost their integrity as a consequence of permanent sewage generated by urban centers. The causes that have generated these impacts on aquatic habitats are still active and are not expected to be resolved in the future.
population: Corynopoma riisei is a common species in piedmont and lowlands streams (Taphorn 1992). The total population size is suspected to be greater than 10,000 individuals, given its broad distribution. The current population trend is stable.
range:
Corynopoma riisei was described from Trinidad island (Gill 1858), and it also inhabits drainages in coastal and Andean ranges in Orinoco basin in Colombia and Venezuela. On Trinidad island it inhabits Aripo, Grande and Oropuche rivers (Phillip et al. 2013). In the Orinoco the records include the rivers Ariari, Arauca and Upía in Meta drainage (Urbano-Bonilla et al. 2009), Torbes, Uribante, Socopó, Santo Domingo, Tucupido, Turbio, Vigirima (Apure drainage), San Diego (Valencia Lake drainage), Tuy and Manzanares in coastal versants (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2009, Bonilla-Rivero and López-Rojas 2013). The species is reported in 213 sites with elevation from 5-615 m above sea level.

The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated at 431,528 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around georeferenced point records.

The geographic attributes for Corynopoma riisei in this assessment were compiled, arranged and reviewed from the following sources: Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF 2020), FishNet2 (Fishnet2 2020), FishBase (Froese and Pauly 2019), SiB Colombia (SiB Colombia 2020) and SpeciesLink (SpeciesLink 2020), and complemented with records from the databases of the following ichthyological collections from Colombia: CZUT-IC (Colección Zoológica, Universidad del Tolima, Ibagué), IAvH-P (Colección de Peces de Agua Dulce del Instituto de Investigación de Recursos Biológicos Alexander von Humboldt, Villa de Leyva), ICN-MHN (Instituto de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional de Colombia, Bogotá), IMCN (Colección Zoológica de Referencia Científica del Museo de Ciencias Naturales Federico Carlos Lehmann Valencia del INCIVA, Cali), and MPUJ (Museo Javeriano de Historia Natural "Lorenzo Uribe, S.J." de la Pontificia Universidad Javeriana, Bogotá), and Venezuela: MCNG (Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional Experimental de los Llanos Occidentales Ezequiel Zamora, Guanare, Venezuela) and CPUCLA (Colección Regional de Peces, Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Centroccidental Lisandro Alvarado, Barquisimeto, Venezuela).
useTrade: Corynopoma riisei has moderate importance in the aquarium fish market.
conservationActions: There are no laws, regulations and programs for its protection. It occurs in Natural Reserve Meseta de Versalles (Colombia), National Park El Tamá, Forest Reserve Ticoporo (Venezuela) and Trinity Hills (Trinidad). It is probably in Natural Park Laguna de Loma Linda (Colombia) and Nationals Parks Guatopo and Tucuragua (Venezuela) (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020). Habitat protection, awareness and communications are recommended. It is necessary to conduct research on the population trend, threats and habitat.

rationale: This species is widespread, and present in some protected areas. Therefore, it is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: It occurs in lowland streams and lentic habitats (lagoons, borrow pits), with high sediment load and muddy substrate, and is tolerant of disturbed habitats. It is often among aquatic vegetation. It is found in mixed schools with other small characiforms. It is an omnivore.
threats: Specific threats to this species are unknown, and those indicated here are  suspected threats known to occur where this species has been found. Since this species lives in a wide variety of habitats it faces many different threats. In the llanos of Colombia and Venezuela, these are small scale agriculture and cattle ranching, but in Guiana Shield rivers, the major threats come from gold miners. However, there are still many areas of the Orinoco Basin that are nearly pristine. As a whole, the Orinoco River Basin is undergoing transformation due to the expansion of the agricultural frontier and many tributaries have been dammed. Deforestation is most extensive in the Andes, piedmont and high plains and has led to sedimentation of most of the Andean river drainages. Agriculture has led to an increase in nutrients and pesticides in the water. This species has probably suffered decreases in its total population as a result. However, no reliable measures of the population before human impacts began, or of current population levels are available.
population: This very abundant and widespread species is assumed to have a population greater than 10,000 individuals.
range: This species was described from the Apure River, west of the city of San Fernando de Apure, in Apure state, Venezuela (Benine et al. 2010). It is probably present throughout whitewater rivers of the Orinoco River Basin.
useTrade: This species may sporadically be collected for the ornamental fish trade. This species is often misidentified as C. spilurus, and may occur in the aquarium trade under that name.
conservationActions: This species is present in several protected areas in both Colombia and Venezuela. However, the degree of actual protection offered from those protected areas is unknown since most have inadequate personelle and funding to be effective.

rationale: This species is found in several countries of northern South America, is locally abundant and present in several protected areas. Therefore, it is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species occurs in both lotic and lentic habitats, often with muddy substrates, abundant aquatic vegetation, whitewaters with some dissolved nutrients and minerals, and pH near neutral. It is also known from clear and blackwater habitats.
threats: As a widespread species present in many different drainages and habitats, this species faces a wide variety of impacts. However, those listed in this section are impacts known to occur where this species is present, but there are no specific data indicating how Hemigrammus rodwayi is directly impacted by them. The Orinoco River Basin has already suffered considerable reduction in headwaters with several large dams that block fish migrations etc. In addition, cattle ranching and agriculture have led to widespread deforestation, especially in the Andes Mountains and adjacent piedmont. As a result, all fish species in the Orinoco Basin have inevitably seen their extent of occurence and habitat quality reduced.
population: Although there are no specific data, we suspect that the total population of this species well exceeds 10,000 individuals, given its wide range.
range: This species was described from the Georgetown Trenches, in the Botanic Garden, and also reported from other coastal rivers such as the Aruka and Barima rivers, Guyana. It is also found in Suriname, French Guiana and Amazon River basin. In Venezuela it has been reported from several rivers, among them the Apure, Cinaruco, Capanaparo, Meta, Caura, Caroní, Cuyuní, and Zuata. There are also many reports of this species from various states in Brazil, and the upper Amazon in Peru.
conservationActions: No conservation measures specific to this species have been implemented.

rationale: This species is fairly widespread in both and abundant in areas with moderate human impacts as well as more pristine remote areas. It is found in several protected areas.
habitat: This species occurs in blackwater streams, with acid pH, low nutrients, low dissolved minerals, high transparency, abundant aquatic vegetation and substrates of sand and decomposing vegetal material, such as that found in morichal palm wetlands.
threats: No specific threats have been documented for this species. The threats listed in this section are known to occur in areas where this species occurs. Since it inhabits morichal palm wetland streams, the increase in fire frequency and intensity may have an impact on this and all other fishes living in that llaneran habitat.
population: There are no population data for this species, but we assume the population exceeds 10,000 individuals, since it is widespread and abundant, as most small characids.
range: This species has been recorded from numerous sites in the Meta and Guaviare river drainages in the llanos of Colombia. It probably occurs in other areas of the Orinoco River Basin to which it is endemic.
useTrade: This species could ocasionally be harvested as an ornamental fish, but would probably be sold as the similar Hyphessobrycon metae, a name more in use in the pet trade.
conservationActions: This species is widespread in both areas impacted by human activities as well as more pristine rivers. It is ocasionally collected as an ornamental (probably identified as Hyphessobrycon metae). It is present in several protected areas.

rationale: This species is widespread in Andean piedmont of Orinoco River Basin in Venezuela and Colombia, and other habitats as well, including the Caura River drainage and present in at least one protected area. Therefore, it is classified as Least Concern.
habitat: This is a whitewater river species, most common in the muddy, moderate dissolved nutrient, rivers that drain the southern flank of the Andes in the Orinoco River Basin. It is also likely to be found in associated floodplain lagoons and marshes and swampy areas.
threats: There are no data on direct threats specific to this species, but agriculture, oil drilling and damming occur in areas from which this species has been reported.
population: There are no population data available, but the population size is assumed to be over 10,000 individuals.
range: This species is widespread and common in the Meta River drainage in Colombia, as well as in the Apure River drainage in Venezuela. It also reported from rivers of the Guyana Shield. The type locality is the Río Portuguesa drainage, río las Marias, at Quebrada  Seca, about 45 min upstream by car from Highway 5, 22 kilometers  north-north west of Guanare, Portuguesa, Venezuela.
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: There are no specific plans or regulations protecting this species.

rationale: This species is known from several different localities in Colombia, some of which are in pristine areas without significant human negative impacts. Therefore, this species is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: Most Moenkhausia are omnivores, feeding on invertebrates and plant material, and oviparous with no parental care (egg scatterers).
threats: There are no specific threats identified for this species, but urban and agricultural areas, and oil drilling, occur in the distribution area.
population: No data are available to estimate the population size but we assume, given its wide distribution, that it exceeds 10,000 individuals.
range: The type locality is the Río Manacacias into upper Río Meta, at Restrepo, Colombia. It is also reported from the Guaviare River drainage. This species is endemic to the Orinoco River Basin.
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures protecting this species.

rationale: This species is probably limited to the lower Orinoco River basin, where it replaces Pristella ariporo that occurs in the piedmont and llanos of Colombia. However, identification of museum specimens not recently reviewed are unreliable to determine the geographic limits of these two species. Even with that uncertainty about its true range, it is common and abundant in the lower Orinoco River Basin, and also reported from other neighboring countries, and so is considered Least Concern.
habitat: This species can be found in slow moving lotic habitats and lentic habitats, usually among dense aquatic vegetation. It is an oviparous omnivore, feeding on tiny invertebrates, algaes and other plant material.
threats: No specific threats to this fish are known, but urban and agricultural areas, and oil drilling, occur in the distribution area.
population: The total population is assumed to be greater than 10,000 individuals.
range: The type locality is Caño Laguna Rafael near Caicara, Orinoco basin. It has been reported from many places in South America, but may in fact be a complex of cryptic species. There are records from the Amazon and Orinoco River basins, as well as from many coastal river drainages of the Guianas and Brazil.
useTrade: This fish is in the ornamental fish trade, but no current information about its collection from the wild is available.
conservationActions: We are aware of no protective measure for this species. It does however occur in several protected areas in Venezuela, Guyana and Suriname.

rationale: Roeboides dientonito is widespread and reported in protected areas and records in museums and regional reports suggest that the population is stable. Therefore, it is evaluated as Least Concern. There are few threats to the species but some drainages (particularly coastal drainages, Maracaibo tributaries and islands) are of concern due to urban and agricultural expansion.
habitat: Roeboides dientonito inhabits a variety of streams, rivers, and lagoons in piedmonts and plains, including estuaries. It inhabits slow currents, clear or white waters on heterogeneous substrates (Taphorn 1992). The species is carnivorous (lepidophagus) and feeds on aquatics and terrestrial insects and microcrustaceans (Ortáz et al. 2003). In large rivers the species has been observed migrating seasonally. The species can reach around 72 mm in standard length. It is a species with opportunistic strategy, fecundity of 280 eggs per female and reproduction usually occurs in the wet season (Winemiller 1989, Taphorn 1992).
threats: Given its wide distribution and abundance and its apparent tolerance to various environmental stressors (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2006), there are few threats to the species. However, in some drainages a decrease in the quantity or quality of the habitat is likely in the near future due to the urban and agricultural expansion leading to the fragmentation and loss of aquatic ecosystems (see Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2011, 2018). Subpopulations of the species in drainages associated with oil exploitation, such as on the eastern coast of Maracaibo Lake and tributaries in upper Apure drainage, may also be under threat.
population: Roeboides dientonito is common in the lowlands of Orinoco basin and adjacents drainages. It is less frequent in piedmonts. In some environments (creeks, lagoons) and seasons high densities can be achieved (Winemiller 1989). In coastal drainages in Venezuela this species comprised 0.6% of relative abundance (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2011). The total population size is suspected to be greater than 10,000 individuals, given its natural abundance and broad distribution. The current population trend is considered stable.
range:
Roeboides dientonito was described from the Palmar river, Maracaibo Lake basin (Shultz 1944). The collections include many tributaries on left margin of Orinoco in Colombia and Venezuela. In Maracaibo basin it occurs in the rivers Misoa, Río Viejo, Negro, Tarra, Chama and Catatumbo. In Orinoco basin the records include the rivers Meta, Casanare, Arauca, Apure, Guárico, Morichal Largo and Orinoco delta (Taphorn 1992, Taphorn et al. 2005). It is reported in drainages to the sea: Aroa, Tocuyo, Tuy, Unare, Neverí (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2009), Paria Gulf in rivers Pilar and San Juan (Lasso et al. 2010) and Trinidad Island in rivers Guanapo and Carapo (Phillip et al. 2013). It is possibly extant in north-western Guyana where rivers drain to the Orinoco. The species is reported in 216 sites with elevation from 1-627 m above sea level.

The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated at 667,539 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around georeferenced point records. Specific threat-based locations are not counted.
