The geographic attributes for Roeboides dientonito in this assessment were compiled, arranged and reviewed from the following sources: Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF 2020), FishNet2 (Fishnet2 2020), FishBase (Froese and Pauly 2019), SiB Colombia (SiB Colombia 2020) and SpeciesLink (SpeciesLink 2020), and complemented with records from the databases of the following ichthyological collections from Colombia: CZUT-IC (Colección Zoológica, Universidad del Tolima, Ibagué), IAvH-P (Colección de Peces de Agua Dulce del Instituto de Investigación de Recursos Biológicos Alexander von Humboldt, Villa de Leyva), ICN-MHN (Instituto de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional de Colombia, Bogotá), IMCN (Colección Zoológica de Referencia Científica del Museo de Ciencias Naturales Federico Carlos Lehmann Valencia del INCIVA, Cali), and MPUJ (Museo Javeriano de Historia Natural "Lorenzo Uribe, S.J." de la Pontificia Universidad Javeriana, Bogotá), and Venezuela: MCNG (Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional Experimental de los Llanos Occidentales Ezequiel Zamora, Guanare, Venezuela) and CPUCLA (Colección Regional de Peces, Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Centroccidental Lisandro Alvarado, Barquisimeto, Venezuela).
useTrade: There are no known uses for the species, but it may be of interest to subsistence fishing for indigenous groups.
conservationActions: Conservation sites and protected areas are within the distribution (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020). The species occurs in National Parks Yurubí, Juan Crisóstomo Falcón, Cueva de la Quebrada del Toro Aguaro, Private Reserve Guáquira, Natural Monument María Lionza, Fish Reserve Caño Guaritico, Sanctuary Esteros de Camaguán. A monitoring program has been applied for habitats and their fishes, including this species, in coastal rivers in Venezuela to determine trends. This species is included in the website about freshwater fish at risk, their monitoring and conservation in coastal drainages of Venezuela (Rodríguez-Olarte and Taphorn 2007). Roeboides dientonito was assigned the category Least Concern in a regional assessment in coastal drainages of the Caribbean Sea in Venezuela (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2011). Site and habitat protection, as well as awareness raising, are recommended. Research into the status and trends in the population and habitats is recommended.

rationale: This species is known from numerous localites throughout the Orinoco River Basin. Therefore, it is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This is an inhabitant of whitewater rivers and streams, and probably also present in lentic habitats. Whitewater rivers typically have around neutral pH, low visibility, moderate dissolved minerals and nutrients and muddy bottoms.
threats: No threats specifically affecting this species have been identified, but agriculture, oil drilling, mining and damming occur in the distribution area.
population: No data are available on the population, but given its widespread distribution, the population size is assumed to be greater than 10,000 individuals.
range: This species is reported from Apure and Arauca river drainages, and the Venezuelan states of Apure, Guárico, Bolivar and Delta Amacuro. It is present in the Meta River drainage in Colombia. It is apparently present throughout the Orinoco River Basin. The type locality is Estrada San Fernando de Apure-Arichuma, rio Apure basin,  about 16 kilometers southwest of San Fernando de Apure, Apure,  Venezuela. Orinoco River basin, Venezuela.
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: There are no specific measures of protection for this species.

rationale: Cichlasoma orinocense is widely dispersed in drainages throughout of Orinoco, Caribbean and Atlantic versants. It is reported in many protected areas and has a stable trend. Therefore, it is evaluated as Least Concern. However, in the distribution there are many environmental stressors with likely negative effects on river integrity and fish populations in the near future.
habitat: Cichlasoma orinocense is common in lowlands and floodplains, and is also in piedmonts. The species inhabits lagoons, creeks, streams, rivers, swamps and estuaries. It is a tolerant species and in some circumstances it can be abundant and dominant. It is benthopelagic and littoral, typical in waters with little or no current on varied substrates. It can inhabit from pristine to depauperate environments in creeks, rivers and lagoons. It is a social fish and forms small groups. The diet consists usually of benthic invertebrates. Reproduction is periodic, with fertility around 1,287 eggs per female and a generation length of 12 months (Winemiller and Taphorn 1989).
threats: In some drainages the creeks and lagoons are affected by environmental stressors associated with the expansion of urban and agricultural frontier, for example deforestation, agrochemicals, water extraction, urban and mining effluents, and water abstraction for agricultural and subsistence uses, particularly in areas of poverty. In such environments, including the rivers Tuy, Unare, Cojedes, lagoons and reservoirs, the subpopulations of this species could be under threat.
population: Cichlasoma orinocense is common in different environments and, in some conditions, can be frequent in creeks and small lagoons. The total population size is suspected to be greater than 10,000 individuals, given its natural abundance and broad distribution. The current population trend is considered stable. In some drainages there are extensive anthropic pressures that are affecting and reducing the integrity of the aquatic ecosystems, such as Tuy and Unare (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2018), and it is possible that the subpopulations of C. orinocense in these places will decrease in the near future.
range:
The type locality for Cichlasoma orinocense is Laguna Mozambique in river Meta system (Kullander 1983). The species is widely distributed along the Orinoco river basin, from the Meta river to Orinoco delta. For Colombia the species is reported in the rivers Meta (Metica, Negro, Lake Mozambique), Tomo and Bita (Mesa-L et al. 2019); while in Venezuela it occurs in the rivers Apure (Caparo, Suripá, Masparro, Igüéz and Maraca creeks, Cojedes, Esteros de Camaguán, Caño Guaritico, reservoirs and main channel), central llanos (Aguaro, Manapire), Paria Gulf (Morichal Largo), Orinoco Delta, Guiana Shield (Caura, Ventuari, Caroní and Cuyuní) and Caribbean verstants in rivers Tuy, Unare and Neverí (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2003, 2009; Taphorn et al. 2005; Lasso et al. 2010; Lasso and Sánchez-Duarte 2011). The species is reported in 149 localities with elevation from 10-383 m above sea level.

The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated at 735,378 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around georeferenced point records. Specific threat-based locations are not counted.

The geographic attributes for Cichlasoma orinocense in this assessment were compiled, arranged and reviewed from the following sources: Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF 2020), FishNet2 (Fishnet2 2020), FishBase (Froese and Pauly 2019), SiB Colombia (SiB Colombia 2020) and SpeciesLink (SpeciesLink 2020), and complemented with records from the databases of the following ichthyological collections from Colombia: CZUT-IC (Colección Zoológica, Universidad del Tolima, Ibagué), IAvH-P (Colección de Peces de Agua Dulce del Instituto de Investigación de Recursos Biológicos Alexander von Humboldt, Villa de Leyva), ICN-MHN (Instituto de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional de Colombia, Bogotá), IMCN (Colección Zoológica de Referencia Científica del Museo de Ciencias Naturales Federico Carlos Lehmann Valencia del INCIVA, Cali), and MPUJ (Museo Javeriano de Historia Natural "Lorenzo Uribe, S.J." de la Pontificia Universidad Javeriana, Bogotá), and Venezuela: MCNG (Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional Experimental de los Llanos Occidentales Ezequiel Zamora, Guanare, Venezuela) and CPUCLA (Colección Regional de Peces, Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Centroccidental Lisandro Alvarado, Barquisimeto, Venezuela).
useTrade: The species is frequent in subsistence fisheries for indigenous and criollo groups. It has some ornamental interest.
conservationActions: There are no known laws, regulations and educational programs specifically oriented to its protection. The species is detected in conservation sites and protected areas, according to IUCN and UNEP-WCMC (2020): Ramsar EFI, National Natural Parks Tuparro, Bita, Aguaro-Guariquito and Caura and Wildlife Reserve Caño Guaritico, among others (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2003, Taphorn et al. 2004, Villa-Navarro et al. 2020). The species is probably in other protected areas, such as National Parks Santos Luzardo and Laguna de Tacarigua. Site and habitat protection, as well as awareness and communications, are recommended. Research into the population, distribution, threats and habitat is needed.

rationale: Crenicichla geayi has a wide distribution in most drainages of Orinoco and Caribbean versants, and also is registered in protected areas. The population is considered stable.  Therefore, it is evaluated as Least Concern. It is important to emphasize that in large parts of the distribution there are environmental stressors with negative effects on river integrity and therefore this species, and so local protection measures are recommended.
habitat: It usually inhabits sections of streams and backwaters of rivers (creeks, streams, rivers, swamps with currents: morichales and canaguchales). It lives in crystalline waters and heterogeneous substrates, but prefers bottom with stones and logs. It is benthopelagic and carnivorous, eating invertebrates and fish (Pearse 1920). It can reach around 400 mm in total length but is usually smaller, around 180 mm standard length (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2018). It has periodic reproduction, more frequently in the dry season, with fecundity around 230 eggs and a generation length of 12 months (Winemiller and Taphorn 1989).
threats: Crenicichla geayi is sensitive to habitat degradation. The main threats to the population occur in rivers with strong intervention (e.g. Turbio, Yaracuy, Tuy), where there is extensive contamination by urban and industrial wastewater, and removal or loss of substrate due to sedimentation (Rodríguez and Barrios 2014, Rodríguez et al. 2006). An increase in subsistence fishing in coastal drainages where the supply of river food is scarce is a potential threat.
population: Crenicichla geayi is common in plains (llanos and savannah) and piedmonts. The total population size is suspected to be greater than 10,000 individuals, given its natural abundance and broad distribution. In coastal drainages in Venezuela this species comprised 2.3% of relative abundance (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2011). The current population trend is considered stable, but in some rivers in the Orinoco basin (e.g. Torbes, Turbio), Lake Valencia and coastal drainages (e.g. Yaracuy, Tuy), there is a loss of quality and quantity of habitat which has reduced or may reduce the population of the species in the future (Rodríguez-Olarte and Barrios 2014).
range:
The type locality for Crenicichla geayi is in Venezuela (Pellegrin 1903). It is widely distributed in the lowlands and piedmonts in Orinoco River basin and Caribbean slopes. In Colombia it occurs in the rivers Orotoy, Acacías, Upía (Meta drainage) and Bita (DoNascimiento et al. 2017, Mesa-S et al. 2019). In Venezuela it is registered in the rivers Torbes, Uribante, Caparo, Portuguesa, Cojedes (Apure drainage), Guárico, Aguaro, Tigre, lower Orinoco, Cuchivero and Caura (Guiana Shield), Orinoco delta; and it also occurs in rivers to Paria Gulf (Guanipa, San Juan), Valencia Lake and Caribbean drainages: Aroa, Tocuyo, Hueque, Neverí (Taphorn et al. 2005, Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2009, Lasso et al. 2010, Lasso and Sánchez-Duarte 2011). The species is reported in 349 sites with elevation from 5-715 m above sea level.

The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated at 767,471 km2 based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around georeferenced point records. Specific threat-based locations are not counted.

The geographic attributes for Crenicichla geayi in this assessment were compiled, arranged and reviewed from the following sources: Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF 2020), FishNet2 (Fishnet2 2020), FishBase (Froese and Pauly 2019), SiB Colombia (SiB Colombia 2020) and SpeciesLink (SpeciesLink 2020), and complemented with records from the databases of the following ichthyological collections from Colombia: CZUT-IC (Colección Zoológica, Universidad del Tolima, Ibagué), IAvH-P (Colección de Peces de Agua Dulce del Instituto de Investigación de Recursos Biológicos Alexander von Humboldt, Villa de Leyva), ICN-MHN (Instituto de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional de Colombia, Bogotá), IMCN (Colección Zoológica de Referencia Científica del Museo de Ciencias Naturales Federico Carlos Lehmann Valencia del INCIVA, Cali), and MPUJ (Museo Javeriano de Historia Natural "Lorenzo Uribe, S.J." de la Pontificia Universidad Javeriana, Bogotá), and Venezuela: MCNG (Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional Experimental de los Llanos Occidentales Ezequiel Zamora, Guanare, Venezuela) and CPUCLA (Colección Regional de Peces, Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Centroccidental Lisandro Alvarado, Barquisimeto, Venezuela).
useTrade: Crenicichla geayi has ornamental interest and is common in subsistence fisheries for indigenous and criollo groups. It is an important ornamental fish in Colombia where it is subject to regulations for its fishing and commercialization (Ortega-Lara et al. 2015). This species is reported in the fluvial ports of Inírida and Villavicencio,where near 15,000 individuals of C. geayi were commercialized in 2013 (Ortega-Lara et al. 2015).
conservationActions: The species was assigned the category Least Concern in a regional assessment in drainages towards the Caribbean Sea in Venezuela (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2011). This species is included in the website about freshwater fish at risk, their monitoring and conservation in coastal drainages of Venezuela (Rodríguez-Olarte and Taphorn 2007). Conservation sites and protected areas are within its distribution (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020). In Colombia the species is registered in Bita and EFI Ramsar sites, Lipa wetlands (Arauca), National Natural Park El Tuparro and Reserva Bojonawi (Mesa et al. 2019, Villa-Navarro et al. 2020). In Venezuela the species is reported in National Parks El Tamá, Yurubí, Guatopo, Tucuragua, Aguaro-Guariquito and Caura, Natural Monument María Lionza and its presence is expected in National Park Santos Luzardo, Refuge Esteros de Chiriguare and Esteros de Camaguán (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2003, 2015). Site and habitat protection in specific drainages (e.g. Yaracuy, Tuy), as well as awareness and communications, is recommended. Research into the population, distribution, threats and habitat is recommended.

rationale: This species has a large distribution area, is present in several protected areas, and is abundant where it occurs. Therefore, it is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This tiny nearly transparent, oviparous South American darter lives on sand bars in large and small rivers. It is epibenthic and feeds on invertebrates.
threats: No threats specifically affecting this species have been identified, but agrictultural and urban areas, oil drilling and mining, all with related pollution, and damming occur within the distribution area.
population: There are no data with which to evaluate the population status of this species but expect the population to be stable.
range: The type locality is Gluck Island, Essequibo River, Guyana. This species is reported from the Essequibo in Guyana and Maroni River basin, which forms the border between Suriname and French Guiana. It is also reported from throughout the Orinoco River Basin in Colombia and Venezuela. It is also widespread in the Amazon River Basin in Ecuador, Peru, Brazil.
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: This species is not specifically protected.

rationale: Rhinodoras gallagheri is listed as Least Concern because it is widely distributed, occurs in protected areas, and considered to have a stable population.
habitat: The habitat of Rhinodoras gallagheri in the Apure river has clear and white waters with high dissolved solids on sandy bottoms. This species is a benthic and nocturnal fish. The fishes of the Rhinodoras genus are usually insectivorous and feed on Trichoptera and Chironomidae (de Lima et al. 2016). The species can reach 117.4 mm of standard length (Sabaj et al. 2008).
threats: The habitat of the species is at risk of fragmentation and loss due to the deposition of sediments associated with the transformation of channels, erosion of slopes, and deforestation in high Andean basins (Winemiller et al. 1996, Oliveira-Miranda et al. 2010). Oil exploitation is a threat in the Andean plains of Colombia and Venezuela.
population: Rhinodoras gallagheri is not a common species, but it is widely dispersed, and is therefore suspected of having a large population (> 10,000 individuals) and stable trend.
range:
Rhinodoras gallagheri was described from Apure, between Portuguesa river mouth and San Fernando de Apure airport, Apure state, Venezuela (Sabaj et al. 2008). The species is distributed along the middle section of the Orinoco basin, in western tributaries in Colombia and Venezuela: Guayabero, Losada, Guaviare, Meta, Arauca, Capanaparo, Portuguesa, Apure and Boconó, among others. The species is distributed in a range of elevations from 36-246 meters above sea level.

The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated at 158,698 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around georeferenced point records.

The geographic attributes for Rhinodoras gallagheri in this assessment were compiled, arranged and reviewed from the following sources: Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF 2020), FishNet2 (Fishnet2 2020), FishBase (Froese and Pauly 2019), SiB Colombia (SiB Colombia 2020) and SpeciesLink (SpeciesLink 2020), and complemented with records from the databases of the following ichthyological collections from Colombia: CZUT-IC (Colección Zoológica, Universidad del Tolima, Ibagué), IAvH-P (Colección de Peces de Agua Dulce del Instituto de Investigación de Recursos Biológicos Alexander von Humboldt, Villa de Leyva), ICN-MHN (Instituto de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional de Colombia, Bogotá), IMCN (Colección Zoológica de Referencia Científica del Museo de Ciencias Naturales Federico Carlos Lehmann Valencia del INCIVA, Cali), and MPUJ (Museo Javeriano de Historia Natural "Lorenzo Uribe, S.J." de la Pontificia Universidad Javeriana, Bogotá), and MCNG (Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional Experimental de los Llanos Occidentales Ezequiel Zamora, Guanare, Venezuela) and CPUCLA (Colección Regional de Peces, Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Centroccidental Lisandro Alvarado, Barquisimeto, Venezuela).
useTrade: There are no known uses for the species Rhinodoras gallagheri.
conservationActions: Rhinodoras gallagheri is not subject to laws or regulations oriented for its specific protection. The species is reported in the following protected areas: Parque Nacional Natural Sierra de la Macarena and Santos Luzardo (Capanaparo-Cinaruco), and Wildlife Refuge Esteros de Chiriguare (DoNascimiento et al. 2018, IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020). Generation of adequate laws surrounding the species is recommended. It is necessary to research and monitor the trends of the population and threats to the species.

rationale: This species is widely distributed in the Amazon forest lowlands in sparsely populated areas. It is harvested only near a few major cities, with most of its range unaffected by most human impacts. Therefore, it is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species is found in small, shaded and shallow forested streams in the forest. It is an oviparous insectivore that feeds at the water's surface. It is capable of leaping from the water to capture flying insects. The subpopulation from Bolivia, according to Gery (1977), is deeper bodied than the Peruvian Amazon subpopulation.
threats: No threats specifically affecting this species have been identified, but there are agricultural and urban areas, and oil drilling, within the range of the species. It is also harvested for the aquarium trade, although only near a few major cities.
population: Given its natural abundance and huge distribution area, the total population size is suspected to be greater than 10,000 individuals. The current population trend is probably stable.
range: This species lives in lowland streams of the western Amazon River basin: Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, Bolivia, and Brazil. The type locality is a creek near Yurimaguas, Peru in the upper Amazon River Basin.
useTrade: This species is in the aquarium fish pet trade.
conservationActions: No information is available on conservation plans for the species, but it does occur in some protected areas.

rationale: The distribution of Chaetostoma formosae is restricted to piedmont and mountain rivers and the Meta and Guaviare drainages, where it is usually common. Some rivers in the wide extension of occurrence of the species are well-preserved, however, a number of pervasive threats exist in several drainages associated with the expansion of the agricultural and urban frontiers, including deforestation, land-use change, sedimentation and urban effluents. This is resulting in a continuing decline in habitat. The area of occupancy (AOO) is best estimated at 1,312 km². There are 2–4 threat-based locations. Therefore, Chaetostoma formosae is assessed as Vulnerable.
habitat: This is an obligate inhabitant of fast-flowing, sometimes high gradient, headwater streams and minor tributaries. Substrates are normally of bedrock with scattered jumbles of rocks and boulders, and while riparian vegetation and submerged leaf litter are common, true aquatic plants are not usually present. The most favourable habitats contain clear, well-oxygenated water, which facilitates the development of a rich biofilm carpeting submerged surfaces, although turbidity, volume, and chemistry can change rapidly and often due to sometimes daily rainfall (Ballen 2011). It is possible that it has a periodic reproductive strategy associated with the rainy season. Chaetostoma formosae can reach 102.6 mm standard length (Ballen 2011).
threats: The habitat for Chaetostoma formosae is threatened by progressive degradation in several drainages resulting from deforestation, primarily for oil palm crops and oil exploitation. There are many urban centres (e.g. Villavicencio, Yopal) in the distribution that discharge effluents to rivers. Land-use change within these catchments is likely to alter hydrology, sediment transport, and habitat conditions within river systems, with adverse consequences for aquatic biodiversity  (Romero-Ruíz et al. 2012, Urbano et al. 2014).
population: The population of Chaetostoma formosae is considered stable in accord with its abundance. The size of the population is considered to be large.
range:
Chaetostoma formosae was described from Chuy creek, affluent to river Upía, upper Meta river basin, Colombia (Ballen 2011). The species is known from western piedmont streams within the upper Guaviare yo upper Meta drainage systems. The records include rivers Orotoy, Acacías, Guayuriba, Cusiana, Guatiquía, Caney, Camoa and Guejar, among others (Usma et al. 2016, DoNascimiento et al. 2018, Urbano-Bonilla et al. 2018). The species is distributed in a range of elevations from 122 to 1,414 m above sea level.

The extent of occurrence (EOO) is best estimated at 32,989 km², and the area of occupancy (AOO) is best estimated at 1,312 km². There are 2–4 threat-based locations.

The geographic attributes for Chaetostoma formosae in this assessment were compiled, arranged and reviewed from the following sources: Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF 2020), FishNet2 (Fishnet2 2020), FishBase (Froese and Pauly 2019), SiB Colombia (SiB Colombia 2020) and SpeciesLink (SpeciesLink 2020), and complemented with records from the databases of the following ichthyological collections from Colombia: CZUT-IC (Colección Zoológica, Universidad del Tolima, Ibagué), IAvH-P (Colección de Peces de Agua Dulce del Instituto de Investigación de Recursos Biológicos Alexander von Humboldt, Villa de Leyva), ICN-MHN (Instituto de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional de Colombia, Bogotá), IMCN (Colección Zoológica de Referencia Científica del Museo de Ciencias Naturales Federico Carlos Lehmann Valencia del INCIVA, Cali), and MPUJ (Museo Javeriano de Historia Natural "Lorenzo Uribe, S.J." de la Pontificia Universidad Javeriana, Bogotá).
useTrade: There are no known uses for the species
conservationActions: There are some conservations sites and protected areas that cover sections of the rivers where the species Chaetostoma formosae is reported (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020): National Natural Park Sierra de la Macarena and DMI Ariari-Guayabero. Habitat protection in the most impacted drainages is recommended, as well as awareness and communications. It is necessary to research the actual conditions and trends for the population size and distribution, threats and habitat.

rationale: Dentectus barbamatus inhabits different environments throughout the rivers in lowlands of Orinoco basin. The species has a stable populations. Therefore, it is evaluated as Least Concern.
habitat: Dentectus barbamatus usually inhabits white and black waters in rivers with heterogeneous parameters on soft and sandy bottoms. It is herbivorous and can reach up to 141.6 mm standard length.
threats: Dentectus barbamatus is affected in localized areas along its western distribution area in premontane and plains in Andean region due to deforestation, agriculture and the oil industry (Winemiller et al. 1996, Etter et al. 2006).
population: It is a species with a wide distribution but it is not common in the collections. The current population trend is probably stable, but no data are available.
range:
Dentectus barbarmatus was described from Salinas river, a tributary of Portuguesa river in Orinoco drainage (Martín Salazar et al. 1982). It is widely distributed along the entire Orinoco basin, from western Andean tributaries to the lower section of the main river channel, close to the Orinoco delta. In Colombia the species occur in the rivers Metica, Cravo Sur, Ariporo, Guacharía, Cusiana, Chire, Meta and wetlands in llanos. From Venezuela the records are in the upper, middle and lower Orinoco, tributaries in Andean drainages (e.g. Masparro, Boconó and Guanare), Guiana Shield drainages (Cuchivero) and Orinoco delta. The species is distributed in a range of elevations from 13-184 meters above sea level.

The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated at 461,860 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around georeferenced point records.

The geographic attributes for Dentectus barbarmatus in this assessment were compiled, arranged and reviewed from the following sources: Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF 2020), FishNet2 (Fishnet2 2020), FishBase (Froese and Pauly 2019), SiB Colombia (SiB Colombia 2020) and SpeciesLink (SpeciesLink 2020), and complemented with records from the databases of the following ichthyological collections from Colombia: CZUT-IC (Colección Zoológica, Universidad del Tolima, Ibagué), IAvH-P (Colección de Peces de Agua Dulce del Instituto de Investigación de Recursos Biológicos Alexander von Humboldt, Villa de Leyva), ICN-MHN (Instituto de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional de Colombia, Bogotá), IMCN (Colección Zoológica de Referencia Científica del Museo de Ciencias Naturales Federico Carlos Lehmann Valencia del INCIVA, Cali), and MPUJ (Museo Javeriano de Historia Natural "Lorenzo Uribe, S.J." de la Pontificia Universidad Javeriana, Bogotá), and MCNG (Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional Experimental de los Llanos Occidentales Ezequiel Zamora, Guanare, Venezuela) and CPUCLA (Colección Regional de Peces, Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Centroccidental Lisandro Alvarado, Barquisimeto, Venezuela).
useTrade: There are no known uses for the species
conservationActions: Dentectus barbamatus is not subject to laws or regulations oriented for its specific protection. The species is reported in the following protected areas: National Parks Yapacana, Delta del Orinoco and Biosphere Reserve of the Orinoco Delta (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020). Habitat protection in the most impacted drainages is recommended, as well as awareness and communications. It is necessary to research the actual conditions and trends for the population size and distribution, threats and habitat.

rationale: Farlowella acus is classified as Vulnerable. The distribution of F. acus is restricted to streams in upper plains and piedmonts in two separate areas: tributaries to Valencia Lake and upper Meta and Guaviare systems, both drainages with different conservation statuses but with bad prognosis for the species. Human intervention is increasing in the Meta and Guaviare drainages, but there are still conserved tributaries and protected areas that can satisfy protection measures for the species. The most critical situation is in the Lake Valencia drainage, where the expansion of the agro-industries and cities affects all tributaries and there are no mitigation measures. The area of occupancy (AOO) is best estimated at 1,308 km2 and there are 2-4 threat-based locations based on these threats, which are causing a continuing decline in the habitat. There are no protected areas for the habitat for the Farlowella acus. Urgent measures are recommended for the protection of the species, which should include general assessment of the habitat and population, as well as the restoration of the habitat.
habitat: Species of Farlowella inhabit piedmont rivers and usually live in small rivers with moderate currents in heterogeneous substrates and with the presence of plants (branches, leaves, roots) on the banks, where they find refuge among the branches and leaves that it frequents. Farlowella species are herbivores that eat algae (e.g. Bacillariophyceae) and have moderate fecundity (García-Alzate et al. 2012). Reproduction is believed to occur during the rainy season.
threats: Habitat degradation is widespread in most piedmonts where the species inhabits. Several environmental stressors threaten the heterogeneity and availability of the habitat of specie. In many tributaries of the Lake Valencia drainage water pollution is widespread, and combined with the destruction of channels and the deforestation of riverbank areas this has eliminated much of the fish richness and diversity (see López-Rojas and Bonilla-Rivero 2000). In the Meta and Guaviare drainages, the piedmonts are more conserved, but the expansion of human frontier is rapid with negative effects on the rivers.
population: There are no data available to estimate the population size. The population trend is decreasing, but this is principally occuring in the Lake Valencia drainage where there is extreme habitat loss.
range:
Farlowella acus was described from Caracas in Venezuela (Kner 1853). The species has a disjunct distribution and the subpopulations are widely separated: in Venezuela one subpopulation is restricted to tributaries in Lake Valencia drainage (rivers Vigirima, Limón, Guayos, Aragua) and adjacent Torito river in Orinoco drainage (Retzer and Page 1996), and another subpopulation is in Colombia, distributed along the tributaries of the upper Meta and probably Guaviare (rivers Ariari, Camoa, Humea, Guayabero). Records from Guiana Shield and lower Orinoco are not considered valid until specimens can be verified. The species is reported in 42 sites with elevation from 300-545 m above sea level.

The extent of occurrence (EOO) is best estimated at 70,212 km2, and the area of occupancy (AOO) is best estimated at 1,308 km2. There are 2-4 threat-based locations.

The geographic attributes for Farlowella acus in this assessment were compiled, arranged and reviewed from the following sources: Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF 2020), FishNet2 (Fishnet2 2020), FishBase (Froese and Pauly 2019), SiB Colombia (SiB Colombia 2020) and SpeciesLink (SpeciesLink 2020), and complemented with records from the databases of the following ichthyological collections from Colombia: CZUT-IC (Colección Zoológica, Universidad del Tolima, Ibagué), IAvH-P (Colección de Peces de Agua Dulce del Instituto de Investigación de Recursos Biológicos Alexander von Humboldt, Villa de Leyva), ICN-MHN (Instituto de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional de Colombia, Bogotá), IMCN (Colección Zoológica de Referencia Científica del Museo de Ciencias Naturales Federico Carlos Lehmann Valencia del INCIVA, Cali), and MPUJ (Museo Javeriano de Historia Natural "Lorenzo Uribe, S.J." de la Pontificia Universidad Javeriana, Bogotá), and Venezuela: MCNG (Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional Experimental de los Llanos Occidentales Ezequiel Zamora, Guanare, Venezuela) and CPUCLA (Colección Regional de Peces, Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Centroccidental Lisandro Alvarado, Barquisimeto, Venezuela).
useTrade: Farlowella fish are important as aquarium fish (Ortega-Lara et al. 2015), but it is unknown if this species is used.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation plans for the species, and there are no conservations sites and protected areas that cover sections of the rivers where Farlowella acus is reported (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020). Habitat protection in the most impacted drainages and awareness at several educative levels is recommended. It is necessary to research the taxonomy of the Farlowella acus group, as well as trends for the population, threats and habitat.

rationale: This species has a wide distribution in the Orinoco basin, including in well preserved habitats and in protected areas. Nevertheless, in various sectors of piedmonts in Orinoco basin there is an accelerated process of depauperation of the rivers and their surroundings, which should be considered in the future. At present, this species is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: Farlowella mariaelenae inhabits usually in streams and rivers in piedmonts and plains. It is associated with heterogeneous substrates, principally gravel, stones and submerged plants (branches, leaves, roots) on the banks and littorals. The species reaches about 167 mm in standard length. Farlowella fishes are herbivores that eat algae. The females have moderate fecundity and the reproduction is possibly in the rainy season (García-Alzate et al. 2012).
threats: The habitat of Farlowella mariaelenae is subject to different stressors, principally in some drainages in Andean piedmonts and upper plains, where human intervention is expanding rapidly. However, there are still several protected areas and watersheds that have good conditions. The principal human stressors are deforestation, water extraction and pollution of waters (see Romero-Ruíz et al. 2012, Lasso et al. 2016).
population: The population size and trend of Farlowella mariaelenae are unknown. Subpopulations are fragmented due to natural causes. The species has low abundance in Cusiana river, Meta drainage (Urbano-Bonilla et al. 2014).
range:
Farlowella mariaelenae was described from the río Salinas, tributary of Pao Viejo river, north-eastern El Baúl, Cojedes state in Venezuela (Martín Salazar 1964). The species occur in Venezuela and Colombia in separate regions: upper Meta and Guaviare drainages (rivers Guayabero, Metica, Upía, Negro, Pauto, Manacacías, Güejar) (DoNascimiento et al. 2018), Apure drainage (rivers Apure, Caparo, Paguey, Masparro, Maraca, Portuguesa, Santo Domingo, Pao) Guárico (rivers Guárico, Orituco), Guiana Shield (rivers Caura, Nichare, Manapiare, Ventuari, Mavaca), lower Orinoco (rivers Tigre, Guanipa, Amana) and tributaries in San Juan drainage (Retzer and Page 1997, Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2003, Taphorn et al. 2004). The records for the Caribbean slope (Turiamo) and Valencia Lake are considered doubtful. The species is reported in 184 sites with elevation from 22-485 m above sea level.

The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated at 788,308 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around georeferenced point records. Specific threat-based locations are not counted.

The geographic attributes for Farlowella mariaelenae in this assessment were compiled, arranged and reviewed from the following sources: Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF 2020), FishNet2 (Fishnet2 2020), FishBase (Froese and Pauly 2019), SiB Colombia (SiB Colombia 2020) and SpeciesLink (SpeciesLink 2020), and complemented with records from the databases of the following ichthyological collections from Colombia: CZUT-IC (Colección Zoológica, Universidad del Tolima, Ibagué), IAvH-P (Colección de Peces de Agua Dulce del Instituto de Investigación de Recursos Biológicos Alexander von Humboldt, Villa de Leyva), ICN-MHN (Instituto de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional de Colombia, Bogotá), IMCN (Colección Zoológica de Referencia Científica del Museo de Ciencias Naturales Federico Carlos Lehmann Valencia del INCIVA, Cali), and MPUJ (Museo Javeriano de Historia Natural "Lorenzo Uribe, S.J." de la Pontificia Universidad Javeriana, Bogotá), and Venezuela: MCNG (Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional Experimental de los Llanos Occidentales Ezequiel Zamora, Guanare, Venezuela) and CPUCLA (Colección Regional de Peces, Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Centroccidental Lisandro Alvarado, Barquisimeto, Venezuela).
useTrade: Farlowella mariaelenae has ornamental interest and is in the commercial trade. It is subject to regulations for its fishing and commercialization in Colombia (Ortega-Lara et al. 2015). The total volume of harvest is unknown.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation plans for the species, but there conservations sites and protected areas where Farlowella acus is registered (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020): National Natural Park Sierra de la Macarena (Colombia), Forest Reserve Caparo, Wildlife Reserves Sabanas de Anaro and Esteros de Chiriguare, National Park Aguaro-Guariquito, Forest Reserve Sipapo, National Park Parima-Tapirapecó (Venezuela).Habitat protection in the most impacted drainages is recommended. Research into the taxonomy of group, as well as monitoring of the population and habitats, is recommended.

rationale: Farlowella vittata is assessed as Least Concern based on its wide distribution, abundance and presence in various protected areas and conserved rivers. Nevertheless, in addition to human impacts in many drainages (e.g. piedmonts), it has important value in the ornamental fishing, which shows a high extraction rate from natural environments.
habitat: The species inhabits creeks, stream and rivers in plains (lagoons, swamps, morichales, cananguchales) and piedmonts on heterogeneous waters and substrates with branches, leaves or roots on the banks and littorals. The species reaches 224 mm in standard length. In Güejar river the species feeds mainly algae and phyto and zooplankton. The females reach sexual maturity at 154 mm SL and reproduced in high water season with a fecundity of 1,819 eggs (García-Alzate et al. 2012).
threats: The habitat of Farlowella vittata is heterogeneous, suggesting few threats specific for the species. However, human stressors primarily related to agriculture occur in the Andean piedmonts of Guaviare, Meta and Apure drainages. Fishing for ornamental purposes is considered a very important threat (García-Alzate et al. 2012), as well as gold mining in Guiana Shield.
population: Data are unavailable to estimate the total population size, but the population of Farlowella vittata is considered to have a stable trend regarding given its abundance and wide distribution throughout the Orinoco basin and neighboring drainages. The species has moderate abundance in creeks and rivers in Cusiana system, Meta drainage (Urbano-Bonilla et al. 2014).
range:
Farlowella vittata was described to Uribante river in Apure drainage, Táchira state in Venezuela (Myers 1942). The species occurs in Colombia and Venezuela tributaries throughout of the Orinoco river drainage, and also in small drainages flowing to the sea. In Colombia the species occurs in rivers Ariari, Guayabero (Guaviare drainage), Cusiana, Cravo Sur, Upía, Laguna Manacacías, and Orotoy (Meta drainage) (Usma et al. 2016, DoNascimiento et al. 2018). In Venezuela the records include the rivers Quinimarí, Canaguá, Masparro, Guanare, Apure polders, Yacambú, Cinaruco, creeks in floodplains (Apure drainage) Orituco, Aguaro, Pao, Mocapra, morichales, cananguchales, Amana, Caris, Uracoa (Guárico and eastern llanos), Guanipa, Cristalino, San juan (slopes to Paria Gulf), upper Orinoco, Ocamo, Ventuari, Cataniapo, Parguaza, Caura, Orocopiche, Caroní (Guiana Shield) and southern Orinoco delta (Retzer and Page 1996, Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2003, Taphorn et al. 2004, Lasso et al. 2010, Lasso and Sánchez-Duarte 2011). The species is reported in 606 sites with elevation from 26-773 m above sea level.

The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated at 918,275 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around georeferenced point records. Specific threat-based locations are not counted.

The geographic attributes for Farlowella vittata in this assessment were compiled, arranged and reviewed from the following sources: Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF 2020), FishNet2 (Fishnet2 2020), FishBase (Froese and Pauly 2019), SiB Colombia (SiB Colombia 2020) and SpeciesLink (SpeciesLink 2020), and complemented with records from the databases of the following ichthyological collections from Colombia: CZUT-IC (Colección Zoológica, Universidad del Tolima, Ibagué), IAvH-P (Colección de Peces de Agua Dulce del Instituto de Investigación de Recursos Biológicos Alexander von Humboldt, Villa de Leyva), ICN-MHN (Instituto de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional de Colombia, Bogotá), IMCN (Colección Zoológica de Referencia Científica del Museo de Ciencias Naturales Federico Carlos Lehmann Valencia del INCIVA, Cali), and MPUJ (Museo Javeriano de Historia Natural "Lorenzo Uribe, S.J." de la Pontificia Universidad Javeriana, Bogotá), and Venezuela: MCNG (Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional Experimental de los Llanos Occidentales Ezequiel Zamora, Guanare, Venezuela) and CPUCLA (Colección Regional de Peces, Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Centroccidental Lisandro Alvarado, Barquisimeto, Venezuela).
useTrade: Farlowella vittata is very important as an ornamental fish in Colombia, including its export. The species is subject to regulations for its fishing and commercialization (Ortega-Lara et al. 2015). It is reported in various ports in Inírida, Puerto Carreño and Villavicencio, and in this last center more than 140,000 individuals of the species were commercialized in 2013 (Ortega-Lara et al. 2015).
conservationActions: There are known laws and programs about ornamental fishing of species in Colombia (Ortega-Lara et al. 2015) but no conservation plans. There are conservations sites and protected areas where Farlowella acus is registered (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020): Natural Reserve Nukak, National Parks Sierra de la Macarena (Colombia), El Tamá, Forest Reserve Caparo, Aguaro-Guariquito, Yapacana, Parima-Tapirapecó, Caura, Wildlife Reserves Esteros de Chiriguare and Caño Guariquito. Habitat protection in the most impacted drainages is recommended, as well as regulation and monitoring of the fishery. Research into the taxonomy of group, as well as the monitoring of threats, the population and habitats, is recommended.

rationale: Lamontichthys llanero is assessed as Least Concern based mainly on its large distribution, abundance and presence in various rivers and habitats with good conservation status, including one protected area. Nevertheless, in addition to there being human impacts in many drainages (e.g. piedmonts), ornamental fishing shows a high extraction rate from natural environments, and represents a threat to the species.
habitat: Lamontichthys llanero inhabits creeks, stream and rivers in the transition zone between piedmonts, upper plains and floodplains. The species inhabits moderate currents with clear or white waters (muddy waters) and substrates with predominance of mud, sand, gravel and stones (Taphorn and Lilyestrom 1984, de Carvalho Paixão and Toledo-Piza 2009). It is also in lentic habitats, lagoons, and polders (módulos de Apure). In Colombia the reproduction is in synchronous with climate and the average of fecundity is 204 eggs (Ortega-Lara et al. 2015).
threats: The habitat of Lamontichthys llanero is heterogeneous and widespread throughout the Orinoco basin. It is possible that the species could be tolerant to certain stressors (e.g. sedimentation). However, there are many rivers with high environmental and human impacts (e.g. agro-industrial effluents, dams) in piedmonts and upper llanos (e.g. Acarigua, Cojedes). In addition, the ornamental fishery represents a significant threat to the species because it reduces the population.
population: Data are unavailable to estimate the total population size of Lamontichthys llanero, but the population of this species is considered likely to have a stable trend given its abundance in samples and wide distribution in Andean drainages in Orinoco basin.
range:
Lamontichthys llanero was described in Guanare Viejo river, tributary of Portuguesa river in Apure drainage of Venezuela (Taphorn and Lilyestrom 1984). The species occurs in Colombia and Venezuela tributaries throughout of the Orinoco river drainage. In Colombia the species is registered in rivers Guayabero, Duda (Guaviare), Negro, Metica, Cravo Sur, Tocaria, Casanare, and Orotoy (Meta) (DoNascimiento et al. 2018). In Venezuela it occurs in rivers Arauca, Santo Domingo, Boconó, Masparro, Guanare, Acarigua, lagoons in floodplains, Portuguesa (Apure), Orituco, Manapire, Santa Elena island (Orinoco medio), and Caura (Taphorn and Lilyestrom 1984, Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2003, Paixão and Toledo-Piza 2009). The species is reported in 73 localities with elevation from 50-300 m above sea level.

The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated at 336,247 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around georeferenced point records. Specific threat-based locations are not counted.

The geographic attributes for Lamontichthys llanero in this assessment were compiled, arranged and reviewed from the following sources: Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF 2020), FishNet2 (Fishnet2 2020), FishBase (Froese and Pauly 2019), SiB Colombia (SiB Colombia 2020) and SpeciesLink (SpeciesLink 2020), and complemented with records from the databases of the following ichthyological collections from Colombia: CZUT-IC (Colección Zoológica, Universidad del Tolima, Ibagué), IAvH-P (Colección de Peces de Agua Dulce del Instituto de Investigación de Recursos Biológicos Alexander von Humboldt, Villa de Leyva), ICN-MHN (Instituto de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional de Colombia, Bogotá), IMCN (Colección Zoológica de Referencia Científica del Museo de Ciencias Naturales Federico Carlos Lehmann Valencia del INCIVA, Cali), and MPUJ (Museo Javeriano de Historia Natural "Lorenzo Uribe, S.J." de la Pontificia Universidad Javeriana, Bogotá), and Venezuela: MCNG (Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional Experimental de los Llanos Occidentales Ezequiel Zamora, Guanare, Venezuela) and CPUCLA (Colección Regional de Peces, Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Centroccidental Lisandro Alvarado, Barquisimeto, Venezuela).
useTrade: Lamontichthys llanero is common as an ornamental fish in Colombia and is usually transported from rivers where it is caught by artisanal fishing to ports Puerto Carreño, in Orinoco river, and Villavicencio in Meta (Ortega-Lara et al. 2015). Lamontichthys llanero is currently shipped out of Colombia.
conservationActions: There are known laws and programs about ornamental fishing including the species Lamontichthys llanero (Ortega-Lara et al. 2015) but no conservation plans. There are various conservation sites in its distribution but the National Park Sierra de la Macarena is the unique protected area where L. llanero is registered (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020, DoNascimiento et al. 2018). Habitat protection in the most impacted drainages is recommended, as well as regulation and monitoring of its fishery. Research into the threats, population and habitats, principally in drainages where this is ornamental fishing, is recommended.

rationale: Parotocinclus eppleyi is evaluated as Least Concern. This species has a stable population along the upper and middle Orinoco lowlands, including the upper Meta. However, the habitat of this species is subject to progressive impacts by environmental stressors, which require further evaluation.
habitat: Parotocinclus eppleyi occurs in creeks and swamps (morichales, cananguchales), streams and rivers in lowlands in the upper and middle Orinoco, but also in the upper Guaviare and Meta. The habitats have clear or black water with moderate currents on sandy bottoms mixed with aquatics plants and roots (Sanabria-Ochoa et al. 2007). The fishes of the genus Parotocinclus are known as detritivores. The species can reach around 30 mm in standard length.
threats: No specific threats are known to this species. However, in the upper Meta, the habitat of the species is affected by deforestation, agricultural expansion and the oil industry, while in rivers of the Guiana Shield (e.g. Atabapo, Ventuari) gold mining is a developing threat (Rodríguez et al. 2007, Lasso et al. 2016).
population: The current population trend is probably stable, but no data are available.
range:
Parotocinclus eppleyi was described from creek Cucurito in Autana drainage, Amazonas, Venezuela (Schaefer and Provenzano 1993). The species is distributed in tributaries of the upper and middle sections of the Orinoco basin. In Colombia, it occurs in rivers Bita, Matavén, Tomo, Meta, and Juriepe. In Venezuela, the records are for rivers Sipapo, Autana, Ventuari, Manapiare, middle Orinoco, Parguaza, and Cinaruco. The species is distributed in a range of elevations from 25-218 meters above sea level.

The extent of occurrence (EOO) is very wide, estimated to be 239,274 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around georeferenced point records.

The geographic attributes for Parotocinclus eppleyi in this assessment were compiled, arranged and reviewed from the following sources: Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF 2020), FishNet2 (Fishnet2 2020), FishBase (Froese and Pauly 2019), SiB Colombia (SiB Colombia 2020) and SpeciesLink (SpeciesLink 2020), and complemented with records from the databases of the following ichthyological collections from Colombia: CZUT-IC (Colección Zoológica, Universidad del Tolima, Ibagué), IAvH-P (Colección de Peces de Agua Dulce del Instituto de Investigación de Recursos Biológicos Alexander von Humboldt, Villa de Leyva), ICN-MHN (Instituto de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional de Colombia, Bogotá), IMCN (Colección Zoológica de Referencia Científica del Museo de Ciencias Naturales Federico Carlos Lehmann Valencia del INCIVA, Cali), and MPUJ (Museo Javeriano de Historia Natural "Lorenzo Uribe, S.J." de la Pontificia Universidad Javeriana, Bogotá), and MCNG (Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional Experimental de los Llanos Occidentales Ezequiel Zamora, Guanare, Venezuela) and CPUCLA (Colección Regional de Peces, Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Centroccidental Lisandro Alvarado, Barquisimeto, Venezuela).
useTrade: This species has ornamental importance (Ortega-Lara et al. 2015).
conservationActions: Parotocinclus eppleyi is included in resolutions for ornamental fish in Colombia (Ortega-Lara et al. 2015). The species occurs in several protected areas in the Orinoco basin (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020): National Natural Park Sierra de la Macarena, DNMI Cinaruco, Ramsar sites Río Bita and EFI, Bojonawi Reserve in Colombia (Maldonado and Bogotá 2007, Córdoba et al. 2016, Villa-Navarro et al. 2017, 2020) and National Parks Yapacana and Capanaparo-Cinaruco in Venezuela (Lasso et al. 2006, Montaña et al. 2010). Habitat protection in the most impacted drainages and awareness raising are recommended. For the research it is necessary to look into trends in the population, threats and habitat.

rationale: The data in biological collections and regional reports do not suggest a reduction in the population of the species. In addition, many rivers where the species inhabits are in a good conservation status or are sheltered by protected areas. Therefore, it is evaluated as Least Concern. However, it is important to recognize the advance of deforestation, contamination and the extraction of water directly from rivers for human and agricultural consumption in various densely populated drainages.
habitat: Parodon apolinari inhabits streams and backwaters with rocky substrates, but also sandy bottoms. Epibenthic and herbivorous, it feeds on algae and eventually on aquatic insects (Taphorn 1992). In certain rivers the species could have an important role in both spatial heterogeneity and benthic diversity (Flecker and Taylor 2004). It possibly has a periodic reproductive strategy associated with the rainy season. Males have snout structures (Myers 1930) and develop a filament in the first radius of the dorsal fin, probably during courtship. It can be 180 mm in standard length, but is usually smaller.
threats: Most drainages where Parodon apolinari occurs are well-preserved forest sections of creeks and rivers in piedmonts and mountains. However, there are environmental stressors in some drainages and rivers, principally the deforestation of the headwaters and riparian zones, extraction of water, transformation of fluvial channels and agro-industrial effluents (e.g. Winemiller et al. 1996, Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2006). This is evident in the drainages of more urbanized piedmonts and mountains, such as Andes and coastal ranges.
population: Given the natural abundance and broad distribution of Parodon apolinari, the size of the population must be large but there are no data available to estimate the population size. This species comprised around 0.5% of relative abundance in Andean piedmonts of Orinoco (Usma 2000) and 3.1% in coastal drainages in Venezuela (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2011). The current population trend is stable.
range:
Parodon apolinari was described from Guavio River in Orinoco basin, Colombia (Schultz 1944). The species occurs in Andean ranges of Colombia and Venezuela in the Orinoco river basin and coastal drainages to the Caribbean Sea in Venezuela. In the Orinoco basin it inhabits rivers Ariari, Guayabero (Guaviare), Cravo Sur, Cusiana, Sardinata, Pauto (Meta), Caparo, Acequia, Guanare, Morador, Cojedes (Apure), Morichal Cascón, Agua Blanca (Guárico), Tocuyo, Aroa, Yaracuy, and Urama (coastal drainages) (Taphorn 1992, Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2009, Londoño-Burbano et al. 2010). The species is reported in 278 sites with elevation from 37-1,042 m above sea level.

The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated at 399,962 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around georeferenced point records. Specific threat-based locations are not counted.

The geographic attributes for Parodon apolinari in this assessment were compiled, arranged and reviewed from the following sources: Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF 2020), FishNet2 (Fishnet2 2020), FishBase (Froese and Pauly 2019), SiB Colombia (SiB Colombia 2020) and SpeciesLink (SpeciesLink 2020), and complemented with records from the databases of the following ichthyological collections from Colombia: CZUT-IC (Colección Zoológica, Universidad del Tolima, Ibagué), IAvH-P (Colección de Peces de Agua Dulce del Instituto de Investigación de Recursos Biológicos Alexander von Humboldt, Villa de Leyva), ICN-MHN (Instituto de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional de Colombia, Bogotá), IMCN (Colección Zoológica de Referencia Científica del Museo de Ciencias Naturales Federico Carlos Lehmann Valencia del INCIVA, Cali), and MPUJ (Museo Javeriano de Historia Natural "Lorenzo Uribe, S.J." de la Pontificia Universidad Javeriana, Bogotá), and Venezuela: MCNG (Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional Experimental de los Llanos Occidentales Ezequiel Zamora, Guanare, Venezuela) and CPUCLA (Colección Regional de Peces, Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Centroccidental Lisandro Alvarado, Barquisimeto, Venezuela).
useTrade: The species is occasionally caught in subsistence fishing, usually practiced by indigenous and criollo groups. Parodon apolinari is rare in the aquarium fish market. The total volume of harvest is unknown.
conservationActions: This species is included in the website about freshwater fish at risk, their monitoring and conservation in coastal drainages of Venezuela (Rodríguez-Olarte and Taphorn 2007). It was included in a regional assessment of the coastal drainages to the Caribbean Sea (Tocuyo, Aroa, Yaracuy, Urama), where it was assigned to the category Least Concern (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2011). There are several conservation sites and protected areas that cover important sections of the rivers where it occurs (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020): National Parks Sierra de la Macarena, Natural Reserve Meseta de Versalles (Colombia), National Parks El Tamá, Yurubí, Aguaro-Guariquito and Natural Monument María Lionza. Habitat protection in the most impacted drainages is recommended, as well as awareness raising. Research into trends for the population, threats and habitat is recommended.

rationale: Several drainages where Parodon suborbitalis lives are impacted. The Sierra de Perijá is in a better conservation status in the piedmonts and mountain, with the only national park with a record of the species. In the rest of piedmont and mountains of Maracaibo Lake basin the intervention is is ancient, intense and extensive. The species is restricted to a strip between piedmonts and uppers plains, usually where it exists a strong human intervention. Where Parodon suborbitalis inhabits, the deforestation, contamination by effluents and the extraction of water are common. The area of occupancy (AOO) is best estimated at 1,872 km2. There are 1-2 threat-based locations. Therefore, it is evaluated as Vulnerable.
habitat: Parodon suborbitalis inhabits creeks, streams and rivers in piedmonts and plains. Usually it is in streams with fast currents with rocky substrates and sandy bottoms. It occurs in small to medium groups, and is herbivorous (epibenthic) feeding on algae and aquatic insects associated with the periphyton (Galvis et al. 1997). The usual size is around 120 mm standard length. Species of Parodon could have an important role in both spatial heterogeneity and benthic diversity in fluvial ecosystems (Flecker and Taylor 2004).
threats: In the Maracaibo basin several environmental stressors are recognized that affect habitat heterogeneity, such as deforestation of watersheds and riparian areas, pollution of waters by urban and agro-industrial effluents, and the transformation of channels by the extraction of water for derivation or accumulation (reservoirs), mainly in the piedmonts and mountains (Galvis et al. 1997, García et al. 2016, Segnini and Chacón 2017).
population: Parodon suborbitalis is habitual in records from rivers in Maracaibo basin, and occasionally can reach a moderate abundance. In surveys (2012) applied in piedmonts of Misoa and Machango rivers (eastern coast of Maracaibo Lake) this species comprised around 1% of relative abundance (unpublished data). There are no data available to estimate the total population size; however, the population trend is considered stable.
range:
Parodon suborbitalis was described from the Lake Maracaibo basin (Cuvier and Valenciennes 1850). The species is native to the Maracaibo basin and also occur in rivers to the Gulf of Venezuela on the west coast of Falcón state in Venezuela. The species inhabits rivers that descend from Mérida (rivers Chama, Motatán, Misoa, Machango) and Perijá (rivers Catatumbo, Limón, Guasare, Palmar) mountain ranges, as well as rivers Misoa, Machango and Maticora at northern slopes to the Gulf of Venezuela (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2009, Londoño-Burbano et al. 2011). The species is reported in 14 sites with elevation from 50-600 m above sea level.

The extent of occurrence (EOO) is best estimated at 67,522 km2, and the area of occupancy (AOO) is best estimated at 1,872 km2. There are 1-2 threat-based locations.

The geographic attributes for Parodon suborbitalis in this assessment were compiled, arranged and reviewed from the following sources: Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF 2020), FishNet2 (Fishnet2 2020), FishBase (Froese and Pauly 2019), SiB Colombia (SiB Colombia 2020) and SpeciesLink (SpeciesLink 2020), and complemented with records from the databases of the following ichthyological collections from Colombia: CZUT-IC (Colección Zoológica, Universidad del Tolima, Ibagué), IAvH-P (Colección de Peces de Agua Dulce del Instituto de Investigación de Recursos Biológicos Alexander von Humboldt, Villa de Leyva), ICN-MHN (Instituto de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional de Colombia, Bogotá), IMCN (Colección Zoológica de Referencia Científica del Museo de Ciencias Naturales Federico Carlos Lehmann Valencia del INCIVA, Cali), and MPUJ (Museo Javeriano de Historia Natural "Lorenzo Uribe, S.J." de la Pontificia Universidad Javeriana, Bogotá), and Venezuela: MCNG (Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional Experimental de los Llanos Occidentales Ezequiel Zamora, Guanare, Venezuela) and CPUCLA (Colección Regional de Peces, Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Centroccidental Lisandro Alvarado, Barquisimeto, Venezuela).
useTrade: This species is reported in subsistence fisheries practiced by family groups (river Misoa). The species has potential in the aquarium market but this use is not yet reported.
conservationActions: National Park Sierra de Perijá is in the distribution (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020) and this species probably occurs in the contiguous protected area in Colombia (National Natural Park Catatumbo-Bari). Habitat protection in the most impacted drainages is recommended, as well as awareness raising. Research into trends for the population, threats and habitats is recommended.

rationale: Triportheus orinocensis has a wide distribution in drainages of Orinoco. The species is reported in several protected areas and rivers with good conditions. The databases do not suggest a reduction in the population. The species Triportheus orinocensis is evaluated as Least Concern (LC).
habitat:
The fishes of the genus Triportheus inhabit varied environments, usually in mud and sand substrates and white waters, including poorly oxygenated water. They have barbels on the lower lips that serve to direct the superficial oxygenated water into the mouth. The diet of Triportheus include seeds, plankton, and small invertebrates (Malabarba 2004). The species can reach 290 mm in standard length and a fertility of 7,000 eggs per female (Lasso 2004).

.
threats: The conservation status of habitats where Triportheus orinocensis occurs are varied. In the upper llanos of Apure and Meta, deforestation is ongoing (Oliveira-Miranda et al. 2010). Oil drilling and mining occur in the plains, with potential negative effects (spills) on the habitat (Briceño 2015). On the other hand, several rivers in the llanos, delta and Guiana Shield are still well preserved, except for the threat of gold mining.
population: Given the natural abundance and broad distribution of Triportheus orinocensis, the size of the population is considered to be large. The current population trend is stable.
range:
Triportheus orinocensis was described in Caño Falcón, to the west of the road from Calabozo to San Fernando, about 35 km south to Fundo Masaguaral, Venezuela (Malabarba 2004). The species is widely dispersed in the lowlands of the Orinoco. The species occurs in the rivers Mataven, Casanare, Arauca, Ariporo, Arauca, Apure (Maraca creek, Apurito, Portuguesa, Igües creek), lower Orinoco and Orinoco delta (Taphorn 1992, Malabarba 2004, Maldonado-Ocampo et al. 2009, Lasso and Sánchez-Duarte 2011). The species is reported in 133 localities with an elevational distribution range from 1-190 m above sea level.

The geographic attributes for Triportheus orinocensis in this assessment were compiled, arranged and reviewed from the following sources: Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF 2020), FishNet2 (Fishnet2 2020), FishBase (Froese and Pauly 2019), SiB Colombia (SiB Colombia 2020) and SpeciesLink (SpeciesLink 2020), and complemented with records from the databases of the following ichthyological collections from Colombia: CZUT-IC (Colección Zoológica, Universidad del Tolima, Ibagué), IAvH-P (Colección de Peces de Agua Dulce del Instituto de Investigación de Recursos Biológicos Alexander von Humboldt, Villa de Leyva), ICN-MHN (Instituto de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional de Colombia, Bogotá), IMCN (Colección Zoológica de Referencia Científica del Museo de Ciencias Naturales Federico Carlos Lehmann Valencia del INCIVA, Cali), and MPUJ (Museo Javeriano de Historia Natural "Lorenzo Uribe, S.J." de la Pontificia Universidad Javeriana, Bogotá), and Venezuela: MCNG (Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional Experimental de los Llanos Occidentales Ezequiel Zamora, Guanare, Venezuela) and CPUCLA (Colección Regional de Peces, Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Centroccidental Lisandro Alvarado, Barquisimeto, Venezuela).
useTrade: The species of the genus Triportheus reach a size of interest for consumption. This species is common in subsistence fisheries and commercialized local markets, but the volume of the harvests is unknown.
conservationActions: There are no specific regulations for its protection. The species occurs in protected areas (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020): Selva RI Matavén, Wildlife Esteros de Chiriguare, and Refuge Esteros de Camaguán. Awareness and communications are recommended, and it is necessary to research the conditions and trends for the fisheries, population and habitat.

rationale: This species has a wide distribution in drainages of Orinoco, Caribbean and Atlantic versants, and is reported in protected areas. There is no evidence of a decline in the population. However, in the broad extent of occurrence for A. metae there are many environmental stressors (e.g. deforestation, contamination by effluents, sedimentation, agroindustry) with negative effects on the integrity of rivers and their fish communities, principally in most urbanized drainages. Based on its widespread distribution, it is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: The habitats for Astyanax metae are lagoons, streams and rivers with crystalline waters and heterogeneous substrates, with a mixture of sand, gravel and stones (Taphorn 1992). It is pelagic and omnivorous, with macroinvertebrates, insects, plants and seeds common in the diet (Pearse 1920). It can reach 160 mm in standard length. The reproduction is annual and during the first months of rainy season. It reaches a fertility of 9,528 eggs / female and the generation length is 12 months (Winemiller and Taphorn 1989). In some drainages there is intensive and accelerated urban and agricultural expansion, with consequent deterioration of habitat for this species (see Rodríguez-Olarte and Taphorn 1995, Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2006, Briceño 2015).
threats: In many drainages where Astyanax metae inhabits there are intense impacts on aquatic ecosystems (Urbano-Bonilla et al. 2009, Oliveira-Miranda et al. 2010, Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2011, Briceño 2015). The Andean piedmonts and their plains face deforestation for migratory agriculture, dams, urban effluents and mining activities, among others. Some streams in Apure and Meta tributaries have lost their integrity and diversity of ichthyofauna as a consequence of these environmental stressors (e.g. Rodríguez-Olarte and Taphorn 1995).
population: Astyanax metae is a common species, mainly in piedmont and adjacent plains. The total population size is suspected to be greater than 10,000 individuals, given its natural abundance and broad distribution. In coastal drainages in Venezuela this species comprised 4.2% of relative abundance (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2011) and for Andean piedmonts (Meta) it can have considerable abundance (Urbano-Bonilla et al. 2009). The current population trend is considered stable, although in the future a potential reduction in the population is expected due to habitat loss according to expansion of human frontier in piedmonts of Orinoco and coastal drainages.
range:
Astyanax metae was described from the Negro river in Meta drainage of Colombia (Eigenmann et al. 1914). The species inhabits mainly low mountain, piedmonts and upper plains of the rivers Guaviare (Orotoy, Guacavía, Ariari), Meta, and Apure (Bumbum, Boconó, Las Marías, Acarigua) in Orinoco basin (Taphorn 1992, Maldonado-Ocampo et al. 2008, Urbano-Bonilla et al. 2009). There are reports for rivers Vigirima in the endorheic basin of Lake Valencia (Pearse 1920), Aroa, Yaracuy, Tuy and Unare in coastal drainages of Venezuela (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2009), and drainages to Paria Gulf (Lasso et al. 2010). There are some doubtful records in the middle Orinoco and eastern plains. The species is reported in 197 localities with elevation from 30-518 m above sea level.

The extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated at 499,619 km2 based on georeferenced point records. Threat-based locations are not counted.

The geographic attributes for Astyanax metae in this assessment were compiled, arranged and reviewed from the following sources: Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF 2020), FishNet2 (Fishnet2 2020), FishBase (Froese and Pauly 2019), SiB Colombia (SiB Colombia 2020) and SpeciesLink (SpeciesLink 2020), and complemented with records from the databases of the following ichthyological collections from Colombia: CZUT-IC (Colección Zoológica, Universidad del Tolima, Ibagué), IAvH-P (Colección de Peces de Agua Dulce del Instituto de Investigación de Recursos Biológicos Alexander von Humboldt, Villa de Leyva), ICN-MHN (Instituto de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional de Colombia, Bogotá), IMCN (Colección Zoológica de Referencia Científica del Museo de Ciencias Naturales Federico Carlos Lehmann Valencia del INCIVA, Cali), and MPUJ (Museo Javeriano de Historia Natural "Lorenzo Uribe, S.J." de la Pontificia Universidad Javeriana, Bogotá), and Venezuela: MCNG (Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional Experimental de los Llanos Occidentales Ezequiel Zamora, Guanare, Venezuela) and CPUCLA (Colección Regional de Peces, Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Centroccidental Lisandro Alvarado, Barquisimeto, Venezuela).
useTrade: Astyanax metae is frequent in subsistence fisheries in coastal drainages (e.g. Aroa, Tuy), but the volume of the harvest is unknown. It has little ornamental interest.
conservationActions: There are no regulations and programs for its protection. This species is included in the digital platform for dissemination and training about freshwater fish, their monitoring and conservation in coastal drainages of Venezuela (Rodríguez-Olarte and Taphorn 2007). It was previously assigned to the category Least Concern in a regional assessment in drainages of the Caribbean Sea in Venezuela (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2011). It occurs in DMI Ariari-Guayabero, Nukak Natural Reserve National Park Sierra de la Macarena, National Parks El Tamá, Tucuragua, Yurubí, and Natural Monument María Lionza (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2011, DoNascimiento et al. 2018, IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020). Awareness and communications raising are recommended, as well as research into trends in the population and habitat.

rationale: Hyphessobrycon fernandezi is classified as Vulnerable. The extent of occurrence (EOO) is best estimated at 15,147 km2, and the area of occupancy (AOO) is best estimated at 592 km2. Given the regional impacts associated with the expansion of the urban frontier (deforestation, agribusiness, effluents, and riverbed transformation), H. fernandezi is best estimated to occur in two threat-based locations. These threats have resulted in a continuing decline in the EOO and habitat. The population is considered severely fragmented because the species has small (potentially non-viable) and isolated subpopulations in different coastal drainages due to natural causes.
habitat: Hyphessobrycon fernandezi inhabits plains and piedmonts in creeks, streams and lagoons with heterogeneous substrates. It is also in estuaries and brackish water. Very little information about the habitat and ecology of H. fernandezi is known. Species of the genus Hyphessobrycon eat insects and algae in similar proportions. It can reach 54 mm in standard length (Lima et al. 2003). Reproduction may be periodic and associated with the rainy season. The genus has variable fecundity, between 300 and 2,000 oocytes (García-Alzate et al. 2008).
threats: Streams in plains are the critical habitat for the species, and there a rapid expansion of the urban and agricultural frontier is reported. Different stressors affect the integrity of rivers and their habitats for the local ichthyofauna, even more so for endemic and rare species such as H. fernandezi (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2006, 2011, 2018, 2019). Deforestation is extensive in the Aroa, Yaracuy and Urama drainages, as well as in all the plains near to the sea. Further, fluviomarine plains are associated with the regional tourism centre in beaches of Morrocoy National Park and agroindustrial developments. All rivers have cities, towns and villages on their banks. Urban and agricultural effluents are not treated before entering the rivers, and the extraction of water is high and permanent. In the plains there are several industrial centres (e.g. oil refineries). There are dams and artificial lagoons that can favour the species, but many are depauperated by urban and industrial effluents (e.g. Cumaripa and Durute reservoirs), introduced species (e.g. Oreochromis sp.) or desiccation by sedimentation.
population: Hyphessobrycon fernandezi is not a common species. In streams piedmonts in Aroa and Yaracuy drainages it comprised <0.1% of relative abundance (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2011), but it could be common in lagoons and reservoirs. There are no data available to estimate the population size, and considering the human and climatic threats in the region, the population has an unknown trend. A significant population reduction is likely in the future due to environmental degradation within its distribution.
range:
Hyphessobrycon fernandezi was described near Aroa, en route to Duaca, Quebrada Cupa, Caribbean slopes of Venezuela (Fernández-Yépez 1972). It is endemic to the coastal drainages in rivers Aroa, Yaracuy, Urama and Sanchón (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2011). It occurs in lowlands, less frequently in piedmonts and estuaries. It is also in Tocuyo drainage, reported for fluviomarine plains in Tacarigua reservoir, and other small neighbouring drainages: Tibana creek in Cuare, Agüide and Ricoa (García-Alzate et al. 2008). The records for the upper tributaries at north of Tocuyo River must be treated with caution, since another very similar species of recent description occurs there (Hyphessobrycon paucilepis). The records in slopes to Venezuela Gulf (Casigua, Bariro, Borojó) and upper Tocuyo are in doubt and should be reviewed. The species is reported in six localities with elevation from 2-285 m above sea level.

The extent of occurrence (EOO) is best estimated at 15,147 km2, and the area of occupancy (AOO) is best estimated at 592 km2. Given the regional impacts associated with the expansion of the urban frontier (deforestation, agribusiness, effluents, and riverbed transformation), H. fernandezi is best estimated to occur in two threat-based locations.

The geographic attributes for Hyphessobrycon fernandezi in this assessment were compiled, arranged and reviewed from the following sources: Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF 2020), FishNet2 (Fishnet2 2020), FishBase (Froese and Pauly 2019) and complemented with records from the databases of the following ichthyological collections Venezuela: MCNG (Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional Experimental de los Llanos Occidentales Ezequiel Zamora, Guanare, Venezuela) and CPUCLA (Colección Regional de Peces, Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Centroccidental Lisandro Alvarado, Barquisimeto, Venezuela).
useTrade: There is no information on the possible use and trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no specific measures for the conservation of the species Hyphessobrycon fernandezi. There are no laws, regulations and educational programs specifically oriented to its protection. This species is included in the website about freshwater fish at risk, their monitoring and conservation in coastal drainages of Venezuela (Rodríguez-Olarte and Taphorn 2007). Hyphessobrycon fernandezi was previously assessed as Vulnerable for a regional assessment in coastal drainages of the Caribbean Sea (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2011) and Near Threatened in the Red Book of Venezuelan Fauna (Rodríguez et al. 2015). Records of the species are detected in protected areas (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020). It is reported in National Parks Yurubí, San Esteban and Morrocoy, and Wildlife refuges Cuare and Tucurere. Most of these protected areas cover only the upper (piedmont) and lower (sea) limits for the species, leaving the plains unprotected and subject to extensive and intensive intervention. The fluviomarine plains in other protected areas are small and under strong human impacts. In some sectors of piedmont private conservation initiatives could be an impact on conservation, such as Hacienda Guáquira (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2011).

rationale: This species occurs in several countries in rivers along the coast from Venezuela to Brazil. Therefore, it is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: Piabucus dentatus is pelagic species that inhabits low-lying coastal waters, including estuaries and floodplain streams. It is often found in turbid, silt-laden tributaries and at some localities occurs in brackish conditions. Gut analyses shown it to be a micropredator, feeding on a variety of small crustaceans, insects and other zoobenthos. Given the behaviour and natural habitat of the species, it is likely to be an egg scatterer exhibiting zero parental care.
threats: No threats specifically affecting this species have been identified, but urban and agricultural areas, oil drilling and damming occur in the distribution range.
population: The total population is assumed to exceed 10,000 individuals because of its occurrence in many coastal rivers of several countries.
range: Piabucus dentatus as currently understood is widespread in coastal waters of northern South America.
