It has been reported from Venezuela, Guyana, Suriname, French Guiana and Amapá, Brazil (Guimarães et al. 2016) where its range extends southwards to the mouth of the Amazon. It is restricted to the delta region in the Orinoco basin. Reports from Peru and Bolivia are misidentifications.
useTrade: This species is in the aquarium fish trade.
conservationActions: There are no conservation plans for this species.

rationale: Chaetostoma joropo is assessed as Vulnerable. The species is restricted to piedmont and mountain rivers and the Meta and Guaviare drainages. Some of these rivers are well-preserved, however, the threats exist in many drainages associated with the expansion of the agricultural and urban frontiers, including deforestation, land-use change, sedimentation and urban effluents. There is continuing decline in habitat based on these threats. The area of occupancy (AOO) is best estimated at 1,580 km². There are 2–4 threat-based locations.
habitat: The habitat of Chaetostoma joropo is mountain and piedmont rivers in the Andes. This species shows preference for rocky substrates, shallow and well oxygenated water (6.1–9.5 mg/l), which is slightly basic pH (7.1–8.6), with conductivity of 10.4–258.0 µS, and temperatures of 21–30°C. It feeds on insect larvae (Diptera) but is mostly algivorous (Ballen et al. 2016). It can reach 146.7 mm standard length.
threats: As for other Loricariidae in the upper tributaries of Guaviare and Meta drainages in Andean versants, the habitat for Chaetostoma joropo is at risk from deforestation, agriculture and oil exploitation and urban effluents. Land-use change within these Andean catchments is likely to alter hydrology, sediment transport, and habitat conditions within river systems, with adverse consequences for aquatic biodiversity  (Romero-Ruíz et al. 2012, Urbano et al. 2014).
population: The population of Chaetostoma joropo is considered stable in accord with its abundance. The size of its population is considered to be large.
range:
Chaetostoma joropo was described from Güejar river, upper Guaviare drainage, Orinoco river basin in Colombia (Ballen et al. 2016). It is present in piedmont rivers of the Orinoco River Basin in Colombia, and in the Casanare, Meta and Guaviare drainages, including the rivers Cusiana, Caja, Purare and Tocoragua, among others. It is found from Vista Hermosa in the Departamento de Meta to the south to the río Tocoragua in the municipality of Tame, Departamento de Arauca to the north. The species is distributed in a range of elevations from 206 to 1,014 m above sea level.

The extent of occurrence (EOO) is best estimated at 37,928 km², and the area of occupancy (AOO) is best estimated at 1,580 km². There are 2–4 threat-based locations.

The geographic attributes for Chaetostoma formosae in this assessment were compiled, arranged and reviewed from the following sources: Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF 2020), FishNet2 (Fishnet2 2020), FishBase (Froese and Pauly 2019), SiB Colombia (SiB Colombia 2020) and SpeciesLink (SpeciesLink 2020), and complemented with records from the databases of the following ichthyological collections from Colombia: CZUT-IC (Colección Zoológica, Universidad del Tolima, Ibagué), IAvH-P (Colección de Peces de Agua Dulce del Instituto de Investigación de Recursos Biológicos Alexander von Humboldt, Villa de Leyva), ICN-MHN (Instituto de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional de Colombia, Bogotá), IMCN (Colección Zoológica de Referencia Científica del Museo de Ciencias Naturales Federico Carlos Lehmann Valencia del INCIVA, Cali), and MPUJ (Museo Javeriano de Historia Natural "Lorenzo Uribe, S.J." de la Pontificia Universidad Javeriana, Bogotá).
useTrade: There are no known uses for the species
conservationActions: There are protected areas from which the species is reported: National Natural Park Sierra de la Macarena (buffer zone) and DMI Ariari-Guayabero (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020). Habitat protection of the most impacted drainages is recommended, as well as awareness and communications. It is necessary to research the actual conditions and trends for the population size and distribution, threats and habitat.

rationale:
Anguilla mossambica is a catadromous, semelparous species with multiple life stages. These life history traits, coupled with the limited information available to infer abundance trends, pose particular challenges in applying the IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria (Jacoby et al. 2015).

Anguilla mossambica is found in fresh and saline water habitats of East Africa, Madagascar and other West Indian Ocean island chains. Documented threats to this species include barriers to migration (Mafuca and Bills 2012), parasites (Sasal et al. 2008, Weyl et al. 2013, McHugh et al. 2017), and the growing exploitation of this species in Madagascar and South Africa, for export to Asia and Europe (Robinet et al. 2008, Gollock et al. 2018). In KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa, a decline in range of ~50% over three generations (30 years) has been estimated in some rivers in the province (C. Hanzen unpub. data). Elsewhere in South Africa, there is anecdotal evidence of declines in the Eerste River catchment in False Bay due to poor water quality, and the Rietvlei-Diep system in Table Bay where recent records have only been of dead A. marmorata individuals with visible lesions (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019). In Réunion Island, this species occurs frequently in some rivers, whereas in Mayotte, A. mossambica are considered scarce (Valade et al. 2018, DEAL and OCEA 2019). Dam construction has also thought to have led to declines in Tanzania (Tamatamah 2012). In the Cahora Bassa Lake, Mozambique, eels (A. marmorata, A. mossambica, and A. bengalensis) were found to be absent where historical studies had reported them as extant prior to dam construction (Mafuca and Bills 2012).

If observed range declines in some areas are reflected in other regions across the distribution of this species, there would be significant cause for concern. This, coupled with growing interest and demand for this species for farming and consumption, has led to A. mossambica being assessed as Near Threatened (NT). The listing for this species is based on inference from limited data across a small range and it is therefore strongly advised that monitoring for this species be conducted to better determine population status. As with all anguillids, co-ordination of the management across this species’ range will also be pivotal in conserving the population.

Assessment of this species was carried out during a workshop held at the Zoological Society of London from the 5th–9th of November, 2018.
habitat:
There are a number of phases in an eel’s life that have specific terminology; the leaf-shaped marine larval stage is referred to as leptocephalus; these become glass eels as they reach continental waters, before developing into pigmented elvers and then the growth phase: the yellow eel. The final stage is the marine-migratory silver eel which is characterised by silvery counter-shading and large eyes.

In South Africa this species inhabits a broad ecological niche, being found in rivers from the headwater to lower reaches (Lin et al. 2012, 2015; Kadye and Booth 2019). Similar to other anguillids, Anguilla mossambica is catadromous, whereby a proportion of the growth phase (yellow eel) reside in freshwater and the other remaining in sea, coastal, or brackish habitats (Tsukamoto 1998, Lin et al. 2015). Elvers in the Eastern Cape, South Africa arrive in considerably higher numbers in the summer (November/December) than during the winter (June/July) or spring months (Wasserman et al. 2012). Although yellow eels are usually fairly sedentary, otolith microchemistry suggests that some individuals in South Africa are inter-habitat migrants that move between freshwater and saline habitats (Lin et al. 2012). In a later study using otolith Sr:Ca ratios, Lin et al. (2015) found 16.7% (n = 5) of individuals in the Maningory River, Madagascar, to exhibit freshwater residency, and 13.3% to be habitat-shifters (n = 4).

Females can attain lengths of up to 120 cm and are generally longer and heavier than males (Froese and Pauly 2011). This species is thought to remain in the yellow stage for 8–18 years before metamorphosing into the silver stage, prior to beginning the spawning migration (McEwan and Hecht 1984, Bruton et al. 1987 in Lin et al. 2012, 2015).

It has been suggested that spawning of this species occurs continuously between June and November in an area north-east of Madagascar and west of the Mascerene Ridge in the Indian Ocean (Robinet et al. 2008). The age of leptocephali increases as they are found further south of the proposed spawning area and it is suggested that individuals are transported by the South Equatorial Current (SEC) (Réveillac et al. 2009b). The present continental range suggests a migration of 1,000 to 2,000 km from the proposed spawning area (Réveillac et al. 2009b). Of the three species that inhabit the Malagasy area (A. mossambica, A. marmorata and A. bicolor), A. mossambica have the slowest otolith growth rate due to its southernmost distribution (Robinet et al. 2008).

Note: Within the IUCN Habitat Classification Scheme table, most listed habitats are considered important for eels. The Marine Oceanic habitats were listed as ‘Major Importance’ due to there likely being a discrete spawning area.
threats:
Anguilla mossambica, like all anguillid eels, is susceptible to a number of, primarily anthropogenic, threats. These threats include but are not limited to; barriers to migration, climate change, habitat degradation, invasive species, parasitism, pollution, predation and unsustainable exploitation. The significance of any single threat, or the synergy it may have with other threats is still poorly understood (Jacoby et al. 2015). It is therefore important to highlight that management measures focusing on a single threat, in isolation of other identified pressures, are potentially less likely to have a significant positive effect on eel abundance. All anguillids are catadromous and semelparous, migrating from continental waters to the ocean to breed, and spawning only once before death. These traits arguably increase the impact of threats, through the terminal nature of reproduction and exposing them to pressures in both freshwater and marine environments.

Barriers to migration appear to be problematic in Mozambique and Zimbabwe with dams such as the Cahora Bassa and Kariba dams preventing migration (Matiza and Crafter 1994, Mafuca and Bills 2012). A study investigating fish diversity in the Cahora Bassa Lake, found eels (A. marmorata, A. mossambica, and A. bengalensis) to be absent (Mafuca and Bills 2012). Historic studies had previously reported these species in this area prior to the construction of the Cahora Bassa Dam (Mafuca and Bills 2012). However, in both the Sundays River (Wasserman et al. 2011) and Baakens River (Muller et al. 2015) in South Africa, A. mossambica was found upstream of the obstructions, and in both studies was the only species able to transverse the weirs.

In South Africa, poor water quality is anecdotally suggested to have caused eel species to become rare in some localities, such as the False Bay catchments, and few specimens remaining in this area have been observed to have severe skin lesions (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019). Non-native species now found in many systems in South Africa, such as the predatory bass (Micropterus spp.) and catfish (Clarias spp.), may also have contributed to the decline (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019).

Fisheries for eels based in Madagascar, Mozambique, and South Africa appear to be increasing, and over the last 15 years, glass eels have been increasingly exported directly from Madagascar to East Asia (Robinet et al. 2008, Gollock et al. 2018). There are also concerns over illegal fishing and trade in the region (see Use and Trade). Weyl et al. (2013) cautioned that the trade of live A. mossambica may result in parasitic introductions into other regions, as a result of its rich parasitic fauna. In the Eastern Cape of South Africa this species is particularly vulnerable to a parasitic gill worm (Pseudodactylogyrus anguillae) (Parker et al. 2011, McHugh et al. 2017). This parasite has been shown to cause damage to gills resulting in impaired respiration (McHugh et al. 2017). Under aquaculture conditions, where fish are kept in high numbers, infection has led to mortalities (McHugh et al. 2017). Parasitic infection by the invasive swim bladder nematode Anguillicola crassus has also been observed in A. mossambica, A. bicolor and A. marmorata from Reunion (Sasal et al. 2008). Two A. marmorata (n = 80), one A. bicolor (n = 23) and one A. mossambica (n = 15) were infected (Sasal et al. 2008). While the infection prevalence was low in these samples, this parasite is known to spread extremely quickly (Kirk 2003).

Climate change has been proposed to play a role in fluctuations of abundance in anguillid species – particularly larval transport and glass eel recruitment – however, our knowledge of these processes, and the scale of their influence, if any, is very limited (Jacoby et al. 2015).
population:
There is little quantitative information available to infer the population status of Anguilla mossambica. It is reasonable to assume that there will have been some effects as a result of the identified threats, although considerably more information would be necessary to determine accurate estimates and associated changes.

A study investigating niche patterns in native and non-native fish within The Great Fish River (South Africa) described A. mossambica as having broad environmental niches and being widespread (Kadye and Booth 2019), which is similar to what has been found in the Sundays River, Eastern Cape (Wassermann et al. 2012). In a study of 4099 glass eels sampled between April 2005 and February 2006 from rivers in Reunion, Mauritius, Mayotte, and Madagascar, 3790 A. mossambica, 246 A. marmorata, and 63 A. bicolor were identifiable (Réveillac et al. 2009a), indicating the latter was a small proportion of the recruitment to these islands at the time.

Other recent monitoring data has been collected from South Africa between 2015 and 2019, predominantly in KwaZulu-Natal (C. Hanzen unpub. data.). A comparison of historical (Scott et al. 2006, GBIF 2018) and current data from the samples collected across this province was carried out. Using this method, the decline in extent of occurrence (EOO) was 51% over three generation lengths, and 59% over the full time series (1959-2019). These records indicate a decline in distribution – and very likely abundance – of this species in some rivers of KwaZulu-Natal. This pattern, if reflected in other areas across the range of this species, would be significant cause for concern.

In some areas in South Africa, such as the Eerste River catchment in False Bay, eels were historically considered a problem species, and recruiting elvers caused blockages in irrigation pumps (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019). Since the 1970s, eels are no longer common in False Bay catchments; this has been suggested to be due to poor water quality (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019). In Tanzania, the decline in native eels (A. bengalensis and A. mossambica) is thought to have begun in the 1980s, as a result of dam construction (Tamatamah 2012). Fishing surveys carried out over the past decade only found a few individual eels in comparison to pre-impoundment fish studies (Tamatamah 2012). A. marmorata and A. mossambica once occurred in the Rietvlei-Diep system in Table Bay, although recent records have only been of dead A. marmorata individuals with visible lesions (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019).

In Réunion, A. mossambica, as well as other recruiting anguillid eels (A. bengalensis, A. marmorata and A. bicolor), are classified as ‘Critically Endangered’ under the regional Red List (Fricke et al. 2009). Listed threats include fisheries (target species and bycatch), habitat loss, construction of barriers to migration, and parasites (Fricke et al. 2009).

Anguilla mossambica yellow eels occur frequently in some rivers of Réunion Island (Valade et al. 2018). The size structure of the population in these areas indicate high mortality, and therefore rivers may produce few silver eels (DEAL and OCEA 2019). In Mayotte, A. mossambica are considered scarce (OCEA 2014).
range:
This species is endemic to countries bordering the southwest Indian Ocean. Along the east coast of Africa, Anguilla mossambica is found in rivers from Kenya south to Table Bay (South Africa), also found on Madagascar and other western Indian Ocean islands (Mascarene: Réunion and Mauritius Islands, Comoros: Mayotte Island and the Seychelles: Mahé and Praslin Islands). Anguilla mossambica, is also the most common anguillid species in the Eastern Cape, South Africa and in eastern Madagascar (Robinet et al. 2008).

Spawning is thought to occur in an area north-east of Madagascar and west of the Mascerene Ridge in the Indian Ocean (Robinet et al. 2008).
useTrade:
The various life stages, ranging from glass to silver, of all anguillid species are harvested and traded on a global scale for farming and consumption, with current demand predominantly driven by East Asian markets, in particular Japan, The Republic of Korea (hereafter South Korea) and mainland China (hereafter China). A concerning pattern of exploitation is already apparent – when one Anguilla species or population becomes over-exploited, industry moves to the next in order to fulfil demand (Gollock et al. 2018).

According to FAO data, annual global production of Anguilla has steadily increased since the 1950s, mainly due to the expansion of farming in East Asia. In 2016, eel farming accounted for 98% of total eel production (over 290,000 tonnes (t)), with China responsible for nearly 86% (FAO 2018). Eel farming is reliant on wild-caught juvenile eels (glass eels/elvers) as “seed” as breeding in captivity is not yet commercially viable. Although the preferred species for farming in East Asia is A. japonica, which is native to the region, declines in availability and ongoing demand has led to increase in harvest and trade in juveniles of other Anguilla spp. in recent years (Shiraishi and Crook 2015, Gollock et al. 2018). Being a plain-coloured eel, there has been an increase in interest in A. mossambica to stock farms in East Asia and elsewhere from 2010 onwards (after A. anguilla was listed in CITES Appendix II in 2009 and the EU banned all trade in A. anguilla from and to the EU), and in particular when the price of A. japonica glass eels increased dramatically due to shortages in 2011–2013.

According to East Asian Customs data, the first known records of imports of live glass eels into Asia from Africa are from 2005, and between 2008 and 2017 East Asian countries/territories imported ~14 t of live eel fry for farming (glass eels and larger juveniles) from Africa (99% from Madagascar). Live eel fry imports from Madagascar (believed to be mainly composed of A. mossambica) reached a peak of 5.6 t in 2013, after which they dropped to less than 600 kg in 2014 and 2015, with no imports recorded in 2016–2017. South Korea reported farming input 0.5 t of A. mossambica in 2012–2013 (Gollock et al. 2018); South Korea tried farming A. mossambica and A. bicolor when the price of A. japonica glass eels increased dramatically due to their shortage during 2011–2013, most of which was reportedly unsuccessful (Fan and Qin 2016, Back and Park 2017).

Live eels and meat are traded globally for consumption and to a much smaller extent Anguilla skins and leather products are also in international trade. Global Customs trade data for live, fresh, frozen and prepared/preserved eel (non-species-specific) are available for the last 40 years.  According to FAO and UN Comtrade, global annual exports of Anguilla averaged around 20,000 t in the late 1970s, after which annual exports showed a steady increase to a maximum of over 130,000 t in 2001. Since then annual exports have been declining, to just over 80,000 t in 2008–2011, increasing again slightly to ~90,000 t in 2013–2015. The export value of these commodities has steadily increased over the past 40 years, reaching USD ~1.6 billion in 2012. Over the last decade, of the four commodity types, live and prepared/preserved eel accounted for nearly 80% of total exports by weight, and China has been the main eel exporter and Japan the main importer. As noted above, a high percentage of eel in international trade is derived from eels having been grown out in farms. 

Anguilla mossambica is found in subsistence and commercial fisheries and in international trade, however as its range overlaps with many other anguillids, species specific data is very limited. No country from the species’ range has reported eel catch or farming data to FAO, however in recent years there has been a reported increase in interest in commercial harvesting of eels (all life stages) from South Africa, Mozambique and Madagascar, with a focus on A. mossambica for export to Europe and Asia. Illegal fishing and trade of glass eels has been reported from the region, and this has been linked to several applications for setting up eel farms in South Africa mainly using A. mossambica imported from Madagascar, all of which have been rejected by national authorities over concerns of disease, introduced parasites and population status (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019). An increase in investment into fisheries and farming of eels in Madagascar and Mauritius, in particular of A. mossambica, has been reported over the last decade (FIS 2010, Farm Africa 2015) and Malagasy eel farmers are advertising their products on B2B marketplaces/trade platforms such as Alibaba. There has also recently been a proposal to farm A. mossambica in aquaculture facilities in Michigan, USA (Wyam-Grothem et al. 2018).

International trade in Anguilla commodities is reported from A. mossambica range states, however, the species composition of shipments is unknown and could contain many different Anguilla species including A. marmorata, A. bengalensis and A. bicolor. According to UN Comtrade, Madagascar, South Africa, Tanzania and Mauritius exported Anguilla commodities between 2008 and 2017, with most exports being live and frozen eels from Madagascar (273 t) and South Africa (129 t). Exports of live eels (all life stages) from Madagascar increased gradually from 4.6 t in 2004 to 8.8 t in 2009 and then in 2010 there was a dramatic increase in exports to over 45 t. From 2011 to 2015 annual exports fluctuated between 16t and 26 t, and in 2016 and 2017 they declined again to ~11 t. Companies trading in the southern and east Africa region declare that their glass and adult live eels are A. mossambica and that they are able to differentiate between species and control harvesting as glass eel recruitment is asynchronous. However, exports to East Asia of live eels caught in Madagascar, Mozambique and South Africa have been reported to include other species (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019).
conservationActions:
There are no known species-specific policies in place for Anguilla mossambica. In South Africa in 1994, the River Health Programme (RHP) was established to monitor the health and ecosystem services provided by riverine habitats and, where necessary, establish protected areas to rejuvenate ecosystems and minimise human impacts (River Health Programme 2003). In South Africa, however, there are plans to try to increase river connectivity by linking adjoining sub-catchments in an attempt to aid fish migration (Rivers-Moore et al. 2011). Eels and eel pathways / migratory routes are also implicit in the Environmental Water Requirement (EWR) and Resource Directed Measures (RDM) methods in South Africa. Native Anguilla spp. are to be included within the South African National Biodiversity Institute (SANBI) National Biodiversity Assessment (NBA) 2018 (Skowno et al. 2019).

In 2018, a nine-year conservation and management plan for anguillid eels in Réunion was produced (Valade et al. 2018). The plan covers the three species of eels found in this territory (A. mossambica, A. bicolor and A. marmorata) and aims to combat the impacts of poaching, fisheries, river habitat quality and connectivity (Hanzen et al. in press). As a French department, Réunion operates under EU regulations, including following the EU Water Framework Directive (Hanzen et al. in press). The Red List of Réunion (IUCN France et al. 2013 in Hanzen et al. in press) lists A. mossambica as Critically Endangered.

As there is little information regarding the population status of this species, it is clear that more research is needed to determine distribution, harvest levels, abundance trends, as well as information on plausible threats. It will be necessary for management and policy to be developed appropriately.

rationale:
Anguilla bengalensis is a catadromous, semelparous species with multiple life stages. These life history traits, coupled with the limited information available to infer abundance trends, pose particular challenges in applying the IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria (Jacoby et al. 2015).

Anguilla bengalensis is widely distributed from east and southeast African water systems, across the Indian Ocean to mainland India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Indonesia and Malaysia, and is an occasional vagrant to the Arabian Peninsula. Although there is some evidence to suggest its range may have declined as a result of barriers to migration in various localities (Matiza and Crafter 1994, Attaala and Rubaia 2005, Tamatamah 2012, Mafuca and Bills 2012, Freyhof et al. 2015, Mzuza et al. 2017). For example, two large dams in the Zambezi (Kariba and Cahora Bassa) block the migration of elvers, posing a threat to future escapement and the spawning stock (Matiza and Crafter 1994, Mafuca and Bills 2012). Throughout India too, declines have been observed in the area of occupancy possibly as a result threats such as reduced habitat availability (Shrestha 2003, Islam 2015). The species is reported as almost absent from some regions, such as the Western Ghats (J. Freyhof pers. comm. 2014). Anguilla bengalensis is exploited for consumption and is being offered for sale on business-to-business (B2B) trade platforms, however, metrics of catch or effort are not available.

While there areno quantitative time-series data relating to declines in the species, there is some evidence indicating that both range and abundance of the species are shrinking. The species has been assessed as Near Threatened (NT); it is suspected that a reduction of close to 30% is likely to have occurred over the last 3 generations (36 years), based on reports of declines across its range. It is strongly advised that monitoring for this species be conducted to better determine population status. As with all anguillids, co-ordination of the management across this species’ range will also be pivotal for conservation.

Assessment of this species was carried out during a workshop held at the Zoological Society of London from the 5th–9th of November 2018.
habitat:
There are a number of phases in an eel’s life that have specific terminology; the leaf-shaped marine larval stage is referred to as leptocephalus; these become glass eels as they reach continental waters, before developing into pigmented elvers and then the growth phase: the yellow eel. The final stage is the marine-migratory silver eel which is characterised by silvery counter-shading and large eyes.

Anguilla bengalensis juveniles feed on insects and other aquatic invertebrates while adults feed on fishes (including trout in the streams of the eastern highlands of Zimbabwe) and crabs (Okeyo 1998). This species inhabits various niches in river systems from quiet undisturbed areas containing mud substrate to deep water, fast-flowing rock pools of rivers (Bell-Cross and Minshull 1988). In Malaysia A. bengalensis has been found to reside in upper/mid-stream areas at higher elevation with cooler water temperatures (Arai and Kadir 2017a). Length estimates for this species range between 80–200 cm (Shrestha 2003) and Pantulu (1957) found there to be strong positive length/weight relationships. Further, a close linear relationship between fecundity and total length has been observed (Kadir et al. 2017). Total length and body weight at silvering has been found to range from 487 to 1295 mm, and 257 to 5100 g, and age at silvering has been found to range from 5.5 to 10.5 years (Chai and Arai 2018). In a study of 47 specimens from Malaysia, seaward spawning migration occurred in individuals displaying high gonadosomatic indices between April and September (Arai and Kadir 2017b). This suggests their spawning season may extend for at least six months of the year (Arai and Kadir 2017b).

Note: Within the IUCN Habitat Classification Scheme table, most listed habitats are considered important for eels. The Marine Oceanic habitats were listed as ‘Major Importance’ due to there likely being a discrete spawning area.
threats:
Anguilla bengalensis, like all anguillid eels, is susceptible to a number of, primarily anthropogenic, threats. These threats include but are not limited to; barriers to migration, climate change, habitat degradation, invasive species, parasitism, pollution, predation and unsustainable exploitation. The significance of any single threat, or the synergy it may have with other threats is still poorly understood (Jacoby et al. 2015). It is therefore important to highlight that management measures focusing on a single threat, in isolation of other identified pressures, are potentially less likely to have a significant positive effect on eel abundance. All anguillids are catadromous and semelparous, migrating from continental waters to the ocean to breed, and spawning only once before death. These traits arguably increase the impact of threats, through the terminal nature of reproduction and exposing them to pressures in both freshwater and marine environments.

In India and Bangladesh in particular, harvesting of this species occurs, but it is not known what impact fishing is having on the overall population. As a mottled species, A. bengalensis is perhaps less desirable to the East Asian market, where plain coloured eels are generally preferred. There is, however, a growing market for mottled eels, although to date this is mainly for A. marmorata (Shiraishi and Crook 2015). 

The Conservation Assessment and Management Plan (CAMP) report on the freshwater fishes of India (Molur and Walker 1998) declared A. bengalensis as ‘Endangered’ according to IUCN criteria. In Bangladesh, A. bengalensis was assessed as ‘Vulnerable’ resulting from population decline attributable to “habitat loss and perceived over-exploitation for export” (Islam 2015). Threats reported to be affecting this species in both localities, were damming, fishing, loss of habitat, invasive species, disease, pollution, climate change, overexploitation and domestic trade (Molur and Walker 1998, Shrestha 2003, IUCN Bangladesh 2015). In Nepal specifically, most dams do not have fish and/or eel ladders, and loss of freshwater habitat is a significant problem (Shrestha 2003).

Barriers to migration appear to be problematic in Mozambique and Zimbabwe with dams such as the Cabora Bassa and Kariba dams preventing migration (Matiza and Crafter 1994, Mafuca and Bills 2012). A study investigating fish diversity in the Cahora Bassa Lake, found eels (A. marmorata, A. mossambica, and A. bengalensis) to be absent (Mafuca and Bills 2012). Historic studies had previously reported these species in this area prior to the construction of the Cahora Bassa Dam (Mafuca and Bills 2012). In Malawi, Nkula Dam is located on the Shire River (Mzuza et al. 2017), which may limit available habitat and movement. In Tanzania, the construction of large dams is also thought to have contributed to eel declines (Tamatamah 2012) Within the Arabian region, vagrant individuals of this species are known from a single location in the Wadi Hajr river, which is dammed 3–4 km from the mouth, possibly blocking upstream access for eels (Attaala and Rubaia 2005, Freyhof et al. 2015).

In South Africa, poor water quality is anecdotally suggested to have caused eel species to become rare in some localities, such as the False Bay catchments, and few specimens remaining in this area have been observed to have severe skin lesions (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019). Non-native species now found in many systems in South Africa, such as the predatory bass (Micropterus spp.) and catfish (Clarias spp.), may also have contributed to the decline (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019).

In 2012 a new species of parasitic nematode was discovered in the intestines of A. bengalensis collected from the freshwater bodies of Kerala State in southern Indian (Moravec et al. 2012). In some parts of India, this species has also been found to contain levels of pollutants that could be toxic to humans. In the Ganges River, West Bengal for example, A. bengalensis specimens that were caught contained methyl mercury concentrations that were higher than the limits set by the PFA (Provention of Food Adulteration Act) for human consumption (Pal et al. 2012). 

Climate change has been proposed to play a role in fluctuations of abundance in anguillid species – particularly larval transport and glass eel recruitment – however, our understanding of these processes, and the scale of their influence, if any, is very limited (Jacoby et al. 2015).
population:
There is little quantitative information available to infer the population status of Anguilla bengalensis. It is reasonable to assume that there will have been some effects as a result of the identified threats, although considerably more information would be necessary to determine accurate estimates and associated changes.

Anguilla bengalensis is the most common eel in Indian freshwater systems, and in particular in Nagaland and Assam. In 1998, this species was classified as ‘Endangered’ in India in accordance with a decline in AOO (area of occupancy) and a decline in the extent and/or quality of habitat (Molur and Walker 1998). During a systematic sampling survey carried out between 2004 and 2006 in the Periyar Tiger Reserve (a large river system in Kerala), its relative abundance was deemed 'rare' across the ten sampling locations (Radhakrishnan and Kurup 2010). The IUCN Red List of Bangladesh assessed A. bengalensis as ‘Vulnerable’ within its regional assessment (Islam 2015). This is due to a suspected population decline of 30% over the last ten years, resulting from habitat-loss and unsustainable exploitation (Islam 2015).

For other localities, there is limited information. There is some anecdotal evidence for localised extirpation in Africa, for example in Lake Kariba, Zimbabwe where fisherman, in 1998, reported no freshwater eel had been found since the construction of a large hydroelectric dam in 1959 (S. Watanabe pers. comm. 2014). In Manyame River, Zimbabwe, A. bengalensis was described as “formerly more numerous”, with individuals having not been collected or caught more recently, possibly indicating decline as a result of dams (Gratwicke et al. 2003). In Tanzania, the decline in native eels (A. bengalensis and A. mossambica) is thought to have begun in the 1980s, also as a result of dam construction (Tamatamah 2012). Fishing trials carried out over the past decade have only found a few individual eels in comparison to pre-impoundment fish studies (Tamatamah 2012).

In some areas in South Africa, such as the Eerste River catchment in False Bay, eels were historically considered a problem species, and recruiting elvers caused blockages in irrigation pumps (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019). Since the 1970s, eels are no longer common in False Bay catchments; this has been suggested to be due to poor water quality (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019). In KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa, river surveys for anguillid eels combined with historical distribution data found A. bengalensis not to be present in areas where they were previously extant (C. Hanzen unpub. data). Since 2000, A. marmorata and A. bengalensis have disappeared from longline sample catches in some catchments in Western Cape. One example is the Breede River, home to the invasive catfish (Clarias spp.), and so this may be a result of predation (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019). Similar to A. marmorata and A. mossambica, A. bengalensis may have once occurred in the Rietvlei-Diep system in Table Bay, although recent records have been of dead A. marmorata individuals with visible lesions (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019).

In Réunion, A. bengalensis (listed under the redundant synonym A. labiata), as well as other recruiting anguillid eels (A. bicolor, A. marmorata and A. mossambica), are classified as ‘Critically Endangered’ under the regional Red List (Fricke et al. 2009). Listed threats include fisheries (target species and bycatch), habitat loss, construction of barriers to migration, and parasites (Fricke et al. 2009).
range:
Anguilla bengalensis is found in Pakistan, India (Kerala, Andhra Pradesh, Arunanchal Pradesh, Manipur, Meghalaya, Orissa, Tamil Nadu, Assam, and Nagaland (Tsurang River)), Bangladesh, Nepal (Gandaki, Koshi, Karnali, Mahakali), Sri Lanka, Myanmar, South Africa (Sympatric with A. marmorata in the Western Cape), Kenya, Mozambique, Tanzania, Eswatini (Komati river system), Lake Kariba, Middle Zambezi and its larger tributaries on the plateau, Limpopo (Umzingwane River and Inyankuni Dam), Pungwe, Buzi, Upper and Lower Save/Runde systems in Zimbabwe. It is also found in Lake Malawi and its catchment area as well as the Shire River and its tributaries and the eastward flowing Athi and Tana drainages (Seegers et al. 2003). In Ethiopia A. bengalensis has been reported from the middle reaches of the Genale River catchment in the southwest of the country and is currently the only anguillid species found in the country (Golubtsov et al. 2012). An electrofishing study conducted in upper estuaries of the Seychelles, Mayotte, Mauritius, Reunion and the east coast of Madagascar recorded no A. bengalensis out of 4,172 collected eels (Robinet et al. 2008). Most recently, this species’ range has been extended to Aceh in Indonesia (Muchlisin et al. 2017), and north-western Peninsular Malaysia (Arai 2014, Arai et al. 2015, Arai and Wong 2016, Arai and Kadir 2017a,b). There are also occasional records of vagrant individuals in the Arabian Peninsula (Wadi Haj in Yemen; Ataala and Rubaia 2005).

There remains some uncertainty surrounding where freshwater eels including A. bengalensis spawn in the Indian Ocean. Indeed, compared to other species, very few leptocephali have been gathered for A. bengalensis and it is still not known whether this species has a single, or multiple spawning locations, or whether spawning location overlaps with other anguillids (see Robinet et al. 2008, Watanabe et al. 2014 for discussion).
useTrade:
The various life stages, ranging from glass to silver, of all anguillid species are harvested and traded on a global scale for farming and consumption, with current demand predominantly driven by East Asian markets, in particular Japan, the Republic of Korea (also known as South Korea) and mainland China (hereafter China). A concerning pattern of exploitation is already apparent – when one Anguilla species or population becomes over-exploited, industry moves to the next in order to fulfil demand (Gollock et al. 2018).

According to FAO data, annual global Anguilla production has steadily increased since the 1950s, mainly due to the expansion of farming in East Asia. In 2016, eel farming accounted for 98% of total eel production (over 290,000 tonnes (t)), with China responsible for nearly 86% (FAO 2018). Eel farming is reliant on wild-caught juvenile eels (glass eels/elvers) as “seed” as breeding in captivity is not yet commercially viable. Although the preferred species for farming in East Asia is A. japonica, which is native to the region, declines in availability and ongoing demand has led to increase in harvest and trade in juveniles of other Anguilla spp. in recent years (Shiraishi and Crook 2015, Gollock et al. 2018). According to East Asian Customs data, between 2008 and 2017 East Asian countries/territories imported ~14 t of live eel fry for farming (glass eels and larger juveniles) from Africa (99% from Madagascar) and 7.6 t from Bangladesh (all in 2014). There is, however, no information suggesting that A. bengalensis is currently used (or there are plans to use it) in eel farms in East Asia.

Live eels and meat are traded globally for consumption and to a much smaller extent Anguilla skins and leather products are also in international trade. Global Customs trade data for live, fresh, frozen and prepared/preserved eel (non-species-specific) are available for the last 40 years.  According to FAO and UN Comtrade, global annual exports of Anguilla averaged around 20,000 t in the late 1970s, after which annual exports showed a steady increase to a maximum of over 130,000 t in 2001. Since then annual exports have been declining, to just over 80,000 t in 2008–2011, increasing again slightly to ~90,000 t in 2013–2015. The export value of these commodities has steadily increased over the past 40 years, reaching USD ~1.6 billion in 2012. Over the last decade, of the four commodity types, live and prepared/preserved eel accounted for nearly 80% of total exports by weight, and China has been the main eel exporter and Japan the main importer. As noted above, a high percentage of eel in international trade is derived from eels having been grown out in farms. 

Anguilla bengalensis is found in subsistence and commercial fisheries and in international trade, however as its range overlaps with many other anguillids, species specific data is very limited and no catch data has been reported to FAO by any of its main African or Asian range States. Anguilla bengalensis is the most common eel in Indian inland waters and is of considerable commercial value in India and the Andaman Islands. On local markets in both India and Bangladesh A. bengalensis is only sold during the yellow or silver eel stage; live eels (greater than 100 g) of this species, originating in Bangladesh, are being offered for sale on B2B marketplaces/trade platforms. Anguilla bengalensis is harvested in small quantities (on average between one and six specimens a day per fisherman) in the Ganale Dawa river basin in Ethiopia (Abelti et al. 2014). Yellow eel bycatch in Myanmar was reported as 12 t in 2017 with 10% of this believed to be A. marmorata or A. bengalensis (SEAFDEC 2018). Other uses of the species include treatment of arthritis, piles and meningitis in India (Talwar and Jhingran 1991, Chanu et al. 2014). In addition, A. bengalensis is considered a 'pristine rare ornamental species of the Himalayan drainage' often being preserved in temple ponds for religious purposes (Shrestha 2003).

International trade in Anguilla commodities is reported from much of A. bengalensis’s range, however, the species composition of shipments is unknown and could contain many different Anguilla species including A. bicolor, A. marmorata and A. mossambica. According to UN Comtrade, exports of eel commodities (live, fresh, frozen and prepared eel) from south Asian countries increased from ~1,330 t in 2008 to ~5,170 t in 2015 (however, data is incomplete and this may be an underestimate), with live (from Bangladesh) and frozen eels (from India) being the main commodities for export. Myanmar reported exports live eels in 2010, 2014 and 2016, totalling ~10,900 t, however, live eel exports in the region are known to include other non-Anguilla eel species such as Monopterus albus (Swamp Eels). Madagascar, South Africa, Tanzania and Mauritius also exported Anguilla commodities between 2008 and 2017, with most exports being live and frozen eels from Madagascar (273 t) and South Africa (129 t). Exports of live eels (all life stages) from Madagascar increased gradually from 4.6 t in 2004 to 8.8 t in 2009 and then in 2010 there was a dramatic increase in exports to over 45 t. From 2011 to 2015 annual exports fluctuated between 16t and 26 t, and in 2016 and 2017 they declined again to ~11 t. Companies trading in the southern and east Africa region declare that their glass and adult live eels are A. mossambica and that they are able to differentiate between species and control harvesting as glass eel recruitment is asynchronous, however exports to East Asia of live eels caught in Madagascar, Mozambique and South Africa have been reported to include other species (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019).
conservationActions:
There are no known species-specific policies in place for Anguilla bengalensis. In South Africa in 1994, the River Health Programme (RHP) was established to monitor the health and ecosystem services provided by riverine habitats and, where necessary, establish protected areas to rejuvenate ecosystems and minimise human impacts (River Health Programme 2003). There are also plans to try and increase upstream and downstream river connectivity in South Africa, by linking adjoining sub-catchments in an attempt to aid migration (Rivers-Moore et al. 2011). Eels and eel pathways / migratory routes are also implicit in the Environmental Water Requirement (EWR) and Resource Directed Measures (RDM) methods in South Africa. Native Anguilla spp. are to be included within the South African National Biodiversity Institute (SANBI) National Biodiversity Assessment (NBA) 2018 (Skowno et al. 2019).

The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) member states (AMSs) have, since 2015, established management initiatives for anguillid eels, which includes developing policy and research (SEAFDEC 2018). In 2016, a workshop was held by the Inland Fishery Resources Development and Management Department/South Asian Fisheries Development Center (IFRDMD/SEAFDEC). This was held to address issues on data collection for eels in Southeast Asia, exchange existing fisheries information, and discuss recommendations to improve the sustainability of anguillid eel fisheries across this range (SEAFDEC 2016). A number of recommendations were suggested, which included harmonising data collection methods, and strengthening regulations on eel trade (SEAFDEC 2016). More recent workshops held by SEAFDEC have taken place in 2019, on both “Statistics of Tropical Anguillid Eels in Southeast Asia” and “Aquaculture of Tropical Anguillid Eels in Southeast Asia” (SEAFDEC 2019).

A scientific meeting on the “3rd International Symposium on the Tropical Eels Genus Anguilla (ISTEGA)” was held in Manado, North Sulawesi, Indonesia, from 1–3 August 2019. The international symposium held by the Indonesian Society of Tropical Eels (ISTES) and supported by the Indonesian Institute of Science as Indonesian Scientific Authority, and two national universities: Sam Ratulangi University of North Sulaewesi, and Tadulako University of Central Sulawesi. The theme of the 3rd ISTEGA 2019 was “science, conservation, and management of the tropical eel genus Anguilla for sustainable use”.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient given the lack of recent information on its distribution, population status and threats in central Peru.
habitat: This species can be found on the forest floor of the Amazonian flanks of the Andes (Heyer 1994). It is thought to occur almost exclusively in closed forest habitats (Heyer 1994). While there are no direct data on this species, reproduction may take place in foam nests in temporary ponds.
threats: While the type locality (Chontilla) appears to be in a relatively good conservation status, some intervening areas in between the known localities are threatened by habitat loss due to increased agricultural activity, which is largely driven by government policies (land tenancy of the area is conditional upon converting forest to agricultural land). The Palcazú Valley is severely fragmented in its lower and mid-altitudinal reaches. The establishment of large livestock grazing  areas is identified as the main mechanism of habitat fragmentation in the vicinity of Yanachaga Chemillén National Park. Illegal logging inside the Oxapampa-Asháninka-Yánesha Biosphere Reserve, as well as migratory agriculture and unsustainable use of agrochemicals are also threats (UNESCO 2016). Although the environmental impact assessment study of Block 107 did not record this species in 2008, the establishment of several oil concessions in the area could likely pose a threat to the remaining subpopulation (Larsen 2015), should it still be extant at this site.
population: This species is only known from the type series and museum specimens. Recent field surveys (September 2007 and May 2008) did not record this species in the vicinity of its type locality (J.C. Chaparro pers. comm. June 2010). An environmental impact assessment study conducted in Block 107 in both dry and rainy seasons also failed to record this species in Chontilla; however, it is possible that these latest surveys may have been conducted in the other peak of Chontilla. During February 2015, systematic nocturnal surveys were performed on the north-western slopes of the Sira: 1 hr 30 min surveys with two observers at each 100 m elevation, between 800 and 1,500 m asl (C. Beirne pers. comm. May 2016). In March 2015, five observers conducted surveys on the same ridge for four hours from 1,500–1,850 m asl (C. Beirne pers. comm. May 2016). In March 2016, two people searched for two hours at the highest peak on the ridge, between 1,800 and 1,925 m asl (C. Beirne pers. comm. May 2016). All searches were unsuccessful in detecting any individuals of this species; however it could be that these searches occurred above the elevational range of the species.
range: This species is known from the double-peaked Mount Chontilla at 780 m asl, in the Iscozazin Valley, Pasco Region, from Serranía del Sira, Huánuco Region (Heyer 1994), and from Tingo Maria (651 m asl), Huánuco Region (A. Angulo pers. comm. 2017), in central Peru, east of the Andes. Although the species description lists its upper elevational range as 2,500 m asl, the 2009 El Sira Communal Reserve Master Plan indicates that the elevational range of the reserve oscillates around 2,000 m asl. Furthermore, the El Sira specimen was examined by Duellman and Toft (1979, as Leptodactylus wagneri), who determined its elevational range in this area to be 500–690 m asl. Thus, it is considered to occur between 500–780 m asl. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 8,075 km2.
useTrade: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"There is no information on the use or trade of this species."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":9149,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"16":11}">There is no information on this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species can be found within the Yanesha Communal Reserve (Chontilla is within this reserve), and it might also occur in El Sira Communal Reserve, Parque Nacional Yanachaga Chemillén and Bosque de Protección San Matias San Carlos, although its presence at these protected areas needs to be verified. All of these conservation areas are within the Oxapampa-Asháninka-Yánesha Biosphere Reserve, established in 2010 (UNESCO 2010). 

Conservation Needed
Enforcement is needed to curb the current and future threats to the Yanesha Communal Reserve.

Research Needed
Surveys in the appropriate elevational range are urgently needed to relocate this species at its known localities and in the intervening areas.

rationale: Rhoadsia altipinna occurs at low elevations from the Guayas River drainage southward to the Tumbes River on the Pacific slope of western Ecuador and northwestern Peru. Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 97,772 km2. This species is highly abundant in western Ecuador and often comprises a dominant portion of the ichthyofauna based on the total number of individuals. Population may be declining locally, but is suspected to be relatively stable range-wide. Despite a number of pervasive threats in western Ecuador and northern Peru, this species remains abundant and does not appear to be under significant threat. Therefore, R. altipinna is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This omnivorous, benthopelagic species occurs in rivers with moderate water velocity and rocky substrates (Revelo and Laaz 2012). In the Santa Rosa River drainage, this species was more common in pool mesohabitats when compared to riffle mesohabitats (Aguirre et al. 2016). Maximum reported body size is 17 cm, but adults more commonly reach 10 cm standard length (SL) (Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015). Weight-length relationships have been established in the Atacames and Súa watersheds, based on extensive sampling of 1,720 individuals (Jiménez-Prado et al. 2019).
threats:
Western Ecuador is heavily impacted by anthropogenic factors including habitat transformation for the development of agricultural fields and towns, the building of dams and creation of artificial reservoirs, habitat deterioration due to pollution, mining and severe river bank modification, and heavy fishing pressure (Aguirre et al. 2014).

The Guayas River basin is subject to a number of anthropogenic stressors on local and regional scales (Loh et al. 2014, Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2016, 2018). In a basin-wide ecological water quality analysis, poor water quality was consistently detected around arable land and adjacent to residential areas (Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2016). The Guayas River basin supports much of the Ecuador’s industrial scale agricultural production, has contributed to high concentrations of pesticide pollutants throughout the watershed (Deknock et al. 2019, Cambien et al. 2020), and continues to drive deforestation as agricultural land-use expands (Borbor-Cordova et al. 2006, Aguirre et al. 2021). Intensive grazing is a standard practice for cattle farming in the lower reaches of the drainage (Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2018). The basin supports a human population of approximately 5.5 million inhabitants (Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2018). Population growth and associated increases in urban expansion and industrial processes have degraded habitat quality around urban population centres (Damanik-Ambarita et al. 2016, Rivera Vera 2017). The agricultural industry in the Guayas River basin is based on monoculture systems, and contributes to the production of about 20% of bananas and 83% of rice for Ecuador (INEC 2016). Mining activity near the Guayas or Santa Rosa River basins presents a threat to aquatic species, including areas such as Ponce Enriquez where the mercury toxicity threshold was three times higher than the threshold recommended for the protection of aquatic life (Appleton et al. 2001).

Gold mining is the primary economic activity in the upper basin of the Puyango-Tumbes River basin (Marshall et al. 2018, Schudel et al. 2018, Marshall et al. 2020). Amalgamation processing occurs primarily in the municipality of Portovelo, Ecuador, where byproducts and wastewater is discharged directly into the Puyango watershed (Marshall et al. 2018, Aguirre et al. 2021). Agricultural production and cattle ranching dominate the landscape in the middle and lower region of the basin, and include the production of bananas, rice, corn, fruit, chickens, goats, cattle, hogs, and sheep (Marshall et al. 2018). Coastal margins and the Tumbes River delta have been developed extensively for shrimp farming (Mialhe et al. 2013).

Despite inferred and continuous declines in freshwater habitat quality, population trend is suspected to be stable or declining slowly.
population:
The total population size of R. altipinna is unknown. However, it is one of the most common species of fishes on the Pacific coast of Ecuador (Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015). This species was dominant in the Abras de Mantequilla wetland, despite a number of localized pervasive threats (e.g., hydroelectric damming, intense fertilizer use, deforestation, and agricultural expansion) (Alvarez-Mieles et al. 2013), and in the Ruidoso River (Aucapiña Franco 2017). In the Santa Rosa River, it was the second most abundant species (Aguirre et al. 2016). In the Viches River, it comprised 16.9% of relative fish abundance by number of individuals captured (Angulo Collahuazo 2020).

Population may be declining locally in the Jubobes River Basin due to the loss of natural refuges, habitat, and riparian vegetation associated with hydroelectric development (Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015). However, this species does not appear to be threatened on a range-wide scale and population trend is suspected to be stable or declining slowly.
range:
Rhoadsia altipinna occurs at low to moderate elevations from the Guayas River drainage (Barriga et al. 2012) southward to the Tumbes River (Valenzuela Reyna 2014), on the Pacific slope of western Ecuador and northwestern Peru (Loh et al. 2014) and including the Catamayo, Chira, and Jubones rivers (Jiménez-Prado et al. 2015). Range may extend northward into the Esmeraldes river drainage (Glodek 1978), but records in this drainage may also represent the close congener R. minor (Loh et al. 2014).

Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 97,772 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around georeferenced collection records (GBIF 2020). Given its relatively broad range. R. altipinna likely occurs in greater than ten threat-based locations. Altitudinal range extends from 25-1,400 masl.
useTrade: This species is not utilized in any commercial capacity, though it has potential as an ornamental species due to the bright coloration of males (Revelo and Laaz 2012). This species may be useful as a sentinel species in areas that are affected by mercury pollution associated with mining and amalgamation processes (Sánchez 2019).
conservationActions: This species is currently of relatively low conservation concern, given high population abundance and a broad range that extends into a number of protected areas (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020), including Abras de Mantequilla wetland (Nugra et al. 2015), a designated Ramsar site, and private conservation areas such as the Palenque River and Pedro Franco Dávila protective forests (P. Arugello pers. comm. 2021). Additional research regarding the direct impact of existing threats would be useful in clarifying the conservation status of this species.

rationale: Chaetostoma microps is widespread throughout headwaters of the Amazon River basin in Ecuador and Peru, and also occurs in the Guayas River drainage and the Tumbes River drainage on the Pacific slopes of Ecuador and Peru, respectively. Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 126,668 km2. Total population size and population trend are unknown. A number of regionally pervasive threats continue to degrade freshwater habitat quality in Ecuador and Peru, including regional land-use changes associated with agricultural expansion, mining activities, oil drilling, dam construction, and pollution. However, there is currently no evidence of major declines in range extent or abundance. Therefore, C. microps is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: Chaetostoma microps is broadly distributed throughout freshwater rivers, streams, and high elevation lagoons (Lujan et al. 2015, Anaguano-Yancha 2017). Elevational distribution extends to a recorded maximum of 1,783 meters above sea level (masl) (Anaguano-Yancha 2017). This species also occasionally enters cave systems, where it has been observed climbing steep flowstone waterfalls (Hoese et al. 2015). Individuals adhere to rocks to feed on periphyton over rocky, gravel, and sandy bottoms (P. Arguello and R. Barriga pers. comm. 2021). Mature males are sexually dimorphic based on enlargement of the unplated, fleshy snout region (Lujan et al. 2015). Maximum reported body size is 8.9 cm total length (TL) (Fisch-Muller 2003).
threats:
Western Ecuador is heavily impacted by anthropogenic factors including habitat transformation for the development of agricultural fields and towns, the building of dams and creation of artificial reservoirs, habitat deterioration due to pollution, mining, and severe river bank modification (Aguirre et al. 2014, 2021). The primary threats to freshwater habitat in western Peru include runoff and pollution associated with urban centres, deforestation and pollution associated with unsustainable agricultural activities, and hydrological modification to support irrigation as urban and agricultural development continue (Ortega and Hidalgo 2008).

In the Ecuadorian and Peruvian Amazon, there are a number of threats associated with land-use change and extractive activities, including deforestation, expanding agriculture, mining and drilling, construction of dams and waterways, and widespread pollution associated with these activities (Castello et al. 2013). However, Loricariids are especially resilient to habitat changes associated with deforestation and losses in forest cover, and in some cases increase in abundance in deforested sections of river (Bojsen and Barriga 2002).

Despite inferred continuing decline in habitat quality, the direct impacts of existing threats on C. microps have not been studied in detail, and there is currently no evidence of major, range-wide population decline.
population: The total population size and population trend of this species are unknown. However, local subsistence fishers anecdotally report significant declines in abundance in the Tumbes River as a result of overfishing (Valenzuela Reyna 2014). Ichthyological sampling throughout the basin in 2012 yielded a single individual (Valenzuela Reyna 2014).
range:
Chaetostoma microps is widespread throughout headwaters of the Amazon River basin in Ecuador and Peru, from the Napo and Pastaza river drainages southward to the Huallaga River drainage (Lujan et al. 2015). It has also been reported from the Guayas River drainage and the Tumbes River drainage on the Pacific slopes of Ecuador and Peru, respectively (Ortega and Hidalgo 2008, Barriga 2012, Valenzuela Reyna 2014).

Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 126,668 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around georeferenced collection records (GBIF 2020).
useTrade: This species is occasionally captured in subsistence fisheries in the Tumbes River drainage (Ortega and Hidalgo 2008).
conservationActions: There are currently no species-specific conservation measures directed towards C. microps. The range of this species is broadly distributed throughout a number of protected areas (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020). Further study regarding population size, especially in Pacific Peruvian drainages, and additional research regarding the direct impact of existing threats would be useful in clarifying the conservation status of this species.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it occurs in XX threat-defined locations, and there is a continuing decline in the quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 19,595 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in three to nine threat-defined locations, and there is a continuing decline in the quality of its habitat in the Andean foothills along the headwaters of the Río Madre de Dios basin.
habitat: This species occurs in forests of the Andean foothills. This area is covered by Amazonian forest with Guadua spp. formations as well as primary forest with predominant presence of trees of the genera Erythrina, Ormosia, Inga, Hevea, and Virola. Frogs are active on the ground at night during the end of the rainy season (April). Its breeding biology is unknown, but it is presumed to breed by direct development similar to its congeners. Although testis and vocal slits were evident in all three males specimens that have been collected, they greatly differ in size (20.7–30.8 SVL), which might indicate that males reach maturity early in development (Padial et al. 2012).
threats: The species overlaps with large areas where creeks and streams are being destroyed by gold mining and this is a severe issue in the lowlands. The forest in which the species occurs is also destroyed by these activities, but because the species does not rely on running water for reproduction, it is possible that the species is able to survive in these areas (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017). Logging, cattle grazing, and oil exploration are also taking place throughout its range, which degrades and destroys its habitat.
population: The type series is comprised of three specimens recorded from two localities. Three additional individuals were collected during June–September 2013 (Villacampa Ortega 2013). The species is very common at Villa Carmen biological station in the buffer zone of Manu National Park, has been recorded from the Kosñipata Valley, and from lower elevations at the Manu Learning Center, which is also in the buffer zone of Manu National Park (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017). Moreover the species was reported in 2016 from the buffer zone of the Bahuaja Sonene National Park near the Inca Mine at Santo Domingo (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017). The population trend is unknown.
range: This species is known from several localities in the Andean foothills along the headwaters of the Río Madre de Dios basin, in Cusco, Puno, and Madre de Dios Regions of Peru (Padial et al. 2012). It occurs at elevations from 685–1,235 m asl, it occurs in three to nine threat-defined locations, and its EOO is 19,595 km2. It may occur more widely than currently mapped, possibly into Bolivia (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species occurs in the Amarakaeri Communal Reserve and the private land of the Manu Learning Center in Madre de Dios. It has not been recorded in Manu National Park, but may occur there. It is listed as Endangered (EN) in Peru and has legal protection provided by the Categorization in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna (Decreto Supremo Nº004-2014-MINAGRI), which bans all hunting, capture, possession, transport or export of the species for commercial purposes.

Conservation Needed
Improved habitat protection is required at sites where this species is known to occur.

Research Needed
Further research on this species' distribution, population status, ecology and life history is needed.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern, since although this recently described species exhibits a restricted distribution – its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 609 km<sup>2</sup> – it is expected to have a much wider range than its current confirmed distribution, it is consistently found during surveys, it occurs in several protected areas, and threats only affect small parts of its estimated range.
habitat: This species inhabits humid sub-montane forests. Males call from grasses, shrubs, and trees up to 2 m above the ground in the understory of the submontane forest, during crepuscular hours and at night, immediately after heavy rains (Shepack et al. 2016). A pair was observed in amplexus in January and the oviducts of this female contained 22 unpigmented eggs, ca 2.5 mm in diameter (Shepack et al. 2016). It is expected to reproduce by direct development, as with other congeners.
threats: Habitat loss due to mining and gas exploration, logging, and coca plantations are localized. Four out of ten individuals tested positive for Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis, the chytrid fungus implicated in population declines of numerous other amphibian species in the region (Catenazzi et al. 2011, 2014). It remains unknown what effect Bd has had on this species, however there is no evidence for population declines (Shepack et al. 2016).
population: It was the second most common species based on the number of sites at which it was detected (14 of 20 samples) during 2014–2015 in the Amarakaeri Communal Reserve, Madre de Dios Region (Deichmann et al. 2017). Due to ongoing localised declines in the extent and quality of its habitat, some subpopulations are suspected to be decreasing.
range: This recently described (2016) species is known from the Kosñipata and Entoro valleys in the buffer zone of Manu National Park and within the Huachiperi Haramba Queros Conservation Concession, in Cusco, as well as Amarakaeri Communal Reserve in Madre de Dios, Peru. It occurs from 40–1,110 m asl and its EOO is 609 km<sup>2</sup>, but it may occur much more widely as there is a lot of suitable habitat outside of the known range.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
In addition to being found in the buffer zone, it is likely to occur within, Manu National Park, it has also been recorded in the Huachiperi Haramba Queros Conservation Concession, a protected area consisting of state-owned lands given in concession to private organizations with the goal of preserving biodiversity (Shepack et al. 2016) and Amarakaeri Communal Reserve (Deichmann et al. 2017).

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: Atherinella venezeulae is restricted to Lago de Valencia, a freshwater lake within the Tuy-Valencia biogeographic subprovince on the Atlantic versant of Venezuela. This species only occurs within the lake, and has not been reported from lotic habitats feeding the lake. Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 495 km2 and Area of Occupancy (AOO) is estimated to be 68-512 km2. The primary threats to this species includes severe habitat degradation associated with sewage, runoff, and industrial wastes. The establishment of non-native species (e.g., Oreochromis mossambicus) is driving continuing declines in the number of mature individuals through direct predation. Continuing declines in habitat quality, habitat availability, and in the number of mature individuals are inferred. Lake populations may exhibit extreme fluctuation in the number of mature individuals based on the availability of food resources. Therefore, A. venezeulae is assessed as Endangered under criterion B1ab(iii,v)+B2ab(iii,v). Additional ichthyological survey and more detailed information regarding the direct impact of existing threats is necessary to clarify the extinction risk of this species.
habitat: Lago de Valencia is an endorheic watershed characterized by eutrophic conditions and a rich benthic and planktonic fauna (Unger and Lewis 1991, Grande 2019). Atherinella venezuelae is exclusively a freshwater, pelagic species carrying its entire life out in the limnetic zone of Lago de Valencia (Unger and Lewis 1983, 1991). This species is planktivorous, with juveniles targeting rotifers, and larger individuals targeting successively larger zooplankton (Unger and Lewis 1983). Spawning occurs in the littoral zone of water bodies throughout the year (Unger and Lewis 1991). Adults typically live 1-2 years (Unger and Lewis 1991). Maximum reported body size is 5 cm total length (TL) (Dyer et al. 2003).
threats:
Lago de Valencia is severely impacted by anthropogenic pollution from nearby cities, industry, and plantation agriculture (López-Rojas and Bonillo-Rivero 2000, Grande 2019). In the last three decades, the majority of rivers and streams feeding Lago de Valencia have been filled with industrial waste and raw sewage. Most pollutants come from the Cabriales River in Carabobo as it passes through the city of Valencia. Los Guayos River receives a number of chemical wastes as it passes through industrial zones. Similarly, the Tapa Tapa River in Aragua passes through a large industrial zone, and eventually transports these wastes in Lago de Valencia (O.M. Lasso-Alcalá pers. comm. 2020). Increased water use around Lago de Valencia has contributed significantly to the loss of tributaries feeding the lake (López-Rojas and Bonillo-Rivero 2000). A number of construction activities have contributed to increased sedimentation and destruction of river channels (López-Rojas and Bonillo-Rivero 2000).

There is considerable evidence to suggest that the introduction of Oreochromic mossambicus into Lago de Valencia in 1959 was a primary driver of population decline (Pérez et al. 2004, Miranda et al. 2010). Additionally, the translocated Caqueatia kraussii is a predator of larval and adult A. venezuelae.

Despite uncertainties regarding the direct impact of existing threats and their direct impact on A. venezuelae, continuing declines in habitat quality and habitat availability are inferred.
population: The total population size of this species is unknown. Trophic ecology in historical habitat suggests that mature adults may exhibit periods of extreme fluctuation based on the availability of food resources (Unger and Lewis 1991). Continued decline in the number of mature individuals is inferred, based on the establishment of Mozambique Tilapia (Oreochromis mossambicus) in Lago de Valencia, which has been identified as a predator of eggs, larvae, and adults (Infante 1981, 1985, Infante and LaBar 1977, Pereira et al. 1981, Ortaz 1985, Royero and Lasso 1992, Señaris and Lasso 1993, Bisbal 2000).
range:
Atherinella venezeulae is restricted to the endorheic Lago de Valencia watershed in the Tuy-Valencia biogeographic subprovince on the Atlantic versant of Venezuela (Eigenmann 1920, Schultz 1949, Luengo 1963, Campo 2003, Brian and Dyer 2006, Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2009, Campo and Ortáz 2015). All records belong to the lake itself and not to the tributary rivers of Lago de Valencia. Some records come from waters in front of the mouth of the Guacara River (August 1970), Punta Palmita (March 1977) and El Burro Island in the centre of the lake (July 2001), while in Aragua, it has only been reported in the Hacienda Macapo (June 2003) on the shores of Lago de Valencia (Campo 2003).

Historical and more recent collections on Trinidad have been taken from tide pools at Brighton Beach, coastal rivers near La Brea Beach, and Gaspar Grande in habitat characterized by relatively high salinity (20-37 ppt) (Fowler 1931, Dyer et al. 2003, Campanella et al. 2015). However, these collection records are likely to represent a separate species (A. brasiliensis). Important taxonomic revisions of the Atheriniformes group do not indicate this species for Trinidad (Chernoff 1986). Likewise, in the latest and most comprehensive review of freshwater and estuarine fishes from the Trinidad and Tobago Islands (Phillip et al. 2013), based on a review of collections and exhaustive field surveys, A. venezuelae was not detected. Therefore, occurrence on Trinidad is unlikely.

Lago de Valencia occupies a surface area of 280 km2 (López-Rojas and Bonillo-Rivero 2000). Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is estimated to be 495 km2, based on a minimum convex polygon calculated around Lago de Valencia. Area of Occupancy (AOO) is estimated to be 68-512 km2, with a lower estimate based on a 2 km2 grid overlain on georeferenced collection records, and an upper estimate calculated by overlaying a 2 km2 grid over the entirety of Lago de Valencia. Given several threats that are likely acting on the entire known distribution of this species (López-Rojas and Bonillo-Rivero 2000), and occurrence only from Lago de Valencia (Campo 2003), a single threat-based location is inferred.
useTrade: This species is used as a bait item by fisherfolk targetting Curvinata (Plagioscion squamosissimus) (O.M. Lasso-Alcalá pers. comm. 2020).
conservationActions: There are currently no species-specific conservation measures directed towards A. venezuelae. Its distribution is unlikely to extend into the boundaries of any protected areas (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020). Site protection and monitoring are needed to reduce pollutant inputs into Lago de Valencia. Further research regarding population size, population trend, and the direct impact of existing threats is urgently needed to clarify the extinction risk of this species.

rationale: This species is listed as Near Threatened on the basis that it is suspected to be undergoing a moderately rapid population decline owing to a number of widespread threats.
habitat: Behaviour This species is strongly migratory (del Hoyo et al. 1992) and often travels considerable distances over land making brief stop-overs on inland waters (Madge and Burn 1988). It arrives on its breeding grounds between late-April and May and breeds from late-May onwards (Madge and Burn 1988) in highly dispersed (Kear 2005) solitary pairs (del Hoyo et al. 1992). After mating (from June onwards), males migrate long distances prior to their flightless moult, most travelling in small groups to inshore or offshore coastal waters (Madge and Burn 1988). Females and juveniles leave the breeding grounds in September (Madge and Burn 1988). The species is highly gregarious when not breeding (Madge and Burn 1988) with males forming large congregations during the flightless moulting period (Kear 2005). Large flocks of several hundred to a thousand (Snow and Perrins 1998) or occasionally over 100,000 individuals can be observed during winter (Scott and Rose 1996). Non-breeders often oversummer on the wintering grounds (Madge and Burn 1988). Habitat Breeding The species breeds on Arctic dwarf heath (Snow and Perrins 1998, Kear 2005) or boggy tundra on pools, small lakes, streams (del Hoyo et al. 1992) and slow-flowing rivers (Snow and Perrins 1998). It shows a preference for freshwater habitats (del Hoyo et al. 1992) with low banks (Flint et al. 1984), small islets (Kear 2005) and high abundances of aquatic invertebrate and plant life positioned in swampy valleys or among mossy bogs (Flint et al. 1984), especially where suitable shrubs (e.g. willow or birch) and herbaceous vegetation are available for nesting cover (Johnsgard 1978, Snow and Perrins 1998, Kear 2005). It generally avoids areas with steep slopes or wetlands enclosed by forest (Kear 2005). Non-breeding Although the species may use freshwater lakes on migration (Madge and Burn 1988, Kear 2005) the majority moult and overwinter at sea (Kear 2005) or shallow inshore waters less than 20 m deep (Kear 2005) (optimally 5-15 m [Scott and Rose 1996]) with abundant benthic fauna (Kear 2005), generally between 500 m and c.2 km from the shore (Snow and Perrins 1998). Diet Its diet consists predominantly of molluscs, especially during the winter (del Hoyo et al. 1992), although it occasionally takes other aquatic invertebrates such as crustaceans (del Hoyo et al. 1992) (e.g. barnacles and shrimps [Johnsgard 1978]), worms (del Hoyo et al. 1992), echinoderms, isopods, amphidods (Kear 2005) and insects (e.g. midges and caddisflies [del Hoyo et al. 1992]) as well as small fish (del Hoyo et al. 1992) and fish eggs (Snow and Perrins 1998).
